chap.title: Volume 1, Section V. - extract
chap.p: From Gar∫tang to Lanca∫ter there is little change in the land∫cape. It ∫till continues bleak and unplea∫ant. But as we now approached the mountains, every object began to proclaim the rugged ∫cenes, into which we were entering. The country we now traver∫ed, may be called a kind of connecting thread: it∫elf of an uncharacterized ∫pecies, ∫triking us with no determined features. It has neither the grandeur of the mountain ∫cene; nor the chearfulne∫s of the ∫ylvan: what wood there is, is poor, and ∫hrivelled. For we now ∫kirted the bay of Cartmel, and the ∫ea-air having caught the trees, had impoveri∫hed their foliage, ∫tinted their growth, and de∫troyed their very form, with unu∫ual rigour.

At a mile's di∫tance Lanca∫ter-ca∫tle ri∫es to view. It's lofty ∫ituation, it's ma∫∫y towers, and exten∫ive buildings (for it is connected with the church) give an air of grandeur to it's appearance: but as parts are neither well ∫haped, nor well combined, it is but an indifferent object from any point. On the ∫pot, the mo∫t beautiful part is a noble front; which, with it's other grand appendages, afford ∫ufficient matter for the curio∫ity of an antiquarian.
On the other ∫ide of the town the river Lune, which is a noble piece of water, when the tide is full, ∫ufficiently adorns the land∫cape.

But here the Lune is a bu∫y, noi∫y ∫cene, banked with quays; covered with ∫hipping; and re∫ounding with nautic clamour. Far otherwi∫e is it's pa∫∫age, a few miles above, through the vale of Lond∫dale; where quietly, and unob∫erved, it winds around projecting rocks -- forms circling boundaries to meadows, pa∫tured with cattle -- or pa∫∫es through groves and thickets, which, in fabulous times, might have been the haunt of wood-gods. In one part, taking a ∫udden turn it circles a little, delicious ∫pot, forming it into a penin∫ula,
called vulgarly, the wheel of Lune. Here once dwelt an ancient hermit; where his eyes ∫aw nothing, nor wi∫hed to ∫ee any thing, except the ∫weet vale, in which he lived.

From the ca∫tle-hill, or rather from the church-yard, we had a very exten∫ive view, compo∫ed of the grande∫t objects. Along the meadows below, the river Lune, now an e∫tuary, and adorned with a variety of coasting ve∫∫els, (le∫∫ening to the eye, through it's ∫everal reaches,) ha∫tens to the ∫ea. In a mile or two, it enters the bay of Cartmel; which filled with the tide, pre∫ents a noble extent of water, ten or twelve miles acro∫s, bounded by the mountains of Furne∫s; which extend through va∫t ∫pace; and then circling the head of the bay, form many a ∫hooting promontory, and many a winding ∫hore.

This exten∫ion of wild country we looked at with regret, knowing the many noble ∫cenes it contained, which we had not had time to vi∫it. We were obliged to re∫t ∫atisfied with forming imaginary pictures among the blue mi∫ts of the mountains. Our guide, an unlettered ∫wain, pointed out, in the broad dialect of his country, the ∫everal ∫pots -- where the ruins of Furne∫s-abbey lay ∫eque∫tered in a lowly vales -- where, far
to the we∫t, Peel-ca∫tle, running boldly out into the water, commanded the entrance of the bay -- where, deep beneath tho∫e purpli∫h mountains, the lake of Coni∫ton occupied a valley ∫ix miles in length -- where Holker-hall; and Bard∫ey; and Coni∫hed, founded on the ∫ite of an ancient priory; and many other places of renowned ∫ituation, were all ∫urrounded with ∫cenes of grandeur; and each, as far as we could judge from our intelligence, with ∫cenes peculiar to it∫elf.

From Lanca∫ter, in our rout to Kendal, the country, every ∫tep, becomes more characteri∫tic. High, ∫helving grounds ari∫e on the right; and on the left, at every opening, we have different views of the bay of Cartmel, and of the mountains of Furne∫s. The fore-ground is every where adorned with large, detached ∫tones; which indicate the rocks we approach.
A little beyond Burton we left the great road and took a circuit of two or three miles to ∫ee the country about Milthorp, and Levens.

Cartmel-bay branches here into a creek; on the ea∫tern ∫ide of which lies Milthorp; a little coa∫ting-port-town; and near it Dalham-tower, in a plea∫ant park, defended by a hill from the ∫ea-air. All around we have beautiful views, con∫i∫ting of woody ∫ore-grounds, and of di∫tances compo∫ed of different parts of this little e∫tuary, and it's appendant mountains.

As we proceeded higher up the creek, the views, increa∫ed in beauty. About Levens, a ∫eat of the early of Suffolk, there is a happy combination of every thing that is lovely and great in land∫cape. It ∫tands at the head of the creek, upon the Kenet, a wild romantic ∫tream, which ru∫hes into the tide, a little below. The hou∫e, incompa∫∫ed with hilly grounds, is well ∫creened from the pernicious effects of the ∫ea-air. But we did not ride up to it. The woods with which it abounds, we were told, grow luxuriantly; and the views at hand are as plea∫ing, as tho∫e at a di∫tance, are great; which con∫i∫t of a lengthened beach of ∫and along the creek; and of Whitbarrow-cragg, a rough, and very picture∫que promontory; with other high lands, ∫hooting into the bay.

Among the beautiful objects of di∫tance, we con∫ider a winding ∫and-beach, e∫pecially when ∫een from a woody fore-ground. It's hue, amid the verdure of foliage, is a plea∫ant, cha∫ti∫ing tint. When the tide flows, the ∫ands change their appearance, and take the ∫till more plea∫ing form of a noble lake.
Levens is at pre∫ent in a neglected ∫tate: but is certainly capable of being made equal to almo∫t any ∫cene in England.

From hence we proceeded to Kendal; ∫ituated in a wild, unplea∫ant country, which contains no ∫triking objects; and cannot be formed into any of tho∫e plea∫ing combinations, which con∫titute a picture. Here and there a view may be found; though but ∫eldom. The ca∫tle, which is a mere ruin, is in ∫ome ∫ituations, e∫pecially near the bridge, a good object.
Between Kendal and Amble∫ide, the wood increa∫es in grandeur; but the ∫cenery is ∫till undetermined. The whole is a ∫ort of confu∫ed greatne∫s.

As we de∫cend to the left, we approach Windermere, where a different ∫pecies of country ∫ucceeds. The wild mountains, which were ∫o ill-ma∫∫ed, and of a kind ∫o unaccommodating to land∫cape, are left behind; and the road dips into a lovely ∫ylvan ∫cene, leading interchangeably through clo∫e groves, under wooded hills, and along the banks of the lake.

chap.title: Volume 1, Section VI.
chap.head: SECT. VI.
chap.p: WE had now arrived on the confines of tho∫e romantic ∫cenes, which were the principal inducement to this tour. Here therefore we propo∫ed to make ∫ome pau∫e; and pay a little more attention to the country, than a ha∫ty pa∫∫age through it, would allow.

But to render a de∫cription of the∫e ∫cenes more intelligible; and to ∫hew more di∫tinctly the ∫ources of that kind of beauty, with which they abound; it may be proper, before we examine the ∫cenes them∫elves, to take a ∫ort of analytical view of the materials, which compo∫e them -- mountains -- lakes -- broken grounds -- wood -- rocks -- ca∫cades -- vallies -- and rivers.

With regard to mountains, it may be fir∫t premi∫ed, that, in a picture∫que view, we con∫ider them only as di∫tant objects; their enor-
mous ∫ize di∫qualifying them for objects at hand. In the removed part of a picture therefore, the mountain properly appears; where it's immen∫ity, reduced by di∫tance, can be taken in by the eye; and it's mon∫trous features, lo∫ing their deformity, a∫∫ume a ∫oftne∫s which naturally belongs not to them.

I would not however be under∫tood to mean, that a mountain is proper only to clo∫e an extended view. It may take it's ∫tation in a ∫econd, or third di∫tance with equal propriety. And even on a fore-ground, a rugged corner of it's ba∫e may be introduced; tho it's upper regions a∫pire far beyond the limits of an picture.

Having thus premi∫ed the ∫tation, which a mountain properly occupies in land∫cape, we ∫hall now examine the mountain it∫elf; in which, four things particularly ∫trike us -- it's line -- the objects, which adorn it's ∫urface -- it's tints -- and it's light and ∫hade.

The beauty of a di∫tant mountain in a great mea∫ure, depends on the line it traces along
the ∫ky; which is generally of a lighter hue. The pyramidal ∫hape, and ea∫y flow of an irregular line, will be found in the mountain, as in other delineations, the true∫t ∫ource of beauty.

Mountains therefore ri∫ing in regular, mathematical lines, or in whim∫ical, grote∫que ∫hapes, are di∫plea∫ing. Thus Burn∫wark, a mountain on the ∫outhern border of Scotland; Thorp-Cloud, near Dovedale in Derby∫hire, e∫pecially when ∫een from the garden at Ilam; and a mountain in Cumberland, which from it's peculiar appearance in ∫ome ∫ituations, takes the name of Saddle-back, all form di∫agreeable lines. And thus many of the pointed ∫ummits of the Alps are objects rather of ∫ingularity, than of beauty. Such forms al∫o as ∫ugge∫t the idea of a lumpi∫h heavine∫s are di∫gu∫ting -- round, ∫welling forms, without any break to di∫incumber them of their weight.

Indeed a continuity of line without a break, whether it be concave, straight, or convex, will always di∫plea∫e, becau∫e it wants variety; unle∫s indeed it be well contra∫ted with other forms. The effect al∫o of a broken line is bad, if the breaks are regular.
The objects, which cover the ∫urface of mountains, are wood, rocks, broken ground, heath, and mo∫∫es of various hues.
Ovid has very ingeniou∫ly given us the furniture of a mountain in the transformation of Atlas.

poem.line: --Jam barba, comæque
In ∫ylvas abeunt; juge ∫unt humerique, manu∫que:
Quod caput ante fuit, ∫ummo e∫t in monte cacumen:
O∫∫a lapis ∫iunt.--

chap.p: His hair and beard become trees, and other vegetable ∫ub∫tance; his bones, rocks; and his head, and ∫houlders, ∫ummits, and promontories. --But to de∫cribe minutely the parts of a distant object (for we are con∫idering a mountain in this light) would be to invert the rules of per∫pective, by making that di∫tinct, which ∫hould be ob∫cure. I ∫hall con∫ider therefore all that variety, which covers the ∫urface of di∫tant mountains, as blended together in one ma∫s; and made the ∫tratum of tho∫e tints, which we often find playing upon them.

The∫e tints, which are the mo∫t beautiful ornaments of the mountain, are of all colours; but the mo∫t prevalent are yellow, and purple. We can hardly con∫ider blue as a mountain-tint. It is the mere colour of the intervening
air -- the hue, which naturally inve∫ts all di∫tant objects, as well as mountains. The late Dr. Brown, author of the E∫timate, in a de∫cription, which he printed, of the lake of Ke∫wick, very ju∫tly calls the∫e tints the yellow ∫treams of light, the purple hues, and mi∫ty azure of the mountains. They are rarely permanent; but ∫eem to be a ∫ort of floating, ∫ilky colours -- always in motion -- always in harmony -- and playing with a thousand changeable varieties into each other. They are literally colours dipped in heaven.

The variety of the∫e tints depends on many circum∫tances -- the ∫ea∫on of the year -- the hour of the day -- a dry, or moi∫t atmo∫phere. The lines and ∫hapes of mountains (features ∫trongly marked) are ea∫ily caught and retained: but the∫e meteor-forms, this rich fluctuation of airy hues, offer ∫uch a profu∫ion of variegated ∫plendor, that they are continually illuding the eye with breaking into each other; and are lo∫t, as it endeavours to retain them. This airy colouring, tho in ∫un∫hine it appears mo∫t brilliant; yet in ∫ome degree it is generally found in tho∫e mountains, where it prevails.

In the late voyages round the world, publi∫hed by Dr. Hawk∫worth, we have an account
of the great beauty of the colouring ob∫erved on the peak of Teneriffe. "It's appearance at "∫un-∫et, ∫ays the author, was very ∫riking. When the ∫un was below the horizon, and the re∫t of the i∫land appeared of a deep black; the mountain ∫till reflected his rays, and glowed with a warmth of colouring, which no painting can expre∫s."

The rays of the ∫un, which are the cau∫e of all colour, no doubt, produce the∫e tints to the eye; yet we mu∫t believe there is ∫omething peculiar in the ∫urfaces of ∫ome mountains, which di∫po∫e them to reflect the rays with ∫uch variety of tints. On many mountains the∫e appearances are not ob∫ervable; and where the ∫urface is uniform, the tint will be ∫o likewi∫e. "The effect in que∫tion, says Mr. Lock, remarking on this pa∫∫age, is very familiar to me. I ∫aw it almo∫t every evening in Savoy, when the ∫un ∫hone. It is only on the tops of the highe∫t mountains, that the effect is perfect. Mount Blanc being covered with the pure∫t ∫now, and having no tint of it's own, was often of the brighte∫t ro∫e-colour."

Having thus given the mountain a line; filled it with objects; and ∫pread over it a beau-
tiful a∫∫emblage of tins; it remains la∫tly to throw the whole into light and ∫hade.--He who would ∫tudy light and ∫hade, mu∫t repair to the mountains. There he will ∫ee their mo∫t magnificent effects.

In every object we ob∫erve a double effect of illumination, that of the parts, and that of the whole. In a building the cornices, the pila∫ters, and other ornaments, are ∫et off, in the language of art, with light and ∫hade. Over this partial effect are ∫pread the general ma∫∫es. It is thus in mountains.

Homer, who had a genius as picture∫que as Virgil, (tho he ∫eems to have known little of the art of painting) was ∫truck with two things in his views of mountains -- with tho∫e cavities and projections, which abound upon their ∫urfaces -- and with what he calls their ∫hadowing forms. Of the former, he takes notice, when he ∫peaks of a ∫ingle mountain; of the latter, when he ∫peaks of mountains in combination. Now it is plain, that in both the∫e
ca∫es he was plea∫ed with the effect of light and ∫hade. In one the partial effect is marked: in the other, the general.

note.p: Under the fir∫t idea he ∫peaks of Mount Olympus, which he calls πολυπτυχα, or many vallied. Il. 8. 411. Under the ∫econd, he ∫peaks of that chain of mountains, which ∫eparate Phthia from the ∫outhern parts of Greece;

poem.line: -- πολλα μεταξυ
-- ουρεα τε σχιοεντα

chap.p: The cavities which he ob∫erved, and which are ∫een only from their being the deep rece∫∫es of ∫hade, together with the rocks, and little projections, which are vi∫ible only from catching a ∫tronger ray of light, contribute to produce the partial effect -- that richne∫s, and variety on the ∫ides of di∫tant mountains, which would otherwi∫e be a di∫play of flat, fatiguing ∫urface. The objects them∫elves are formle∫s, and indi∫tinct; yet, by pre∫enting different ∫urfaces for the light to reflect on, the rich and variegated effect, here mentioned, is produced.

The grand ma∫∫es are formed by one mountain's over-∫hadowing another -- by the ∫un's turning round ∫ome promontory -- or by the tran∫ver∫e po∫ition of mountains; in all which ca∫es the ∫hadow falls broad and deep -- ∫weeps over all the ∫maller ∫hades, to which it ∫till,
gives a deeper tinge; and unites the whole in one great effect.

It is an agreeable amu∫ement to attend the∫e va∫t ∫hadows in their ∫low, and ∫olemn march over the mountains -- to ob∫erve, how the morning ∫un ∫heds only a faint catching light upon the ∫ummits of the hills, through one general ma∫s of hazy ∫hade -- in a few hours how all this confu∫ion is di∫∫ipated -- how the lights and ∫hades begin to break, and ∫eparate, and take their form and breadth -- how deep and determined the ∫hadows are at noon -- how fugitive and uncertain, as the ∫un declines; till it's fires, glowing in the we∫t, light up a new radiance through the land∫cape; and ∫pread over it, in∫tead of ∫ober light and ∫hade, all the colours of nature, in one bright, momentary gleam.

It is equally amu∫ing to ob∫erve the various ∫hapes, which mountains a∫∫ume through all this variety of illumination; rocks, knolls, and promontories, taking new forms; appearing, and di∫appearing, as the ∫un veers round;
who∫e radiance, like varni∫h on a picture, (if I may u∫e a degrading compari∫on,) brings out a thou∫and objects unob∫erved before.

To the∫e more permanent effects of illumination may be added another ∫pecies, which ari∫es from accident -- I mean tho∫e partial, flitting ∫hades, which are occa∫ioned by floating clouds. The∫e may ∫ometimes produce a good effect; but they contribute as often to di∫turb the repo∫e of a land∫cape. To painters however they are of great u∫e, who are frequently obliged, by an untoward ∫ubject, to take the advantage of every probability to produce an effect.

chap.title: Volume 1, Section VII.
chap.head: SECT. VII.
chap.p: HAVING thus con∫idered the chief circum∫tances, which occur in di∫tant mountains, let us now inlarge our view, and take in the lake, which makes the next con∫iderable part of this romantic country.
The fen, the pool, and the lake would pre∫ent very different ideas, tho magnitude were out of the que∫tion.
The fe is a pla∫hy inundation, formed on a flat -- without depth -- without lineal boundary -- of ambiguous texture -- half water -- and half land -- a ∫ort of vegetable fluid.

The pool is a collection of the ∫oakings of ∫ome common; or the re∫ervoir of the neighbouring ditches, which depo∫it in it's ouzy bed
the ∫oid of the country, clay, or mud; and give a corre∫pondent tinge to the water.

In ∫ome things the fen and the pool agree. They both take every thing in, and let nothing out. Each of them is in ∫ummer a ∫ink of putrefaction; and the receptacle of all tho∫e unclean, mis∫hapen forms in animal life, which breed and batten in the impurities of ∫tagnation;

poem.line: Where putrefaction into life ferments,
And breathes de∫tructive myriads.

chap.p: Very different is the origin of the lake. It's magnificent, and marble bed, formed in the caverns and deep rece∫∫es of rocky mountains, received originally the pure pellucide waters of ∫ome ru∫hing torrent, as it came fir∫t from the hand of nature -- arre∫ted it's cour∫e, till the ∫pacious, and ∫plendid ba∫on was filled brimfull; and then di∫charged the ∫tream, un∫ullied, and undimini∫hed, through ∫ome winding vale, to form other lakes, or increa∫e the dignity of ∫ome imperial river. Here no impurities find entrance, either of animal, or of vegetable life:

poem.line: --Non illic canna palu∫tris,
Nec ∫teriles ulvæ, nec acuta cu∫pide junci.

gap.desc: landscape oval sketch of lake scene

chap.p: From the bri∫k circulation of fluid through the∫e animated bodies of water, a great ma∫ter of nature has nobly ∫tyled them, living lakes:

poem.line: -- Speluncæ
Vivique lacus.--

chap.p: and indeed nothing, which is not really alive, de∫erves the appellation better. For be∫ides the vital ∫tream, which principally feeds them, they receive a thou∫and little gurgling rills, which trickling through a thou∫and veins, give life, and ∫pirit to every part.
The principal incidents ob∫ervable in lakes, are, their line of boundary -- their i∫lands -- and the different appearances of the ∫urface of the water.

The line of boundary is very various. Sometimes it is boldly broken by a projecting promontory -- ∫ometimes indented by a creek -- ∫ometimes it undulates by an irregular ∫hore -- and ∫ometimes ∫wells into a winding bay. In each of the∫e circum∫tances it is ∫u∫ceptible of beauty; in all, it certainly de∫erves attention: for as it is of cour∫e ∫o con∫picuous a boundary, that the lea∫t har∫hne∫s in it is di∫cernible. I
have known many a good land∫cape injured by a bad water boundary.

This line, it may be further ob∫erved, varies under different circum∫tances. When the eye is placed upon the lake, the line of boundary is a circular thread, with little undulation; unle∫s when ∫ome promontory of more than u∫ual magnitude ∫hoots into the water. All ∫maller irregularities are lo∫t. The particular beauty of it under this circum∫tance, con∫i∫ts in the oppo∫ition between ∫uch a thread, and the irregular line formed by the ∫ummits of the mountains.

But when the eye is placed on the higher grounds, above the level of the lake, the line of boundary takes a new form; and what appeared to the levelled eye a circular thread, becomes now an undulating line, projecting, and retiring more or le∫s, according to the degree of the eye's elevation. The circular thread was indebted for it's principal beauty to contra∫t: but this, like all other elegant lines, has the additional beauty of variety.

And yet, in ∫ome ca∫es, the levelled eye has the advantage of the elevated one. The line, which forms an acute angle from the higher ∫ituation,
may be ∫oftened, when ∫een from the water, into an ea∫y curve.
The i∫lands fall next under our view. The∫e are either beauty, or a deformity to the lake; as they are ∫haped, or ∫tationed.

If the i∫land be round, or of any other regular form; or if the wood upon it be thick and heavy (as I have ob∫erved ∫ome planted with a clo∫e grove of Scotch fir) it can never be an object of beauty. At hand, it is a heavy lump: at a di∫tance, a murky ∫pot.

Again, if the i∫land, (however beautifully ∫haped, or planted;) be ∫eated in the centre of a round lake; in the focus of an oval one; or in any other regular po∫ition; the beauty of it is lo∫t, at lea∫t in ∫ome points of view.

But when it's lines, and ∫hape are both irregular -- when it is ornamented with ancient oak, rich in foliage, but light and airy -- and when it takes ∫ome irregular ∫ituation in the lake; then it is an object truly beautiful -- beautiful in it∫elf, as well as in compo∫ition. It mu∫t however be added, that it would be difficult to place ∫uch an object in any ∫ituation, that would be equally plea∫ing to every ∫tand.
The ∫urface of the lake offers it∫elf la∫t to ob∫ervation. The ∫everal incidents, which ari∫e here, are all owing to the ∫ky, and the di∫po∫ition of the water to receive it's impre∫∫ion.
That the ∫ky is the great regulator of the colour of the water, is known to all arti∫ts.

poem.line: Olli cæruleus ∫upra caput a∫titit imber,
Noctem hyememque ferens: et inhorruit unda tenebris.

chap.p: And again

poem.line: Jamque rube∫cebat radiis mare, et athere ab alto
Aurora in ro∫eis fulgebat lutea bigis.

chap.p: The effect indeed holds univer∫allyy; as water in all ca∫es, expo∫ed to the ∫ky, will act as a mirror to it.
In the darkne∫s of a brooding ∫torm, we have ju∫t ∫een, the whole body of the water will be dark: inhorruit unda tenebris.

In clear, and windy weather, the breezy ruffled lake, as Thom∫on calls it, is a ∫hattered mirror: It reflects the ∫erenity; but reflects it partially. The hollow of each wave is commonly in ∫hadow, the ∫ummit is tipped with light. The light or ∫hadow therefore prevails, according to the po∫ition of the waves to the
eye: and at a di∫tance, when the ∫ummits of the waves, agreeably to the rules of per∫pective, appear in contact, the whole ∫urface in that part will be light.

But when the ∫ky is ∫plendid, and at the ∫ame times calm, the water (being then a perfect mirror,) will glow all over with corre∫pondent tints; unle∫s other reflections, from the objects around, intervene, and form more vivid pictures.
Often you will ∫ee a ∫pacious bay, ∫creened by ∫ome projecting promontory, in perfect repo∫e; while the re∫t of the lake, more pervious to the air, is cri∫ped over by a gentle ripple.

Sometimes al∫o, when the whole lake is tranquil, a gentle perturbation will ari∫e in ∫ome di∫tant part, from no apparent cau∫e, from a breath of air, which nothing el∫e can feel, and creeping ∫oftly on, communicate the tremulous ∫hudder with exqui∫ite ∫en∫ibility over half the ∫urface. In this ob∫ervation I do little more than tran∫late from Ovid:

poem.line: --Exhorruit, æquoris in∫tar,
Quod fremit, exigua cum ∫ummum ∫tringitur aura.

chap.p:
No pool, no river-bay, can pre∫ent this idea in it's utmo∫t purity. In them every cry∫talline particle is ∫et, as it were, in a ∫ocket of mud.
Their lubricity is lo∫t. More or le∫s, they all flow cum gurgite flavo. But the lake, like Spencer's fountain, which ∫prang from the limpid tears of a nymph,

poem.line: --is cha∫t, and pure, as pure∫t ∫now,
Ne lets her waves with any filth be dyed.

chap.p: Refined thus from every ob∫truction, it is tremblingly alive all over: the mere∫t trifle, a fri∫king fly, a falling leaf, almo∫t a ∫ound alarms it,

poem.line: --that ∫ound,
Which from the mountain, previous to the ∫torm,
Rolls o'er the muttering earth, di∫turbs the flood,
And ∫hakes the fore∫t-leaf without a breath.

chap.p: This tremulous ∫hudder is ∫ometimes even ∫till more partial: It will run in lengthened parallels, and ∫eparate the reflections upon the ∫urface, which are lo∫t on one ∫ide, and taken up on the other. This is perhaps the mo∫t picture∫que form, which water a∫∫umes; as it affords the painter an opportunity of throwing in tho∫e lengthened lights and ∫hades, which give the greatest variety and clearne∫s to water.

There is another appearance on the ∫urfaces of lakes, which we cannot account for on any principle either of optics, or of per∫pective.
When there is no apparent cau∫e in the ∫ky, the water will ∫ometimes appear dappled with large ∫pots of ∫hade. It is po∫∫ible the∫e patches may have connection with the bottom of the lake; as naturali∫ts ∫uppo∫e, the ∫hining parts of the ∫ea are occa∫ioned by the ∫pawn of fi∫h: but it is more probable, that in ∫ome way, they are connected with the ∫ky, as they generally e∫teemed in the country to be a weather-gage. The people will often ∫ay, "It will be no " hay-day to day, the lake is full of ∫hades." -- I never my∫elf ∫aw this appearance; o I might be able to give a better account of it: but I have heard it ∫o often taken notice of; that I ∫uppo∫e there is at lea∫t ∫ome ground for the ob∫ervation. Tho, after all, I think it probably the∫e ∫hades may be owing only to floating clouds.

From this great variety, which the ∫urfaces of lakes a∫∫ume, we may draw this conclu∫ion, that the painter may take great liberties, in point of light and ∫hade, in his repre∫entation of water. It is, in many ca∫es, under no rule, that we are acquainted with; or under rules ∫o
lax, that the imagination is left very much at large.

On the ∫ubject of lakes, I have only farther to add, that many bodies of water, under this denomination, are found upon the ∫ummits of lofty mountains. In this ∫ituation they are commonly made ba∫ons; or re∫ervoirs; and want the plea∫ing accompaniments, which adorn the lower lakes. Lakes of this kind are a collection of ∫prings; and di∫charge them∫elves generally from their elevated ∫tations in ca∫cades.

chap.title: Volume 1, Section VIII.
chap.head: SECT. VIII.
chap.p: WE have now made a con∫iderable advance towards a land∫cape. The ∫ky is laid in; a mountain fills the offskip; and a lake, with it's accompaniments, takes po∫∫e∫∫ion of a nearer di∫tance. Nothing but a fore-ground is wanting; and for this we have great choice of objects -- broken ground -- trees -- rocks -- ca∫cades -- and vallies.

In a di∫tance the ruling character is tenderne∫s; which on a fore-ground, gives way to what the painter calls force, and richness. Force ari∫es from a violent oppo∫ition of colour, light, and ∫hade: richne∫s con∫i∫ts in a variety of parts, and glowing tints. In ∫ome degree, richne∫s is found in a di∫tance; but never, united with force: for in a distance; tho the lights may be ∫trong, and the parts varied; yet
the ∫hades and tints will ever be faint, and tender.
In the mean time, this oppo∫ition on the fore-ground, violent as it is, mu∫t always be subject to the ruling ma∫∫es of light and ∫hade, and colouring, which harmonize the whole.
The effect of this harmony is breadth, or repo∫e. It's oppo∫ite is flutter, and confu∫ion.

It appears therefore, that the management of fore-grounds is a matter of great nicety. In them a very contradiction mu∫t be reconciled: breadth and repo∫e, which con∫i∫t in uniting the parts; mu∫t be made to agree with force and richne∫s, which con∫i∫t in violently breaking them. And what adds to the difficulty, the eye, brought thus on the ∫pot, is hurt by the minute∫t defect. Whereas, at a di∫tance, an irregular da∫h of the pencil, if it be not one thing, may be conceived to be another: ob∫curity is there a ∫ource of beauty. -- Hence it is, that many great ma∫ters, who can throw a di∫tance into a plea∫ing confu∫ion, and give it the effect of nature; have failed in exerci∫ing their art on a fore-ground.
Having premi∫ed thus much with regard to fore-grounds in general, let us now examine the fore-grounds, which are pre∫ented to us in this very picture∫que country.

Broken grounds are the fir∫t objects of our attention. Here they abound in every ∫hape. The painter will ea∫ily find, either ∫ome rough knoll, who∫e parts are ample -- the ∫loping corner of a hill, perhaps worn by a mountain-torrent -- a rugged road, winding through the cha∫m of a rifted promontory -- or ∫ome other part of nature equally grand and picture∫que.

If he chu∫e to adorn his fore-ground with wood (and who does not?) he will find it in ∫ome parts of this country in a tolerable ∫tyle of greatne∫s. But, in general, the old timber is decayed or cut down; and that ∫ort of wood incouraged, which is the mo∫t profitable -- ∫uch wood, as, in a cour∫e of time, is turned into charcoal. It has, in ∫ome degree, the effect of better trees in a di∫tance; but it is very deficient, when we call for an ancient oak to give the fore-
ground a grandeur equal to the ∫cene -- when we want the magnificence of it's ∫hadowing form to mantle over the vacant corner of a land∫cape -- when we wi∫h it to hid ∫ome heavy promontory; or to ∫catter a few loo∫e branches over ∫ome ill-∫haped mountain-line -- when it's ma∫∫y foliage is nece∫∫ary to give depth to ∫hade -- it's twi∫ted bole, covered with grey mo∫s, to oppo∫e the vivid green in it's neighbourhood -- or, la∫tly, it's warm autumnal tint to contra∫t the colder hues of di∫tance. In all the∫e ca∫es a deficiency of fore∫t-wood is ∫ometimes regretted in the ∫cenery before us; but not often: and where it is, the lo∫s is ea∫ily ∫upplied by other objects; among which rocks are the principal: and the∫e, when ornamented with wood, tho of a ∫maller ∫ize, have generally the effect of the mo∫t luxuriant foliage.
Rocks differ in ∫urface; general form; and colour.

The rock naturally wears that ∫mooth weather-beaten ∫urface, which time gives it through a ∫ucce∫∫ion of ages. But rocks, firm as they are, are ∫ubject to change. Springs undermine them: torrents wa∫h the earth from around
them: fro∫ts loo∫en them; and ∫ometimes they are torn by ∫torms and earthquakes. Under the∫e circum∫tances, when large ma∫∫es fall away, the rock exhibits a fractured ∫urface; which in general has a better effect, than the ∫mooth one. Nature, in the∫e in∫tances, may be ∫aid to retouch her compo∫itions: the fractured parts are larger and ∫harper; and better adapted to receive either ∫mart, catching light; or a body of light and ∫hade. -- An humble imitation of the ∫urfaces of fractured rocks is ∫ometimes exhibited in large coals: they may at lea∫t a∫∫i∫t the imagination of the painter.

With regard to the general form of rocks, both ∫pecies, the ∫mooth, and the fractured, have equal variety. Both have their bold projections -- both hang alike over their ba∫es -- are rifted into cha∫ms -- and ∫hoot ∫ometimes into horizontal, and ∫ometimes into diagonal ∫trata.

The natural colour of rocks is either grey, or red. We have of each kind in England; and both are beautiful: but the grey rock, (which is the common ∫pecies in this ∫cenery) makes the finer contra∫t with the foliage either of ∫ummer, or of autumn.

I call red, and grey the natural colours of rocks; but more properly they are the ground only of a variety of tints. The∫e tints ari∫e from weeds, mo∫∫es, and lychens of various kinds, which uniting together on the ∫urface of a rock, often make a rich, and very harmomonious a∫∫emblage of colouring; and the painter, who does not attend to the∫e minutiæ (we are con∫idering fore-grounds) lo∫es half the beauty of the original.

Among the∫e lychens, the white ∫pecies is the lea∫t plea∫ing. When mixed with other tints, it may form an agreeable contra∫t: and even, when it borrows no aid of this kind, if it be ∫paringly, and happily introduced, it may add a beauty to the natural colour of the grey rock, by giving it the brilliancy of a few ∫harp touches. But when it prevails; and ∫preads, like a bald leprous ∫cab, over a whole ∫urface; it's mealy hue is very di∫gu∫ting, unle∫s it be thrown into ∫hadow, or ∫upported by ∫ome ma∫s of foliage, or other vivid tint in contact with it.

Be∫ides the ∫pecies of rocks ju∫t de∫cribed, there is another, called the cragg; which conveys the idea of a rock roughly pounded. With the∫e ∫hattered fragments whole ∫ides of
mountains are often covered; down which they appear continually to ∫hiver. This ∫pecies is very inferior to former. It wants that breadth of ∫urface, which gives dignity to an object. In a di∫tance indeed, which melts the fragments into one ma∫s, the effect is good: but in the ∫ituation, in which we are now con∫idering rocks, as the appendages of a fore-ground, the cragg is meanly circum∫tanced.
The ca∫cade, which is the next object of our ob∫ervation, may be divided into the broken, and the regular fall.

The fir∫t belongs mo∫t properly to the rock; who∫e projecting fragments, impeding the water, break it into pieces -- da∫h it into foam -- and give it all the ∫pirit, and agitation, which that active element is capable of receiving. -- Happy is the pencil, which can ∫eize the varieties, and brilliancy of water under this circum∫tance.
In the regular fall the water meets no ob∫truction; but pours down, from the higher grounds to the lower, in one ∫plendid ∫heet.

Each kind hath it's beauties; but, in general, the broken fall is more adapted to a ∫mall
body of water; and the regular to a large one. The ∫mall body of water has nothing to recommend it, but it's variety and bu∫tle: where-as the large body has a dignity of character to maintain. To fritter it in pieces would be to de∫troy in a degree the grandeur of it's effect. Were the Niagara thus broken, at lea∫t if ∫ome con∫iderable parts of it were not left broad and ∫heety, it might be a grand ∫cene of confu∫ion; but it could not be that va∫t, that uniform, and ∫imple object, which is mo∫t capable of expre∫∫ing the idea of greatne∫s.

As there a few con∫iderable rivers in the romantic country, we are now examining, the mo∫t beautiful ca∫cades, (which are innumerable) are generally of the broken kind. The regular falls (of which al∫o there are many) are objects of little value. Tho they are ∫ometimes four of five hundred feet in height; yet they appear only like threads of ∫ilver at a di∫tance; and like mere ∫pouts at hand; void both of grandeur, and variety. -- And yet, in heavy rains, ∫ome of them mu∫t be very noble, if we may judge from their channels, which often ∫hew great marks of violence. -- But I was never fortunate enough to ∫ee any of them in the∫e moment of wildne∫s.

The∫e two kinds of ca∫cades, the broken, and the regular, may be combined. If the weight of water be ∫mall, it is true, it will admit only the broken fall: but if it be large, it may with propriety admit a combination of both: and the∫e combinations may be multiplied into each other with endle∫s variety.

The regular fall admits al∫o another mode of variety by forming it∫elf into what may be called the ∫ucce∫∫ive fall; in which the water, in∫tead of making one continued ∫hoot, falls through a ∫ucce∫∫ion of different ∫tories. Of this kind are many of the mountain-ca∫cades in this country, which are often very beautiful; e∫pecially where the ∫tages are deranged; and the water ∫eeks it's way from one ∫tage to another.

This is the ∫pecies of ca∫cade, which was the great object of imitation in all the antiquated water-works of the la∫t age. Our fore-fathers admired the ∫ucce∫∫ive fall; and, agreeably to their awkward mode of imitation, made the water de∫cend a regular flight of ∫tone-∫tairs.

Before we conclude the ∫ubject of ca∫cades, it may be ob∫erved, that, as in other objects of beauty, ∫o in this, proportion mu∫t be a
regulating principle. I ∫hall not be ∫o preci∫e as to ∫ay, what is the exact proportion of an elegant ca∫cade. Nor is it nece∫∫ary. The eye will ea∫ily ∫ee the enormity of disproportion, where it exi∫ts in any great degree: and that is enough. Thus when a mountain-ca∫cade falls four or five hundred feet, and is perhaps ∫carce two yards broad; every eye mu∫t ∫ee the di∫proportion: as it will al∫o, when the whole breadth of ∫ome large river falls only two or three feet. Both would be more beautiful, if their falls held a nearer proportion to their quantities of water.

The la∫t ∫pecies of fore-grounds are vallies; with regard to which it mu∫t be remarked fir∫t, that narrow contracted vallies only are meant. The open valley mu∫t cla∫s it∫elf among objects of di∫tant ∫cenery.
chap.note: Let it be ob∫erved, that the terms vale, and valley; denote univer∫ally, through this work, the greater, and ∫maller ∫cenes of the ∫ame kind. I con∫ider valley as the diminutive of vale.
chap.p:
It mu∫t ∫econdly be remarked, that even contracted valleys are not purely of the nature of
fore-grounds, but participate of di∫tance. One ∫ide-∫creen mu∫t nece∫∫arily be a little removed, if you would give your ∫cenery the advantage of per∫pective.
The∫e things being premi∫ed, we may con∫ider the valley as a ∫pecies of fore-ground; the ingredients of which Spencer hath given us in very few words.

poem.line: Through woods, and mountains wild they came at la∫t
Into a plea∫ant dale, that lowly lay
Betwixt two hills, who∫e high heads over placed,
The valley did with cool ∫hade overca∫t:
Through mid∫t thereof a little river rolled.

chap.p: The∫e ingredients admit great variety in compo∫ition. The ∫ides of the valley may be high, or low; rocky, or woody; ∫mooth, or full of jutting promontories: and the∫e variations again may play into each other with a thou∫and interchanges.

When we find a concurrence of beautiful circum∫tances in the∫e ∫cenes -- when their ∫ides are well proportioned, and picture∫quely adorned -- and e∫pecially when they are ∫o fortunate as to open on a rich di∫tance; a lake bounded by a rocky mountain; or any other intere∫ting object, they form a land∫cape of a very plea∫ing kind.

The rivers al∫o with which the∫e vallies ∫carce ever fail of being adorned, have the ∫ame variety as the hills; and may, now and then, be introduced very happily to a∫∫i∫t the fore-ground. They are pure chry∫talline ∫treams -- generally ∫parkling over beds of pebbles -- often tumbling, and foaming over the ledges of rocks -- and forming, through the whole of their cour∫e, a continuation of little bu∫tling ca∫cades.

Nearly allied to the contracted valley, is, what in this country, is called a gill; in others, a dell. It is a narrow cleft, winding between two rocky precipices; and overgrown with wood, which clo∫es at the top, and almo∫t excludes the day. Through the bottom foams a torrent. You hear it ∫ounding in it's fall from one rocky ∫tage to another: but it is rarely vi∫ible.

The∫e romantic ∫pots are generally impervious. When they are a little more open, ∫o as to allow a narrow foot-path to ∫tray among them, they are the mo∫t beloved haunts of ∫olitude and meditation; and of all the parts
of this delightful ∫cenery, afford the mo∫t refre∫hing refuge from noon-tide heat.
Such were the ∫cenes the poet panted after, when they drew from his ∫oul, oppre∫∫ed by the languor of a ∫ummer-∫un, that ardent a∫piration;

poem.line: -- O quis me gelidis in vallibus Hæmi
Si∫tat, et ingenti ramorum protegat umbrâ!

chap.p: How intimately acquainted with the∫e ∫cenes he was, his own very accurate de∫riptions ∫hew.

poem.line: -- Den∫is hunc frondibus atrum
Urget utrimque latus nemoris, medioque fragosus
Dat ∫onitum ∫axis, et torto vertice torrens.

chap.p: Dat ∫onitum, ∫ays this accurate ob∫erver of nature; remarking in the expre∫∫ion, that the torrent was an addre∫s to the ear, not to the eye.

The contracted valley, we have ∫een, may open to a di∫tance; but a view into the gill furni∫hes only a fore-ground. It can only con∫i∫t of ∫ome little ∫eque∫tered rece∫s -- a few twi∫ted boles -- a ca∫cade ∫parkling through the trees -- or a tran∫lucent pool, formed in the cavity beneath ∫ome rock, and ju∫t large enough to reflect the hanging wood, which over ∫ha
dows it. And yet even on this contracted ∫cale, we have many a beautiful land∫cape:

poem.line: -- For nature here
Has, with her living colours, formed a ∫cene
Which Rui∫dael be∫t might rival: cry∫tal lakes,
O'er which the giant-oak, him∫elf a grove,
Flings his romantic branches, and beholds
His reverend image in th' expan∫e below.
If di∫tant hills be wanting, yet our eye
Forgets the want, and with delighted gaze
Re∫ts on the lovely fore-ground --

chap.title: Volume 1, Section IX.
chap.head: SECT. IX.
chap.p: WE have now examined the materials, of which the magnificent ∫cenery of this country is compo∫ed -- the di∫tant mountain -- the lake -- and the fore-ground: but a few general ob∫ervations on the∫e materials, as united in compo∫ition, may perhaps throw ∫ome new and picture∫que lights on the whole.

In many countries much grander ∫cenes are exhibited, than the∫e, -- mountains more magnificent, and lakes more exten∫ive: yet, it is probable there are few, in which the ∫everal objects are better proportioned; and united with more beauty.
In America the lakes are ∫eas; and the country on their banks, being removed of cour∫e to a great di∫tance, can add no accompaniments.

Among the ∫maller lakes of Italy and Switzerland, no doubt, there are many delightful ∫cenes: but the larger lakes, like tho∫e of America, are di∫proportioned to their accompaniments: the water occupies too large a ∫pace, and throws the ∫cenery too much in di∫tance.

The mountains of Sweden, Norway, and other northern regions, are probably rather ma∫∫es of hideous rudene∫s, than ∫cenes of grandeur and proportion. Proportion indeed in all ∫cenery is indi∫pen∫ably nece∫∫ary; and unle∫s the lake, and it's corre∫pondent mountains have this ju∫t relation to each other, they want the fir∫t principle of beauty.

The value of lake-∫cenery ari∫es rather from the idea of magnificence, than of variety. The ∫cene is not continually ∫hifting here, as on the banks of a winding river. The lake is ∫o va∫t, that it ∫tands ∫till, as it were, before the moving eye. Nor is this attended with ∫atiety. A quick ∫ucce∫∫ion of imagery is nece∫∫ary in ∫cenes of le∫s grandeur, where little beauties are ea∫ily ∫canned: but ∫cenes, like the∫e, demand contemplation. The∫e rich volumes of
nature, like the works of e∫tabli∫hed authors, will bear a frequent peru∫al. Contemplation adds to their value.

In the mean time, with all this magnificence and beauty, it cannot be ∫uppo∫ed, that every ∫cene, which the∫e countries pre∫ent, is correctly picture∫que. In ∫uch immen∫e bodies of rough-hewn matter, many irregularities, and even many deformities, mu∫t exi∫t, which a practi∫ed eye would wi∫h to correct. Mountains are ∫ometimes crouded -- their ∫ides are often bare, when contra∫t requires them to be wooded -- promontories form the water-boundary into acute angles -- and bays are contracted into narrow points, in∫tead of ∫welling into ample ba∫ons.

In all the∫e ca∫es the imagination is apt to whi∫per, What glorious ∫cenes might here be made, if the∫e ∫tubborn materials could yield to the judicious hand of art! -- And, to ∫ay the truth, we are ∫ometimes tempted to let the imagination loo∫e among them.

By the force of this creative power an intervening hill may be turned a∫ide; and a di∫tance introduced. -- This ill-∫haped moun-
tain may be pared, and formed into a better line. -- To that, on the oppo∫ite ∫ide, a lightne∫s may be given by the addition of a higher ∫ummit. -- Upon you bald declivity, which ∫tretches along the lake, may be reared a fore∫t of noble oak; which thinly ∫catter'd over the top, will thicken as it de∫cends; and throw it's vivid reflections on the water in full luxuriance.
The line of the water too, which perhaps is ∫traight, the imagination will ea∫ily correct. It will bring forward ∫ome bold promontory; or open ∫ome winding bay.

It will proceed even to the ornaments of art. On ∫ome projecting knoll it will rear the maje∫ty of a ruined ca∫tle, who∫e ivyed walls ∫eem a part of the very rock, on which they ∫tand. On a gentle ri∫e, opening to the lake, and half incircled by wood hills, ∫ome mouldring abbey may be ∫eated; and far beyond may appear di∫tant objects, under ∫ome circum∫tance of picture∫que illumination:

poem.line: The fore∫t darkening round, and glittering ∫pire.

chap.p:
Thus the imagination will a∫∫i∫t tho∫e ∫cenes, which, tho replete with beauties beyond it's power to create, may contain deformities,
which it might wi∫h to remove. It corrects one part of nature by another; and compo∫es a land∫cape, as the arti∫t compo∫ed his celebrated Venus, by ∫electing accordant beauties from different originals. Scarce any ∫ingle archetype is ∫ufficiently correct. Any other idea of improving nature is ab∫urd; and can be adopted only by men of fal∫e ta∫te, who imagine they improve her by an addition of heterogeneous decorations.

As to the improvement of ∫uch va∫t ∫cenes as the∫e, it is in every ∫hape, except by a little planting, beyond all power of art. I cannot therefore be under∫tood to ∫ugge∫t improvement here. All we get by imagining, how ∫uch a country as this might be improved, is merely a little practice in the rules of picture∫que compo∫ition.

We may remark further, that the power which the imagination hath over the∫e ∫cenes, is not greater, than the power, which they have over the imagination. No tame country, however beautiful, however adorned, can di∫tend the mind, like this awful, and maje∫tic ∫cenery. The wild ∫allies of untutored genius
often ∫trike the imagination more, than the mo∫t correct effu∫ions of cultivated parts. Tho the eye therefore might take more plea∫ure in a view (con∫idered merely in a picture∫que light) when a little adorned by the hand of art; yet I much doubt, whether ∫uch a view would have that ∫trong effect on the imagination; as when rough with all it's bold irregularities about it; when beauty, and deformity, grandeur and horror, mingled together, ∫trike the mind with a thou∫and oppo∫ing ideas; and like chymical infu∫ions of an oppo∫ite nature, produce an efferve∫cence, which no harmonious mixtures could produce.

poem.line: Surely there is a hidden power, that reigns
'Mid the lone maje∫ty of untamed nature,
Controuling ∫ober rea∫on--

chap.p: Were a lover of nature placed abruptly in the mid∫t of ∫uch ∫cenes as the∫e, the effect might be too ∫trong: and this in∫tance, as in others, he might di∫cover the weakne∫s of his fir∫t progenitor; in whom, on viewing ∫uddenly a grand land∫cape, we are told,

poem.line: So deep the power of tho∫e ingredients pierced,
Ev'n to the inmo∫t ∫eat of mortal ∫ight
That Adam now inforced to clo∫e his eyes,
Sank down, and all his ∫pirits became intranced.

chap.p: But nature, which brings out the ∫un through the medium of twilight, hath in this ca∫e al∫o provided for the weakne∫s of the vi∫ual nerve. The∫e grand ∫cenes are gradually introduced. The idea grows imperceptibly to maturity. The great ∫tones of ye∫terday become rocks to-day. Hills, in a few ∫tages, are converted into mountains; and we ∫ee, now and then, the glimp∫e of a lake; before the eye is filled with the whole va∫t, ∫plendid ∫urface of it.

If the imagination be thus fired by the∫e romantic ∫cenes even in their common ∫tate, how much more may we ∫uppo∫e it wrought on, when they ∫trike us under ∫ome extraordinary circum∫tance of beauty, or terror -- in the tranquility of a calm, or the agitation of a ∫torm?

Some ∫cenes, particularly of the ∫ylvan kind, are perhaps be∫t ∫uited to a calm. They receive their principal beauty from the richne∫s of the objects; which is improved by chearful and ∫plendid lights.

Other ∫cenes, le∫s inriched by objects, are meagre in a calm, and glaring ∫un∫hine. A
bright hemi∫phere only renders their poverty more apparent. To ∫uch ∫cenes a ∫torm, which produces ∫ublime ideas by heaving clouds, and bur∫ting lights, gives an adventitious con∫equence, and leads the eye, in it's pur∫uit of objects, to the grandeur of the effect.
But there are ∫ome ∫cenes in nature, which are adapted to both circum∫tances -- none more, than the ∫cenery of lakes -- none perhaps ∫o much.

During five days, which we ∫pent among the lakes, we ∫aw one of them only, and that but once, under the circum∫tance of a perfect calm -- when there was neither wind to ruffle, nor cloud to ob∫cure, the re∫plendency of the ∫urface -- when we ∫aw the poet's de∫cription literally tran∫lated --

poem.line: -- Silet arduus æther:
Tum zephyri po∫uere: premit placida æquora pontus.

chap.p:
If an artificial mirror, a few inches long, placed oppo∫ite to a door, or a window, occa∫ions often very plea∫ing reflections; how noble mu∫t be the appearance, when an area of many leagues in circumference, is formed into one va∫t mirror; and this mirror ∫urrounded by a combination of great, and beautiful objects? The maje∫tic repo∫e of ∫o grand, ∫o ∫olemn,
and ∫plendid a ∫cene rai∫es in the mind a ∫ort of enthu∫ia∫tic calm, which ∫preads a mild complacence over the brea∫t -- a tranquil pau∫e of mental operation, which may be felt, but not de∫ribed;

poem.line: -- ∫pread,
Into a liquid plain, it ∫tands unmoved,
Pure as th' expan∫e of heaven --
And to the fringed bank, with o∫iers crowned,
It's cry∫tal mirror holds --

chap.p:
Other adventitious circum∫tances, of le∫s value in them∫elves, but in union very picture∫que, add new life, and beauty to ∫o ∫till a ∫cene -- groups of cattle in various parts, driven by the heats of noon, along the ∫hores of the
lake -- and fi∫hing-boats extending their nets in dotted circles, and forming tremulous reflections from their flaccid ∫ails.

When we take a view of ∫uch a glorious ∫cene in all it's ∫plendor, we regret, that it ∫hould ever be deformed by the rough bla∫ts of tempe∫t: and yet I know not, whether, under this latter circum∫tance, it may not have a ∫till greater power over the imagination. Every little idea is lo∫t in the wild uproar and confu∫ion of ∫uch a ∫cene.

Nor is it in this di∫turbed ∫tate, le∫s an object of picture∫que beauty. The ∫ky floating with broken clouds -- the mountains half ob∫cured by driving vapours; and mingling with the ∫ky in awful ob∫curity -- the trees ∫training in the bla∫t -- and the lake ∫tirred from the bottom, and whitening every rocky promontory with it's foam; are all objects highly adapted to the pencil.

In the mid∫t of the tempe∫t, if a bright ∫unbeam ∫hould ∫uddenly break out; and in Shake∫pear's language, light up the ∫torm, the ∫cenery of an agitated lake, thus a∫∫i∫ted by the powers of contra∫t, affects both the imagination, and
the eye, in a ∫till greater degree. Some broad mountain-∫ide, catching a ma∫s of light, produces an a∫toni∫hing effect amid∫t the leaden gloom, which ∫urrounds it. Perhaps a ∫unbeam, half-∫uffu∫ed in vapour, darting between two mountains, may ∫tretch along the water in a lengthened gleam, ju∫t as the ∫kiff pa∫∫es to receive the light upon it's ∫welling ∫ail: while the ∫ea-gull, wheeling along the ∫torm, turns it's ∫ilvery ∫ide, ∫trongly illumined, again∫t the bo∫om of ∫ome lurid cloud; and by that ∫ingle touch of oppo∫ition, gives double darkne∫s to the ri∫ing tempe∫t.

Compared with ∫uch ∫cenes, how inanimate do the ∫ubjects of Canaletti appear! -- how flat his ∫quare canals, and formal ∫treet-per∫pective; when oppo∫ed to ∫preading lakes, and ∫weeping mountains! -- the puny labours of men, to the bold, irregular ∫cenery of nature! Nor can we help regretting the lo∫s of ∫uch pictures as might have been produced, if Canaletti's free pencil had been thrown loo∫e in ∫uch a country as this.

But the∫e ∫cenes are not only ∫uperior to the ∫ubjects of Canaletti; but to tho∫e of a greater
ma∫ter, the younger Vanderveld. Sea-views, tho grander in ∫ome re∫pects, are, on the hole, inferior to the views before us. Their great deficiency is the want of a variety in their accompaniments. One ∫pecies of them indeed, and but one, is ∫uperior to the utmo∫t efforts of the lake -- the ∫egment of ∫ome land-locked bay; which, in a ∫torm e∫pecially, is a noble ∫ubject: the waters are more agitated, and form bolder ∫wells; which, of cour∫e, receive grander effects of light. Here too, in∫tead of the dancing ∫kiff, we are pre∫ented with the terrors of ∫hipwreck. The beacon al∫o, ∫eated on a bleak eminence, marks the coa∫t with peculiar danger; while the di∫tant port-town, di∫covered by a gleam of light under the ∫hadowing cliff, makes the ∫cene ∫till more affecting by the exclu∫ion of hope within ∫ight of ∫ecurity.

I have only farther to ob∫erve, in general, on the ∫cenes of this romantic country, that they are ∫ubject to violent convul∫ions of various kinds. Every thing, here, is in the grand ∫tyle. The very elements, when they do mi∫
chief, keep in uni∫on with it, and perform all their operations with an air of dignity.

Upon ∫ome of the mountains, particularly on Cro∫s-fell, a bla∫t, called in the country, a helm-wind, will ∫ometimes ari∫e ∫uddenly, of a nature ∫o violent, that nothing can with∫tand it's force. The experienced mountaineer, as he traver∫es tho∫e wild regions, fore∫eeing it's approach, throws him∫elf flat upon the ground; and lets it pa∫s over him. It's rage is momentary: and the air in∫tantly ∫ettles into it's former calm.

The∫e hurricanes are not uncommon in other mountainous countries. Mr. Misson particularly ∫peaking of the mountains near In∫pruck, tells us, that the winds often force their way through their hollow parts, as if through pipes, and rai∫e ∫uch furious hurricanes, as will ∫ometimes root up, not only trees; but even rocks.

The lake too is ∫ubject to ∫omething of the ∫ame kind of emotion; which the inhabitants of the country call a bottom-wind. Often,
when all is calm, and re∫plendent around; as the boat is plying it's ∫teady way; the boatman will de∫cry at a di∫tance (happy that it is ∫o) a violent ebullition of the water. He will ∫ee it heave and ∫well; forced upwards by ∫ome internal convul∫ion; and ∫uffering all the agitation of a ∫torm. But as ∫oon as the confined air has ∫pent it's force, the agitated ∫urface immediately ∫ub∫ides.
Of the∫e bottom-winds al∫o we meet with frequent accounts: particularly in ∫ome of the Sweedi∫h lakes, which are very ∫ubject to them.
Something of this kind, ∫eems to have given Spencer an idea, which he introduces in his idle lake:

poem.line: The waves come rolling, and the billows roar,
Outrageou∫ly as they engaged were:
But not one puff of wind there did appear.

chap.p: Often al∫o a va∫t body of water, collected in the entrails of a mountain, it is ∫aid, will force a way through it's ∫ide; and ru∫hing down the declivity, take it's cour∫e through the valley; where it is not uncommon to ∫ee the marks of it's deva∫tation.
The ∫ame effects are ∫ometimes produced by water-∫pouts, which in countries like the∫e, are collected, as at ∫ea, and fall upon mountains.
The avalanche, or fall of ∫now, is common here too, as in other mountainous countries. Inundations al∫o are occa∫ioned by it's ∫udden melting.

But the fall of cliffs, and large fragments of mountains, loo∫ened by rain, and fro∫t, produces one of the greate∫t ∫cenes of terror, which belongs to this romantic country; and to which we are chiefly indebted for that variety of fractured rock, and broken ground, which are among it's greate∫t ornaments. Virgil has given us a de∫cription of this kind in great perfection.

poem.line: Qualis in Euboico Baiarum litore quondam
Saxea pila cadit; --------------
Prona trahit, penitu∫que vadis illi∫a recumbit
Mi∫cent ∫e maria, & nigræ attolluntur arenæ
Tum ∫onitu Prochyta alta tremit, durumque cubile
Inarime, Jovis imperiis, impo∫ta Typhæo.

chap.p: The immediate effect is fir∫t de∫cribed

poem.line: Mi∫ent ∫e maria, & nigræ attolluntur arenæ

chap.p: After a ∫olemn pau∫e, the grand ecchoes, and di∫tant repetitions, lengthened out from the rocky ∫cenery around, are nobly introduced.

poem.line: Tum ∫onitu Prochyta alta tremit, durumque cubile
Inarime, Jovis imperiis, impo∫ta Typhæo.

chap.p: Having thus collected a few of tho∫e general ideas, with which the ∫cenery of this country abounds, we ∫hall now illu∫trate them in a tour through ∫ome of it's mo∫t romantic parts.

chap.title: Volume 1, Section X.
chap.head: SECT. X.
chap.p: AMBLESIDE is an ordinary village; but delightfully ∫eated. A cove of lofty mountains half incircles it on the north; and the lake of Wynander opens in front; near the ∫hores of which it ∫tands.

The ground between it and the mountains, which are at lea∫t two miles di∫tant, is various, broken, and woody. A mountain-torrent, about half a mile from the village, forms a grand ca∫cade; but it was ∫o overgrown with thickets, that we had no point of view to ∫ee it from, but the top; which is the mo∫t unpicture∫que we could have.

From this fall the ∫tream ru∫hes along a narrow valley, or gill, luxuriantly adorned with rock, and wood: and winding through it about a mile, emerges near the head of the lake, into which it enters. This gill was
∫o overgrown with wood, that it appeared almo∫t impervious: but if a path could be carried through it, and the whole a little opened, it might be made very beautiful. A ∫cene in it∫elf ∫o plea∫ing, with a noble ca∫cade at one end, and an exten∫ive lake at the other, could not fail, to ∫trike the imagination in the mo∫t forcible manner.

From Amble∫ide we ∫et out for Bowne∫s, to take a view of the lake. Part of the road we had traver∫ed, the day before, from Kendal; and were a ∫econd time amu∫ed by the woody land∫cape it afforded; and it's ∫udden, interrupted openings to the lake, before the whole bur∫t of that magnificent ∫cene was pre∫ented. -- From the higher grounds, above Bowne∫s, we had an elevated view of its whole extent.

Windermere, or Winander-water, as it is ∫ometimes called, extends from north to ∫outh, about twelve or fourteen miles. In breadth, it rarely exceeds two; and is ∫eldom narrower than one. The ∫outhern end winds a little towards the we∫t. The northern, and we∫tern coa∫ts are wild, and mountainous -- the ea∫tern, and ∫outhern are more depre∫∫ed; in
∫ome parts cultivated, in others woody. Oppo∫ite to Bowne∫s, the lake is divided into two parts by a clu∫ter of i∫lands; one of which is larger than the re∫t.

Bowne∫s is the capital port-town on the lake; if we may adopt a dignified ∫tyle, which the grandeur of the country naturally ∫ugge∫ts. It is the great mart for fi∫h, and charcoal; both which commodities are largely imported here; and carried by land into the country. It's harbour is crouded with ve∫∫els of various kinds; ∫ome of which are u∫ed merely as plea∫ure-boats in navigating the lake. -- In one of the∫e we embarked, and ∫tanding out to ∫ea; made for the great i∫land; which we were informed was a very intere∫ting ∫cene.
We ∫oon arrived at it; and landing at the ∫outh end, we ordered our boat to meet us at the north point; meaning to traver∫e it's little boundaries.

A more ∫eque∫tered ∫pot cannot ea∫ily be conceived. Nothing can be more excluded from the noi∫e, and interruption of life; or abound with a greater variety of tho∫e circum∫tances, which make retirement plea∫ing.

The whole i∫land contains about thirty acres. It's form is oblong: it's ∫hores irregular; retiring into bays, and broken into creeks.
The ∫urface too is uneven; and a ∫ort of little Appennine ridge runs through the middle of it; falling down, in all ∫hapes, into the water. -- Like it's great mother-i∫land, the ∫outhern part wears a ∫moother a∫pect, than the northern, which is broken, and rocky.
Formerly the whole i∫land was one entire grove. At pre∫ent, it is rather bare of wood; tho there are ∫ome large oaks upon it.

One of it's greate∫t beauties ari∫es from that irregular little Appennine, ju∫t mentioned, which extends from one end to the other. This circum∫tance hides it's in∫ularity, by connecting it with the continent. In every part, except on the high grounds, you ∫tand in an amphitheatre compo∫ed of the noble∫t objects; and the lake performing the office of a ∫unk fence, the grandeur of each part of the continent is called in, by turns, to aid the in∫ignificance of the i∫land.

The oblong form al∫o of the lake gives the i∫land another great advantage. On both it's ∫ides, the oppo∫ite ∫hores of the continent are little more than half a mile di∫tant: but at the northern and ∫outhern points there is a large ∫heet of water. The views therefore, as you walk round, are continually changing
through all the varieties of di∫tances; which are ∫till farther improved by a little degree of obliquity, in the po∫ition of the i∫land.

He who ∫hould take upon him to ornament ∫uch a ∫cene as this, would have only to conduct his walk and plantations, ∫o as to take advantage of the grand parts of the continent around him; -- to hide what is offen∫ive -- and, amid∫t a choice of great and picture∫que ∫cenes, to avoid ∫hewing too much. As he would have, at all times, an exuberance of water, he ∫hould not be o∫tentatious in di∫playing it. It would be a relief to the eye ∫ometimes to exclude it wholly; and to introduce a mere ∫ylvan ∫cene, with di∫tant mountains ri∫ing above it. A tran∫ient glance of the water, with ∫ome well-cho∫en objects beyond it, would often al∫o have a good effect; and ∫ometimes a grand expan∫ion of the whole. -- Thus the objects around, tho unmanageable in them∫elves, might be brought under command by the a∫∫i∫tance of an in∫ular ∫ituation.

With regard to the ornamenting of ∫uch a ∫cene, an elegant neatne∫s is all the improver
∫hould aim at. Amid∫t the∫e grand objects of nature, it would be ab∫urd to catch the eye with the affected decorations of art. The ∫imple idea he would de∫ire to pre∫erve, is, what the place it∫elf ∫ugge∫ts, a ∫eque∫tered retreat. The boundaries ∫hould in a great mea∫ure be thicket -- on the ea∫tern coa∫t e∫pecially, which is oppo∫ed to the only cultivated part of the country: and if there be any thing in that part worth giving to the eye, it might be given through ∫ome unaffected opening.
For thickets, the wild wood of the country would abundantly ∫uffice. It grows luxuriantly, and would ∫oon produce it's effect.
The middle parts of the i∫land, with a few clumps properly di∫po∫ed, might be neat pa∫turage, with flocks, and herds; which would contra∫t agreeably with the rough ∫cenery around.
The hou∫e, at pre∫ent, ∫tands too formally in the middle of the i∫land. It might ∫tand better near the ∫outhern promontory. The air of this ∫weet retreat is ∫aid to be very pure.
chap.note: Since this view of Windermere i∫land was taken, it hath been under the hands of improvement. The proprietor, I have been told, ∫pent ∫ix thou∫and pounds upon it; with which ∫um he has contrived to do almo∫t every thing, that one would wi∫h had been left undone. It is now in other hands, which may probably re∫tore it's beauty.
chap.p: This i∫land belonged formerly to the Philip∫ons, a family of note in We∫tmoreland. During the civil wars, two of them, an elder, and a younger brother, ∫erved the king. The former, who was the proprietor of it, commanded a regiment: the latter was a major.

The major, who∫e name was Robert, was a man of great ∫pirit, and enterprize; and for his many feats of per∫onal bravery, had obtained, among the Oliverians of tho∫e parts, the appellation of Robin the Devil.

After the war ∫ub∫ided, Col. Briggs, a ∫teady friend to the u∫urpation, re∫iding at Kendal, under the double character of a leading magi∫trate (for he was a ju∫tice of the peace) and an active commander, held the country in awe. This per∫on having heard, that Major Philp∫on was at his brother's hou∫e on the i∫land in Windermere, re∫olved, if po∫∫ible, to ∫eize, and puni∫h a man, who
had made him∫elf ∫o particularly obnoxious. With this view he mu∫tered a party, which he thought ∫ufficient; and went him∫elf on the enterprize. How it was conducted, my authority does not inform us -- whether he got together the navigation of the lake, and blockaded the place by ∫ea; or whether, he landed, and carried on his approaches in form. Neither do we learn the ∫trength of the garri∫on within; nor of the works without: thos every gentleman's hou∫e was, at that time, in ∫ome degree a fortre∫s. All we learn, is, that Major Philp∫on endured a ∫eige of eight, or ten days with great gallantry; till his brother, the colonel, hearing of his di∫tre∫s, rai∫ed a party, and relieved him.
chap.note: Dr Bourn's hi∫. of We∫tmoreland.
chap.p:
It was now the major's turn to make reprizals. He put him∫elf therefore at the head of a little troop of hor∫e, and rode to Kendal, where Col. Briggs re∫ided. Here being informed, that the colonel was at prayers, (for it was on a ∫unday morning) he ∫tationed his men properly in the avenues; and him∫elf, armed, roder directly into the church. It is
∫aid, he intended to ∫eize the colonel, and carry him off: but as this ∫eems to have been totally impracticable, it is rather probably, that his intention was to kill him on the ∫pot; and in the mid∫t of the confu∫ion, to e∫cape. Whatever his intention was, it was fru∫trated; for Briggs happened to be el∫ewhere.

The congregation, as might be expected, was thrown into great confu∫ion on ∫eeing an armed man, on hor∫eback, enter the church; and the major taking the advantage of their a∫toni∫hment, turned his hor∫e round, and rode quietly out. But having given an alarm, he was pre∫ently a∫∫aulted as he left the church: and being ∫eized; his girths were cut; and he was unhor∫ed.

At this in∫tant, his party made a furious attack on the a∫∫ailants; and the major, killing with his own hand, the man, who had ∫eized him, clapped the ∫addle, ungirthed as it was, upon his hor∫e; and vaulting into it, rode full ∫peed through the ∫treets of Kendal, calling to his men to follow him; and with his whole party made a ∫afe retreat to his a∫ylum in the lake. -- The action marked the man. Many knew him; and they who did not, knew as well from the exploit, that it
could be nobody, but Robin the Devil. -- Such are the calamities of civil war! After the direful effects of public oppo∫ition cea∫e; revenge, and private malice long keep alive the animo∫ity of individuals.

chap.title: Volume 1, Section XI.
chap.head: SECT. XI.
chap.p: HAVING thus taken a view of a place abounding with ∫o many beauties, we found our bark waiting for us at the northern point; and ∫etting ∫ail, in∫tead of returning to Bowne∫s, we ∫tood for Amble∫ide. We could have wi∫hed to navigate the whole lake; but it was too great an undertaking for mea∫ured time; and we contented our∫elves with going in que∫t of the beauties of it's northern divi∫ion.
As we left the i∫land, the ∫cene opening on every ∫ide, we found our∫elves ∫urrounded with objects of great magnificence.

On the we∫tern coa∫t ran a continuous range of craggy mountains, thinly ∫cattered over with trees, which had formerly over∫pread it. It is a part of Furne∫s-fell; the whole of which
we had before ∫een, in one va∫t combination of di∫tant mountains, bounding our view over the bay of Cartmel. The part we now ∫aw ∫tretches about two leagues along the lake.

On the ea∫tern ∫ide, we pa∫∫ed ∫everal ∫mall i∫lands, ∫ome of which were well-wooded; others were mere rocks with low, twi∫ted trees bur∫ting from their crevices; all of them probably worth vi∫iting, if our time had allowed. Through the openings of the∫e i∫lands, we had partial views of the ea∫tern coa∫t; till having advanced further through this little archipelago into the body of the lake, the whole ea∫tern ∫kreen opened to the eye -- This ∫ide, tho le∫s magnificent than the mountains of Furne∫s on the left, contains however more variety. It is broken into hills; ∫ome of which are cultivated, and others covered with wood.

But, on the whole, neither of the∫e ∫ide-∫creens is an object purely picture∫que. The we∫tern ∫hore is great indeed; but it is an unvaried ma∫s of heavy greatne∫s. The ea∫tern is broken too much, and wants both unity and grandeur. When we rode through it in the morning, it made an admirable fore-ground in almo∫t every part: but we now found it le∫s qualified as a di∫tance.

The ∫ide-∫creens however are the lea∫t e∫∫ential parts of this va∫t ∫cene. The front is the capital part -- that part, on which the eye immediately ∫ettles. It con∫i∫ts of that immen∫e body of barrier mountains, which ∫eparate the two counties of Cumberland and We∫tmoreland; appearing in this view to be drawn up in a ∫ort of tumultuary array, mountain beyond mountain, as far as the eye could reach.

As we advanced in our voyage, this great divi∫ion of the lake (from the i∫lands to it's northern point,) tho really oblong, a∫∫umed the form of a va∫t circular ba∫on: and the rough mountains, ari∫ing round it, appeared, from ∫o ∫plended an area, with new grandeur. Indeed contra∫t gave an additional force to the character of each.

This great ∫cene however, ∫urveyed thus from a centre, was rather amu∫ing, than picture∫que. It was too exten∫ive for the painter's u∫e. A ∫mall portion of the circle, reduced to paper, or canvas, could have conveyed no idea; and a large ∫egment would have exceeded all the powers of the pallet.

It is certainly an error in land∫cape-painting, to comprehend too much. It turns a picture into a map. Nothing is more delu∫ive, than to ∫uppo∫e, that every view, which plea∫es in nature, will plea∫e in painting. In nature, the plea∫ure ari∫es from the eye's roaming from one pa∫∫age to another; and making it's remarks on each. In painting, (as the eye is there confined within certain limits,) it ari∫es from ∫eeing ∫ome ∫elect ∫pot adorned agreeably to the rules of art. And the painter, who wi∫hes to make a plea∫ing compo∫ition, mu∫t not include more than he can thus adorn. His fore-ground, and his di∫tance mu∫t bear a proportion to each other; which cannot be the ca∫e, if he include a va∫t compa∫s. For as he can only take in a certain quantity of fore-ground; the removed parts of his picture ∫hould bear a proper proportion to it. Well-managed exceptions may be found: yet ∫till, in general, the rule is good.

But altho the whole of the amphitheatre we are now ∫urveying, was, in it's full dimen∫ions, no ∫ubject for a picture; yet it exhibited many parts which, as di∫tances, were purely picture∫que; and afforded an admirable collection of mountain ∫tudies for a painter. I ∫peak
particularly of the front ∫kreen, in which the lines of the mountains were beautiful, and various -- the inter∫ections al∫o of tho∫e lines -- the promontories; with the deep ∫hades they projected -- and above all, the mountain colouring, which was the mo∫t ∫plendid we had ever ∫een. Airy tints of vivid yellow, green, and purple, we could pri∫matically ∫eparate. Bright ∫pots of effulgence al∫o appeared; which could not well be denominated of any colour. Yet all, tho di∫played in ∫uch rich profu∫ion, were blended with ∫uch nice harmony; and tempered ∫o mode∫tly by the grey mi∫tine∫s of di∫tance; that gorgeous as the∫e hues were, there was not a ∫ingle colour, that glared, or was out of place.

poem.line: ---- For who can paint
Like nature? Can imagination boa∫t,
Amid∫t it's gay creation, hues like her's?
Or can it mix them with that matchle∫s ∫kill
And lo∫e them in each other?

chap.p:
We had now made a con∫iderable progre∫s in our voyage. The ∫ide-∫creen on the left, kept ∫till the ∫ame di∫tance; but the mountains in front, as we approached them, began now to ∫eparate into near, and di∫tant grounds:
and the rocks and woods, which, in the painter's language, adhered before; now broke away in a variety of projections; tho ∫till o'er∫pread with ∫oft colouring, and tender ∫hadow.

As we approached nearer, this ∫oftne∫s of colouring took a more vivid hue; and the promontories, and rocks continued ∫till projecting to the eye with new force of ∫hade: while the mountains, which ranged behind, began more and more to retire. The length of the lake, tho it affected the nearer grounds, made no change in the di∫tant mountains: ∫o that the comparative di∫tance between the fore-ground and them, was now much greater, than it had been.
An appearance of this kind is beautifully de∫cribed by Virgil. When Æneas came in ∫ight of Italy, he fir∫t ∫aw a hazy appearance of hills, and low land;

poem.line: ----procul ob∫curos colles, humilemque videmus
Italiam ----

chap.p:
On a nearer approach, he di∫covered the temple of Minerva, which being ∫eated on
high ground, ∫eemed, as if it ∫tood on a promontory hanging over the ∫ea.

poem.line: ----Templum apparet in arce Minervæ

chap.p: But as he came clo∫e in with the land, the rocks took their proper form; and the temple retreated to a di∫tance.

poem.line: ---- Gemino demittunt brachia muro
Turriti ∫copuli; re∫ugitque a litore templum.

chap.p: As we approached the end of the lake, the promontories and rocks a∫∫umed new height; and almo∫t hid the mountains, which continued to retire beyond them; while the form of the nearer grounds began al∫o to vary. The water, which, a little before, ∫eemed in contact with the rocks, appeared now to wa∫h a meadow; beyond which the rocks formed a fir∫t di∫tance.

The ∫cenery put us in mind of Berghem; who often cho∫e a meadow, with a rock behind it, to relieve his cattle. His rock is generally left plain, and ∫imple, almo∫t without a ∫ingle varying tint; a mere ma∫s of tender ∫hadow: while the cattle are touched with infinite force and ∫pirit. We ∫aw the picture realized. Berghem's imagination could not
have formed a better back-ground, nor a more beautiful group. Such combinations are plea∫ing in life, in painting, and in poetry.

poem.line: ---- On the gra∫∫y bank
Some ruminating lie, while others ∫tand
Half in the flood; and often bending ∫ip
The circling-∫urface. In the middle rears
The ∫trong, laborious ox his hone∫t front,
Which incompo∫ed he ∫hakes; and from his ∫ide
The troublous in∫ects la∫hes with his tail,
Returning ∫till. Amid his ∫ubjects ∫afe,
Slumbers the monarch-∫wain, his carele∫s arm
Thrown round his head, on downy mo∫s reclined;
Here lay his ∫crip, with whol∫ome viands filled;
There, li∫tening every noi∫e, his faithful dog.

chap.p: Through the meadow at the bottom of the rocky ground, two rivers, the Bratha, and the Rotha, wind their way; and uniting before they meet the lake, enter it with a full, but quiet ∫tream; and furni∫h it with large ∫upplies.
The Rotha takes it's ri∫e from mountains about twelve miles di∫tant; and forms the two lakes of Gra∫mer, and Rydal, before it enter Windermere.

The Bratha ri∫es from the pike of Langdale, in a mountainous, and rocky country; and
after a turbulent cour∫e, buries at length all it's inquietude in the peaceful waters of the lake, where it's name is no more remembred.
Our boatmen having conveyed us a con∫iderable way up the∫e united ∫treams, landed us on the meadows, within half a mile of Amble∫ide.
Before we leave this grand expan∫e of water, I cannot forbear remarking a few circum∫tances, that relate to it.

In the fir∫t place we admired it's extraordinary brightne∫s. It is all over nitidis argenteus undis. The eye can ∫ee di∫tinctly, in ∫mooth water, through a medium of at lea∫t a dozen yards; and view the inhabitants of it's deep rece∫∫es, as they play in ∫hoals, and

poem.line: ----∫porting with quick glance
Shew to the ∫un their waved coats dropt with gold.

chap.p:
How far the tran∫parency of water is an addition to a scene, I cannot take upon me to ∫ay. Mo∫t of the lakes in Scotland, which I ∫aw, are of a mo∫∫y-tinctured hue; and yet had their full effect in land∫cape. -- As a detached object however the tran∫parent lake is
incomparably the mo∫t beautiful. I ∫hould ∫uppo∫e al∫o, that the more brilliant the water is, the more brilliant are the reflections.

Among the great variety of fi∫h, which inhabit the exten∫ive waters of this lake, the char is the mo∫t remarkable. It is near twice the ∫ize of a herring. It's back is of an olive-green: it's belly of a light vermilion; ∫oftening in ∫ome parts into white; and changing into a deep red, at the in∫ertion of the fins.

A parcel of char, ju∫t caught and thrown together into the luggage-pool of a boar, makes a plea∫ant harmony of colouring. The green olive-tint prevails; to which a ∫pirit is here and there given by a light blu∫h of vermilion; and by a ∫trong touch of red, if a fin happen to appear. The∫e plea∫ing colours are a∫∫i∫ted by the bright ∫ilvery lights, which play over the whole; for nothing reflects light more beautifully than the ∫cales of fi∫h.

Char are caught only in the winter-∫ea∫on, when twenty dozen in a day, are ∫ometimes taken by a ∫ingle boat. In ∫ummer they retire to the rocky caves below, ∫ome of which are ∫aid to be unfathomable: nor do they breed
in any lake, in which ∫uch deep rece∫∫es are not found.

The char-fi∫hing is a very profitable branch of trade to the proprietors of the lake. The whole area of it is divided into five di∫tricts. An invi∫ible line cro∫∫es the ∫urface from crag to crag -- a limit, which the fi∫herman correctly knows. But tho the ∫pace of each fi∫hery is nearly equal, yet the produce is otherwi∫e; the fi∫h running in ∫hoals ∫ometimes in one part of the lake, and ∫ometimes in another. -- When the farmer rents land, he can judge of his bargain by the ∫urface. When he rents water, he mu∫t take his chance.

But fi∫h are not the only inhabitants of this lake. Innumerable flights of water-fowl frequent it's exten∫ive plain. The naturali∫t may declare their names, and cla∫∫es: the painter has only to remark the variety of forms, in which they appear -- ∫ometimes ∫itting in black groups upon the water, ri∫ing and ∫inking with the waves: at other times in the air, circling the lake in figured files; or with he∫itating wing ∫eizing ∫ome ∫tation on it's banks, or ∫urface. -- With regard to the∫e minute ap-
pendages of land∫cape, let me only ∫ugge∫t, that birds ∫hould never be introduced upon the wing, near the eye. Quick motion, of any kind, repre∫ented, is an ab∫urdity: and the longer you look, the more ab∫urd it becomes. But at a little di∫tance the motion of a bird appears ∫o ∫low, that the eye will endure a degree of improbability in the repre∫entation of it.

I have only to add, that this magnificent piece of water ∫uffers little change, in appearance, from ∫ea∫ons; but pre∫erves the dignity of it's character under all circum∫tances; ∫eldom depre∫∫ed, and as ∫eldom rai∫ed above it's ordinary level -- Even in the mo∫t violent rains, when the country is drenched in water, the mountains pour down floods through new channels; the lake maintains the ∫ame equal temper; and tho it may ∫pread a few yards over it's lowe∫t ∫hores (which is the utmo∫t it does) yet it's increa∫e is ∫eldom the object of ob∫ervation: nor does the ∫everity of the greate∫t drought make any con∫iderable alternation in it's bounds. Once, (it is recorded,)
it ro∫e ∫even feet in perpendicular height. It's boundaries would then certainly appear inlarged; but this was a very uncommon ca∫e.

But if it be not rai∫ed by rains, it is often greatly agitated by winds. Of all the lakes of this country, none lies ∫o expo∫ed, through the whole length of it, to ∫udden ∫qualls, as this: nor does any piece of fre∫h water in the whole i∫land perhaps emulate the grandeur of a di∫turbed ocean ∫o much. It is of cour∫e navigated with great caution, whenever there is a tendency to ∫tormy weather.
