Many accidents have ∫hewn the nece∫∫ity of this caution: but one made ∫uch an impre∫∫ion on the country, as a century cannot efface. Several people in the neighbourhood of Bowne∫s, having been attending a fair at Hawk∫hed, a town on the other ∫ide of the lake, had embarked, in the evening, on their return home. But before this little voyage could be performed, ∫o violent a ∫torm aro∫e, that their boats foundered; and no fewer than forty-∫even per∫ons peri∫hed.
chap.note: This account is taken from Dr. Bourn's hi∫t. of We∫tmoreland. It is probable the∫e people might all have peri∫hed together in the ferry boat.

chap.title: Volume 1, Section XII.
chap.head: SECT. XII.
chap.p: FROM Amble∫ide we propo∫ed to ∫et out for Ke∫wick; being obliged, for want of time, to leave one ∫cene behind us, which we wi∫hed much to vi∫it -- that of Furne∫s-abbey. But the lo∫s was in a great mea∫ure made up, and our curio∫ity ∫atisfied, by the accounts and drawings of Mr. John Smith, an ingenious young painter, who had been ∫tudying the ruins on the ∫pot.
chap.note: This arti∫t has had a principal hand in etching the drawings which accompany the∫e ob∫ervations.
chap.p:
Furne∫s-abbey lies about twenty miles from Amble∫ide, beyond tho∫e mountains, which range on the we∫tern ∫ide of Windermere. It is ∫ituated in a beautiful valley, in the mid∫t
of a wide, open, cultivated country, which ri∫es every where in large ∫wells; but is no where diver∫ified by any objects of picture∫que beauty. In ∫o inanimate a ∫cene we are ∫urprized to find a valley of ∫o different a ∫tructure; adorned with rock, and wood; through which winds a rapid ∫tream.
At the entrance of this ∫cene ∫tands the village of Dalton; from whence the valley, winding about four miles in one large, ∫weeping, narrow curve, opens on a rich view of Cartmel-bay.

About a mile within the valley, in the wide∫t part, ∫tands the abbey. It ∫eems to have been con∫tructed in a good ∫tyle of Gothic architecture; and has ∫uffered, from the hand of time, only ∫uch depredations, as picture∫que beauty requires. The intire plan of the abbey-church, and a large fragment of it, ∫till remain. The tower in the centre, which ∫eems never to have been lofty, is perforated with large arches. At the end of the we∫tern aile ∫tand the ruins of a low, ∫imple tower, where the bells of the abbey are ∫uppo∫ed to have hung: and from the ∫outh aile projects a building, which is called the chapter-hou∫e. The cloy∫ters are continued in the ∫ame di-
rection; one wall of which, and all the internal ∫tructure are gone. At the end of the cloy∫ters ari∫es a very rich and picture∫que fragment, which is called the ∫chool.

Round the whole runs an irregular wall, which cro∫∫ing the valley in two places, and mounting it's ∫ides, makes a circuit of about two miles. In many parts it is hid with trees, or ∫hrubs: in ∫ome parts, where it is di∫covered, it is beautiful; and in very few, di∫gu∫ting.

In this wall are two gates, one to the north, and the other to the we∫t; which ∫eem to have been the only outlets of the place. That to the north has been the great entrance: the other has more the appearance of a po∫tern with a porter's lodge.
The proprietor of this noble ∫cene is lord George Cavendi∫h, who is a faithful guardian of it, and, I am informed, takes care to prevent any further depredations.
From Amble∫ide we ∫et out for Ke∫wick, which is about eighteen miles farther north.

We were now about to enter the middle, and mo∫t formidable part, of that va∫t chain
of mountains, which I have before mentioned, as the barrier between Cumberland, and We∫tmoreland; and which promi∫ed, from a di∫tant view, to pre∫ent us with a great variety of very grand ∫cenery. Our morning's voyage on the ∫mooth expan∫e of the lake aided our pre∫ent expedition with all the powers of contra∫t.
But before we enter the∫e maje∫tic ∫cenes, it may be nece∫∫ary to premi∫e a di∫tinction between a ∫cene of mountains, and a mountain ∫cene.

Mountainous countries mo∫t commonly pre∫ent only the former. The objects are grand; but they are huddled together, confu∫ed, without connection; and the painter con∫iders them onoly as ∫tudies; and forms them into pictures by imaginary combinations.

We ∫omtimes however ∫ee a mountainous country, in which nature it∫elf hath made the∫e beautiful combinations -- where one part relates to another, and the effect of a whole is produced. This is what I call a mountain ∫cene.

Of this latter kind is almo∫t the whole road between Amble∫ide, and Ke∫wick. The mountains are naturally combined into ∫cenes; which if not, in all parts, purely picture∫que; are, in all parts, marked with the great lines of compo∫ition; tho often on too wide a ∫cale for imitation.

The fir∫t object of our attention, on leaving Amble∫ide, was Rydal-hall, the ∫eat of Sir Michael le Fleming. It ∫tands on a ri∫ing lawn. On the north and ea∫t it is ∫heltered by lofty mountains. In front, towards the ∫outh, it commands a noble di∫tance, con∫i∫ting of the exten∫ive vale of Windermere, bounded by the lake. The mountain, on the north, called Rydal-cragg, ri∫ing clo∫e behind the hou∫e, is high and rocky. That on the ea∫t, is of inferior ∫ize, but is covered with wood. Between the∫e mountains runs a narrow, wooded valley; through which a con∫iderable ∫tream, falling down a quick de∫cent, along a rocky channel, forms a ∫ucce∫∫ion of ca∫cades.

One of the∫e, tho but a miniature, is ∫o beautiful both in it∫elf, and in it's accompaniments, as to de∫erve particular notice. -- It is
∫een from a ∫ummer-hou∫e; before which it's rocky cheeks circling on each ∫ide form a little area; appearing through the window like a picture in a frame. The water falls within a few yards of the eye, which being rather above it's level, has a long per∫pective view of the ∫tream, as it hurries from the higher grounds; tumbling, in various, little breaks, through it's rocky channel, darkened with thicket, till it arrive at the edge of the precipice, before the window; from whence it ru∫hes into the ba∫on, which is formed by nature in the native rock. The dark colour of the ∫tone, taking ∫till a deeper tinge from the wood, which hangs over it, ∫ets off to wonderful advantage the ∫parkling lu∫tre of the ∫tream; and produces an uncommon effect of light. It is this effect indeed, from which the chief beauty of the ∫cene ari∫es. In every repre∫entation, truly picture∫que, the ∫hade ∫hould greatly overbalance the light. The face of nature, under the glow of noon, has rarely this beautiful appearance. The arti∫t therefore generally courts her charms in a morning, or an evening hour, when the ∫hadows are deep, and extended; and when the ∫loping ∫un-beam affords rather a catching,
than a glaring light. In this little exhibition we had an admirable idea of the magical effect of light picture∫quely di∫tributed.
On leaving Rydal, we entered a va∫t cha∫m between two mountains, which may properly be called a portal to the ∫cenes we approached.

On pa∫∫ing it, we were pre∫ented with a grand ∫cene of mountains; adorned by a lake, called Rydal-water, on the left; not indeed adequate to the greatne∫s of the ∫urrounding objects; but of ∫uch beauty, as immediately to fix the eye. In the mid∫t of it is a rocky i∫land, covered with wood. The little river Rotha, winding round a promontory, enters it on the north.

Leaving the∫e ∫cenes, we a∫cended a very ∫teep hill; from the ∫ummit of which was di∫played a pro∫pect of de∫olation in a very dignified form. It was an amphitheatre of craggy mountains, which appeared to ∫weep round a circumference of at lea∫t thirty miles; tho in fact, perhaps it did not include half that ∫pace. But great objects naturally form a
wide ∫cale of men∫uration. -- The ∫oul involuntarily ∫huddered at the fir∫t a∫pect of ∫uch a ∫cene. -- At the di∫tant part of it lay Gra∫mer-lake; which being ∫o far removed from the eye, ∫eemed only a bright ∫pot at the bottom of the mountains.

To this lake the road directly led. A nearer approach pre∫ented us with ∫ome beautiful views on it's banks; tho, on the whole, it's principal merit con∫i∫ted in refre∫hing the eye with a ∫mooth expan∫e of water, in the mid∫t of ∫uch a variety of rough mountain-∫cenery. As we ∫kirted it's limits, it ∫eemed larger, than that of Rydal; and tho it appeared like a ∫pot at a di∫tance, became now the principal feature of this va∫t vale.

From hence the road led us into another amphitheatre, wild, and immen∫e like the former; but varied greatly in the ∫hapes of the mountains; which were here more broken and irregular; ∫hooting, in many places, into craggy ∫ummits, and broken points.

And yet even the∫e wild ∫cenes, covered, as they are, with craggs, and ∫carce furni∫hing the lea∫t tint of vegetation, are ∫ubject to rights,
for which none but the hard inhabitant would think it worth his while to contend. You ∫ee every where their bare, and barren ∫ides marked with partition-walls -- ∫tones without morter, laid upon each other, cro∫∫ing at right angles; and running down ∫teeps, and along precipices, where the eye can ∫carce conceive they could have any foundation. All the∫e partitions of de∫olation, as they may be called, have their inhabitants; each maintaining a few ∫tunted ∫heep, which picking the meagre tufts of gra∫s, which grow under the ∫heltered ∫ides of craggs, and ∫tones, earn, like their owners, a hard ∫ub∫i∫tence.

At the conclu∫ion of this immen∫e amphitheatre, into which we la∫t entered, we found an exit, equal to the ∫cene -- another grand mountain-gap, or portal, through which the road carried us up another ∫teep mountain -- At the top we pau∫ed, and looking back on the ∫cenes we had left, were pre∫ented with a view, which wholly filled the imagination.

It was a retro∫pect of the amphitheatre we had pa∫∫ed; but in a ∫tyle ∫till grander, than the pro∫pect of it. It was more ∫trongly marked with great out-lines of compo∫ition; and was, of cour∫e, more a whole.

A wide vale, thrown by per∫pective into a circular form, lay before the eye. Here al∫o the di∫tant part ∫eemed occupied by the lake of Gra∫mer; but a greyi∫h mi∫t left the idea ambiguous. Beyond the lake aro∫e various mountains, which bounded it: and ∫till beyond the∫e, appeared the blue heads of other mountains. Tho∫e, which formed the ∫ide-∫creens of the vale, advancing forward from the di∫tant mountains beyond the lake, approached the eye in a grand ∫weep, by the ea∫y gradations of per∫pective. The promontories, and rece∫∫es, of the more removed parts were marked by a faint ∫hadow; till by degrees both the ∫ide-∫creens, growing boldly on the eye, were lo∫t behind the two cheeks of the craggy portal, which, with the road between them, formed a fore-ground equal to the ∫cene. The whole view is entirely of the horrid kind. Not a tree appeared to add the lea∫t chearfulne∫s to it.

With regard to the adorning of ∫uch a ∫cene with figures, nothing could ∫uit it better than a group of banditti. Of all the ∫cenes I ever ∫aw, this was the mo∫t adapted to the perpetration of ∫ome dreadful deed. The imagination can hardly avoid conceiving a band of robbers lurking under the ∫helter of ∫ome pro-
jecting rock; and expecting the traveller, as he approaches along the valley below.

Nothing however of this kind was ever heard of in the country. The depredations of foxed, are the only depredations, to which the cottages in the∫e vallies are expo∫ed. Our po∫tilion pointed to a rugged part on the ∫ummit of a rocky mountain on the left, which, he told us, was the great harbour of the∫e animals. Here they bred; from hence they infe∫ted the country; and to this inacce∫∫ible a∫ylum they retreated in the hour of alarm.

After we left the two amphitheatres, ju∫t de∫cribed, we met with nothing bery intere∫ting, till we came to the celebrated pa∫s, known by the name of Dunmail-Rai∫e, which divides the counties of Cumberland, and We∫tmoreland.

The hi∫tory of this rude monument, which con∫i∫ts of a mon∫trous pile of ∫tones, heaped on each ∫ide of an earthen mound, is little known. It was probably intended to mark a divi∫ion, not between tho∫e two northern counties; but rather between the two kingdoms of England, and Scotland, in elder times, when the Scotti∫h border extended
beyond it's pre∫ent bounds. And indeed this chain of mountains ∫eems to be a much more natural divi∫ion of the two kingdoms, in this part, than a little river in a champaign country, like the E∫k, which now divides them. It is ∫aid, this divi∫ion was made by a Saxon prince, on the death of Dunmail the la∫t king of Cumberland, who was here ∫lain in battle. -- But for whatever purpo∫e this rude pile was fabricated, it hath yet ∫uffered little change in it's dimen∫ions; and is one of tho∫e monuments of antiquity, which may be characterized by the ∫criptural phra∫e of remaining to this very day.

The entrance into Cumberland pre∫ents us with a ∫cene very ∫trongly marked with the ∫ublime; grander, tho le∫ picture∫que, than the amphitheatre we had pa∫∫ed. It is a vi∫ta of mountains pur∫uing each other, if I may ∫o phra∫e it, through an ea∫y de∫cent
of not le∫s than ∫ix, or ∫even miles; and clo∫ed at the di∫tant end by Wyburn-lake, a con∫iderable piece of water.
chap.note: There are three pa∫∫ages, over this chain of mountains, into Cumberland. This by Amble∫ide, is the wilde∫t, and mo∫t picture∫que. A ∫econd by Brough over Stainmore, is dreary, rather than wild: and a third by Shap, is both.
chap.p: This ∫cene is great in all it's parts; and in it's general compo∫ition. The mountains, of which the ∫ide-∫creens of this vi∫ta are formed, fall generally in ea∫y lines, and range at the di∫tance of a mile and a half, or two miles, from each other. But it is difficult to a∫certain a di∫tance of this kind: for as the mountain ri∫es gradually from it's ba∫e, we cannot ea∫ily fix where it begins. It is enough to ob∫erve, that through the whole immen∫ity of the view before us there appeared no di∫proportion.

Among the mountains, which compo∫e this magnificent ∫cene, there is one on the right, of ∫uperior grandeur,; ∫tretching, near a league and a half, in one va∫t concave ridge. This mountain is known by the name of Helvellin; with which three mountains only, through this va∫t region, di∫pute the point of altitude -- Cro∫s-fell -- Gra∫mer -- and Skiddaw. The inhabitants of it's invirons give it univer∫ally for Helvellin: but, I believe, it is no where el∫e treated with ∫uch re∫pect.

Be∫ides the general grandeur of this view, there is a wonderful variety in the ∫hapes of the ∫everal mountains, which compo∫e it. Nature's vi∫tas are never formed by rule, and compa∫s. Whenever ∫he deviates towards a regular ∫hape, ∫he does it with that negligent air of greatne∫s, which marks ∫ublimity of genius. No attention to trifles characterizes her ∫cenes. Her very regularities di∫cover tho∫e ∫trong touches of contra∫t, that range of imagination, which de∫troys every idea of ∫amene∫s.

Of all the rude ∫cenery we had yet vi∫ited, none is equalled this in de∫olation. The whole is one immen∫ity of barrenne∫s. The mountains are univer∫ally over∫pread with craggs, and ∫tones, which are ∫ometimes ∫cattered carele∫sly over their ∫urfaces; and ∫ometimes appear ∫hivering in ca∫cades of crumbling fragments down their ∫ides. Helvellin, through all it's ∫pace, is one intire pavement. Nor is the view disfigured by the abundance of this more ordinary ∫pecies of rock. In it's va∫tne∫s the parts coale∫ce; and become a
whole. -- The fractured rock, ∫o beautiful in it∫elf, is calculated rather for ∫maller pictures. Here it would be lo∫t.
chap.note: See pages 108.
chap.p: The∫e va∫t regions, who∫e parts are thus ab∫orbed in the immen∫ity of a whole, have the ∫tronge∫t effect on the imagination. They di∫tend the mind, and fix it in a kind of ∫tupor:

poem.line: ---- the∫e regions, where retired
From little ∫cenes of art, great Nature dwells
In awful solitude ----

chap.p: We now approached the lake of Wyburn, or Thirlmer, as it is ∫ometimes called; an object every way ∫uited to the ideas of de∫olation, which ∫urround it. No tufted verdure graces it's banks, nor hanging woods throw rich reflections on it's ∫urface: but every form, which it ∫ugge∫ts, is ∫avage, and de∫olate. It is about two miles in length, and half as much in breadth, ∫urrounded by barren mountains, and precipices, ∫helving into it in all directions:

poem.line: ---- A joyle∫s coa∫t
Around a ∫tormy lake ----

chap.p: And to impre∫s ∫till more the characteri∫tic idea of the place; the road hanging over it, ran along the edge of a precipice. -- One peculiar feature al∫o belongs to it. About the middle of the lake, the ∫hores, on each ∫ide, nearly uniting, are joined by an Alpine bridge. I did no ob∫erve any picture∫que beauty ari∫ing from this circum∫tance: but rather a formality; at lea∫t from the ∫tand, where I viewed it. A communication however of this kind rather increa∫es the romantic idea.

Beyond Wyburn-lake we deviated into a mere ∫cene of mountains. Nature ∫eemed to have aimed at ∫ome mode of compo∫ition, which ∫he had left unfini∫hed; but it was difficult to conceive, what ∫pecies of land∫cape ∫he meant; a valley, or a woody rece∫s; a barren ∫cene, or a cultivated one. There was a mixture of all.

This mi∫cellaneous pa∫∫age however did not continue long. It appeared only a ∫hort interruption of the grand vi∫ta, from which we had deviated at the lake of Wyburn; and into which we now returned. Nature however ∫eemed to have ∫pent her force in her fir∫t
effort; which was greatly ∫uperior to the ∫econd.

The thickets among the∫e mountains, and indeed many other parts of the country, are frequented by the wild-cat; which Mr. Pennant calls the Briti∫h tyger; and ∫ays, it is the fierce∫t, and mo∫t de∫tructive bea∫t we have. He ∫peaks of it as being three or four times as large as the common cat. We ∫aw one dead, which had been hunted on the day we ∫aw it; and it ∫eemed very little inferior, if at all, to the ∫ize he mentions.
By this time we approached Ke∫wick; and from the de∫cent of Ca∫tle-hill, at about two miles di∫tance, had an exten∫ive view of the whole country around that celebrated ∫cene of romantic beauty.

Before us lay a plain many leagues in circumference, divided into two large portions; each of which is floated by a lake. Derwent-water over∫preads the nearer; and Ba∫∫enthwait, the more di∫tant. Surrounding the whole, ri∫es a va∫t, circular chain of mountains; and tow-
ering over them all, on the ea∫tern ∫ide of the i∫thmus, ∫tands the mountain of Skiddaw. We had heard too much of this mountain, to meet it properly: it has none of tho∫e bold projections, and ∫haggy majesty about it, which we expected to have ∫een in this king of mountains. It is a tame, inanimate object; except at ∫uch a di∫tance, as ∫mooths the imbo∫∫ed work of all the∫e rich fabrics; and where it's double top makes it a di∫tingui∫hed object to mark, and characterize a ∫cene. -- But if the mountain di∫appointed us; the ∫cene, over which it pre∫ided, went beyond our imagination.

This rich, exten∫ive view was aided, when we ∫aw it, by all the powers (or, more properly, the re∫plendency) of light and ∫hade. The morning had been fine: but in the afternoon the clouds began to gather, threatening rain. A heavy ∫ky over∫pread the higher, and middle regions o the air with all the ∫olemnity of gloom; dropping it's dark mantle to the ∫kirts of the horizon. Ju∫t as we arrived at the brow of the hill, with the ∫cenery of the two lakes, and their accompaniments before us, the ∫etting ∫un bur∫t forth in a glow of ∫plendor.

If a common ∫un-∫et often gives a beautiful appearance even to an ordinary land∫cape; what mu∫t have been the effect of an uncommon one, on ∫uch a land∫cape as this -- a ∫un-∫et not merely a flood of ∫plendor, but contra∫ted by the fulle∫t depth of ∫hade? Here we had the beauties of the little ∫ummer-hou∫e ∫cene, on the mo∫t exten∫ive ∫cale. The effect was a∫toni∫hing. The whole was a ∫cene of glory -- but a ∫cene of glory painted by the hand of nature. Tho every part glowed with tran∫cendent lu∫tre; the whole was in nice∫t harmony. But it was a tran∫itory vi∫ion. While we gazed; it faded: and in a few moments nothing was left, but the great outlines -- the grand compo∫ition of the ∫cene. We ∫hould have ∫tood over it even thus, in rapture; if we had not ju∫t ∫een what a ∫plendid addition it was capable of receiving.
We have a grand picture from the pencil of a great ma∫ter, of the clo∫e of ∫uch an evening.

poem.line: As when from mountain tops the du∫ky clouds
A∫cending, while the north-wind ∫leeps, o'er∫pread
Heaven's chearful face; the louring element
Scowls, o'er the darken'd land∫cape, ∫now or ∫hower;
If chance the radiant ∫un, with farewel ∫weet,
Extend his evening beam, the fields revive
The birds their notes renew, and bleating herds
Atte∫t their joy, that hill and valley ring.

chap.p: But Milton's ideas, I think, in general, are rather mu∫ical, than picture∫que. We have the ∫ame picture by an inferior ma∫ter; tho a better colouri∫t.

poem.line: Thus all day long the full di∫tended clouds
Indulge their genial ∫tores ----
Till in the we∫tern ∫ky, the downward ∫un
Looks out effulgent from amid the flu∫h
Of broken clouds, gay ∫hifting to his beam.
The rapid radiance in∫tantaneous ∫trikes
The illumin'd moutnain; through the fore∫t ∫treams;
Glows on the lake; and in a yellow mi∫t
Spreads o'er the bright, interminable plain.

chap.p: Here we have all the re∫plendency of light; but not a ∫ufficient balance of ∫hade. Milton gives the balance in the other ∫cale. If Thom∫on had introduced, like Milton, the louring element ∫cowling over his darkened land∫cape, his re∫plendent tints would have had their full force; and the effect had been complete.

Ke∫wick is the fir∫t town we meet with, on our entrance into Cumberland; and tho a place of no con∫equence, is however much
∫uperior to Amble∫ide. Between the two places there is a great re∫emblance. Ke∫wick ∫tands at the north-point of Derwent-water; which is the very point, that Amble∫ide occupies on Windermere. But the ∫ituation of Amble∫ide is more romantic, as it ∫tands more in the middle of that chain of mountains, which ∫eparates the two counties. At Ke∫wick the roughne∫∫es of the country are wearing off: for in a few miles beyond it, this great barrier ends.
Here we re∫olved to fix our head-quarters for a few days; and from thence to vi∫it ∫uch of the neighbouring lakes, and mountains, as had been mo∫t recommended to our notice.

gap.desc: landscape orientated map of Keswick Lake

chap.title: Volume 1, Section XIII.
chap.head: SECT. XIII.
chap.p: ON the 9th of June we ∫et out on hor∫eback (which I mention, as it is the only conveyance the road will admit) on an expedition into Borrodale; a wild country ∫outh-we∫t of Ke∫wick. Our road led along the lake of Derwent, which was the fir∫t object we ∫urveyed.

But before we examined the particulars of this grand ∫cene, we took a general view of the whole, from it's northern ∫hore; which is the only part unblockaded by mountains. This is the i∫thmian part, which joins the valley of Derwent-water with that of Ba∫∫enthwait. It was ea∫y from the higher grounds of this i∫thmus to obtain the ∫tation we de∫ired.

The lake of Derwent, or Ke∫wick-lake, as it is generally called, is contained within a circumference of about ten miles; pre∫enting it∫elf in a circular form, tho in fact it is rather oblong. It's area is inter∫per∫ed with four or five i∫lands: three of which only are of con∫equence, Lord's i∫land, Vicar's i∫land, and St. Herbert's i∫land: but none of them is comparable to the i∫land on Windermere, in point either of ∫ize, or beauty.

If a painter were de∫irous of ∫tudying the whole circumference of the lake from one ∫tation, St. Herbert's i∫land is the ∫pot he ∫hould choo∫e; from whence, as from a centre, he might ∫ee it in rotation. I have ∫een a ∫et of drawings taken from this ∫tand; which were hung round a circular room, and intended to give a general idea of the boundaries of the lake. But as no repre∫entation could be give of the lake it∫elf; the idea was lo∫t, and the drawings made but an awkward appearance.

Lord's i∫land had it's name being the place, where once ∫tood a plea∫ure-hou∫e, belonging to the unfortunate family of Derwent-water, which took it's title from this lake. The ancient manor-hou∫e ∫tood on Ca∫tle-hill above Ke∫wick; where antiquarian traces al∫o the ve∫tiges of a Roman fort. But an heire∫s of Derwent-water marring into the family of the Ratcliffs; the family-∫eat was removed from Ke∫wick to Dil∫ton in Northumberland.

As the boundaries of this lake are more mountainous than tho∫e of Windermere; they, of cour∫e, afford more romantic ∫cenery. But tho the whole ∫hore, except the ∫pot where we ∫tood, is incircled with mountains; they rarely fall abruptly into the water; which is girt almo∫t round by a margin of meadow -- on the we∫tern ∫hores e∫pecially. On the ea∫tern, the mountains approach nearer the water; and in ∫ome parts fall perpendicularly into it. But as we ∫tood viewing the lake from it's northern ∫hores, all the∫e marginal parts were lo∫t; and
the mountains (tho in fact they de∫cribe a circle of twenty miles, which is double the circumference of the lake) appeared univer∫ally to ri∫e from the water's edge.

Along it's we∫tern ∫hores on the right, they ri∫e ∫mooth and uniform; and are therefore rather lumpi∫h. The more removed part of this mountain-line is elegant: but, in ∫ome parts, it is di∫agreeably broken.

On the ea∫tern ∫ide, the mountains are both grander, and more picture∫que. The line is plea∫ing; and is filled with that variety of objects, broken-ground, -- rocks, -- and wood, which being well combined, take from the heavine∫s of a mountain; and give it an airy lightne∫s.

The front-∫creen, (if we may ∫o call a portion of a circular form,) is more formidable, than either of the ∫ides. But it's line is le∫s elegant, than that of the ea∫tern-∫creen. The fall of Lodoar, which adorns that part of the lake, is an object of no con∫equence at the di∫tance we now ∫tood. But in our intended ride we propo∫ed to take a nearer view of it.

Of all the lakes in the∫e romantic regions, the lake we are now examining, ∫eems to be mo∫t generally admired. It was once admirably characterized by an ingenious per∫on, who, on his fir∫t ∫eeing it, cryed out, Here is beauty indeed -- Beauty lying in the lap of Horrour! We do not often find a happier illu∫tration. Nothing conveys an idea of beauty more ∫trongly, than the lake; nor of horrour, than the mountains; and the former lying in the lap of the latter, expre∫∫es in a ∫trong manner the mode of their combination. The late Dr. Brown, who was a man of ta∫te, and had ∫een every part of this country, ∫ingled out the ∫cenery of this lake for it's peculiar beauty. And unque∫tionably it is, in many places, very ∫weetly romantic; particularly along it's ea∫tern, and ∫outhern ∫hores: but to give it pre-eminence may be paying it perhaps as much too high a compliment; as it would be too
rigorous to make any but a few comparative objections.
chap.note: The late Mr. Avi∫on, organi∫t of St. Nicholas at Newca∫tle upon Tyne.
In a letter to Lord Lyttelton, quoted above.
chap.p: In the fir∫t place, it's form, which in appearance is circular, is le∫s intere∫ting, I think, than the winding ∫weep of Windermere, and ∫ome other lakes; which lo∫ing them∫elves in va∫t reaches, behind ∫ome cape or promontory, add to their other beauties the varieties of di∫tance, and per∫pective. Some people object to this, as touching rather on the character of the river. But does that injure it's beauty? And yet I believe there are very few rivers, which form ∫uch reaches, as the lake of Windermere.

To the formality of it's ∫hores may be added the formality of it's i∫lands. They are round, regular, and ∫imilar ∫pots, as they appear from mo∫t points of view; formal in their ∫ituation, as well as in their ∫hape; and of little advantage to the ∫cene. The i∫lands of Windermere are in them∫elves better ∫haped; more varied; and uniting together, add a beauty, and contra∫t to the whole.

But among the greate∫t objections to this lake is the abrupt, and broken line in ∫everal of the mountains, which compo∫e it's ∫creens, (e∫pecially on the we∫tern, and on part of
the ∫outhern ∫hore) which is more remarkable, than on any of the other lakes. We have little of the ea∫y ∫weep of a mountain-line: at lea∫t the eye is hurt with too many tops of mountains, which injure the ideas of ∫implicity, and grandeur. Great care therefore ∫hould be taken in ∫electing views of this lake. If there is a littlene∫s even amid∫t the grand ideas of the original, what can we expect from repre∫entations on paper, or canvas? I have ∫een ∫ome views of this lake, injudiciou∫ly cho∫en, or taken on too exten∫ive a ∫cale, in which the mountains appear like hay-cocks. -- I would be under∫tood however to ∫peak chiefly of the appearance, which the lines of the∫e mountains occa∫ionally make. When we change our point of view, the mountain-line changes al∫o, and may be beautiful in one point, tho it is di∫plea∫ing in another.

Having thus take a view of the whole lake together from it's northern point, we proceeded on our rout to Borrodale, ∫kirting the ea∫tern coa∫t along the edge of the water. The grand ∫ide-∫creen, on the left hung over us; and we found it as beautifully romantic,
and plea∫ing to the imagination, when it's rocks, precipices, and woods became a fore-ground; as it appeared from the northern point of the lake, when we examined it in a more removed point of view.

Nor do the∫e rocky ∫hores recommend them∫elves to us only as fore-grounds. We found them every where the happie∫t ∫tations for obtaining the mo∫t picture∫que views of the lake. The inexperienced conductor, ∫hewing you the lake, carries you to ∫ome gari∫h ∫tand, where the eye may range far and wide. And ∫uch a view indeed is well calculated, as we have ju∫t ∫een, to obtain a general idea of the whole. But he, who is in que∫t of the picture∫que ∫cenes of the lake, mu∫t travel along the rough ∫ide-∫creens that adorn it; and catch it's beauties, as they ari∫e in ∫maller portions -- it's little bays, and winding ∫hores -- it's deep rece∫∫es, and hanging promontories -- it's garni∫hed rock, and di∫tant mountain. The∫e are, in general, the picture∫que ∫cenes, which it affords.

Part of this mountain is known by the name of Lady's-rake, from a tradition, that a young lady of the Derwentwater family, in the time of ∫ome public di∫turbance, e∫caped a pur∫uit
by climbing a precipice, which had been thought inacce∫∫ible. -- A romantic place ∫eldom wants a romantic ∫tory to adorn it.

Detached from this continent of precipice, if I may ∫o ∫peak, ∫tands a rocky hill, known by the name of Ca∫tellet. Under the beetling brow of the natural ruin we pa∫∫ed; and as we viewed it upwards from it's ba∫e, it ∫eemed a fabric of ∫uch grandeur, that alone it was ∫ufficient to give dignity to any ∫cene. We were de∫ired to take particular notice of it for a rea∫on, which ∫hall afterwards be mentioned.

As we proceeded in our rout along the lake, the road grew wilder, and more romantic. There is not an idea more tremendous, than that of riding along the edge of a precipice, unguarded by an parapet, under impending rocks, which threaten above; while the ∫urges of a flood, or the whirlpools of a rapid river, terrify below.

Many ∫uch roads there are in various parts of the world; particularly among the mountains of Norway and Sweden; where they are
carried along precipices of ∫uch frightful height, that the trees at the bottom a∫∫ume the azure tint of di∫tance; and the cataracts which roar among them, cannot even be heard, unle∫s the air be perfectly ∫till. The∫e tremendous roads are often not only without rail, or parapet of any kind; but ∫o narrow, that travellers in oppo∫ite directions cannot pa∫s, unle∫s one of the draw him∫elf up clo∫e to the rock. In ∫ome places, where the precipice does not afford footing even for this narrow ∫helf; or, where it may have foundered, a cleft pine is thrown acro∫s the cha∫m. The appalled traveller arriving at the ∫pot, ∫urveys it with di∫may. -- Return, he dare not -- for he knows what a variety of terrors he has already pa∫∫ed. -- Yet if his foot ∫lip, or the plank, on which he re∫ts, give way; he will find his death, and his grave together; and never more be heard of.
But here we had not even the miniature of the∫e dreadful ideas, at lea∫t on the ∫ide of the lake: for in the ∫teepe∫t part, we were ∫carce rai∫ed thirty of forty feet above the water.

As we edged the precipices, we every where ∫aw fragments of rock, and large ∫tones ∫cattered about, which being loo∫ened by fro∫tsw and rains, had fallen from the cliffs above; and ∫hew the traveller what dangers he has e∫caped.

Once we found our∫elves in hands more capricious than the elements. We rode along the edge of a precipice, under a ∫teep woody rock; when ∫ome large ∫tones came rolling from the top, and ru∫hing through the thickets above us, bounded acro∫s the road, and plunged into the lake. At that in∫tant we had made a pau∫e to ob∫erve ∫ome part of the ∫cenery; and by half a dozen yards e∫caped mi∫chief. The wind was loud, and we conceived the ∫tones had been di∫lodged by it's violence: but on riding a little further, we di∫covered the real cau∫e. High above our heads, at the ∫ummit of the cliff, ∫at a group of mountaineer children, amu∫ing them∫elves with pu∫hing ∫tones from the top; and watching, as they plunged into the lake. -- Of us they knew nothing, who were ∫creened from them by intervening thickets.

As we approached the head of the lake, we were de∫ired to turn round, and take a view of Ca∫tellet, that rocky hill, which had appeared ∫o enormous, as we ∫tood under it. It had now ∫hrunk into nothing in the mid∫t of that ∫cene of greatne∫s, which ∫urrounded it. I mention this circum∫tance, as in the∫e wild countries, compari∫on is the only ∫cale u∫ed in the men∫uration of mountains. At lea∫t it was the only ∫cale to which we were ever referred. In countries graced by a ∫ingle mountain, the inhabitants may be very accurate in their inve∫tigations of it's height. The altitude and circumference of the Wrekin, I have no doubt, is accurately known in Shrop∫hire; but in a country like this, where chain is linked to chain exactne∫s would be endle∫s.
By this time we approached the head of the lake; and could now di∫tingui∫h the full ∫ound of the fall of Lodoar; which had before reached our ears, as the wind ∫uffered, indi∫tinctly in broken notes.

This water-fall is a noble object, both in it∫elf, and as an ornament of the lake. It appears more as an object connected with the lake, as we approach by water. By land, we ∫ee it over a promontory of low ground, which, in ∫ome degree, hides it's grandeur. At the di∫tance of a mile, it begins to appear with dignity.

But of whatever advantage the fall of Lodoar may be as a piece of di∫tant ∫cenery, it's effect is very noble, when examined on the ∫pot. As a ∫ingle object, it wants non accompaniments of off∫kip; which would rather injure, than a∫∫i∫t it. They would di∫turb it's ∫implicity, and repo∫e. The greatne∫s of it's parts affords ∫cenery enough. Some in∫truments plea∫e in concert: others you wi∫h to hear alone.

The ∫tream falls through a cha∫m between two towering perpendicular rocks. The intermediate part, broken into large fragments, forms the rough bed of the ca∫cade. Some of the∫e fragments ∫tretching out in ∫helves, hold a depth of ∫oil ∫ufficient for large trees. Among the∫e broken rocks the ∫tream finds it's way through a fall of at lea∫t an hundred feet; and in heavy rains, the water is every way ∫uited to the grandeur of the ∫cene. Rocks and
water in oppo∫ition can hardly produce a more animated ∫trife. The ground at the bottom al∫o is very much broken, and overgrown with trees, and thickets; among∫t which the water is ∫wallowed up into an aby∫s; and at length finds it's way, through deep channels, into the lake. We di∫mounted, and got as near as we could: but were not able to approach ∫o near, as to look into the woody cha∫m, which receives the fall.

Having viewed this grand piece of natural ruin, we proceeded in our rout towards the mountains of Borrodale; and ∫haping our cour∫e along the ∫outhern ∫hores of the lake, we came to the river Derwent, which is a little to the we∫t of the Lodoar.

The∫e two rivers, the Lodoar, and the Derwent, furni∫h the chief ∫upplies of Derwentwater. But tho∫e of the latter are much ampler. The Lodoar accordingly is lo∫t in the lake: while the Derwent, fir∫t giving it's name to it, retains it's own to the ∫ea.

On pa∫∫ing this river, and turning the fir∫t great promontory on our left, we found our∫elves in a va∫t rece∫s of mountains. We had ∫een them at a di∫tance, from the northern extremity of the lake. They were more than objects of grandeur. But now they had a∫∫umed their full maje∫tic form; ∫urrounding us on every ∫ide with their lofty barriers; and ∫hutting out, in appearance, every idea of an e∫cape. Wild and various beyond conception were their ∫hapes: but they participated rather of the de∫olate, than of the fanta∫tic idea. From the bottom of the lake indeed they formed too great a combination of pointed ∫ummits. But here all the∫e grote∫que ∫hapes di∫appeared. The ∫ummits receded far behind; and we only ∫aw the bur∫ting rocks, and bold protuberances, with which the ∫ides of the∫e enormous ma∫∫es of ∫olid earth are charged. Many of them are covered, like the ∫teeps of Helvellin, with a continued pavement of craggs.

The winding of the Derwent was the clue we followed in our pa∫∫age through the∫e regions of de∫olation. An aperture between the
mountains brought us into another wild rece∫s, where a ∫imilar ∫cene opened; diver∫ified from the fir∫t only by ∫ome new forms, or new po∫ition, or varied furniture, of the incumbent mountains.

As we doubled one promontory, another unfolded; and we found our∫elves, not in, what appeared at firt, a rece∫s of moutnains; but in a narrow, winding valley; the ∫cenes of which, by quick tran∫itions, were continually ∫hifting. This valley ∫o replete with hideous grandeur, is known by the name of the ∫traits of Borrodale.

In the middle of one of the rece∫∫es of the valley lies an enormous ∫tone; which is called in the country Boother-∫tone. Ma∫∫y rocks of immen∫e ∫ize, rent from mountains, are every where found: but this ∫tone appears to be of a different kind. It does not ∫eem to have been the appendage of a mountain; but it∫elf an independent creation. It lies in a ∫ort od diagonal po∫ition; over∫hadowing a ∫pace, ∫ufficient to ∫helter a troop of hor∫e.

Not far from hence ari∫es a woody hill, called Ca∫tell-cragg; which is al∫o detached from the ∫cenery around it. On the ∫ummit of this hill, ∫tood formerly a fortre∫s, ∫uppo∫ed to be of Roman origin; intended to guard this avenue into the country. After it had been relinqui∫hed by the Romans, it was occupied by the Saxons; and, after their day, it was given, with all the lands about Borrodale, by one of the lords of Derwent-water, to the monks of Furne∫s. By the∫e religious it was ∫till maintained in it's military capacity; which is perhaps a ∫ingular in∫tance of the kind. But as the Scots, in tho∫e days, made frequent irruptions even thus far into the country; and as the monks had great po∫∫e∫∫ions to defend in the valley of Borrodale; where one of their principal magazines was e∫tabli∫hed; the holy fathers thought it proper to adopt this uncommon mea∫ure. Be∫ides their tythe-corn, they ama∫∫ed here the valuable minerals of the country; among which, ∫alt, produced from a ∫pring in the valley, was no incon∫iderable article.

We had now travelled three of four miles in this winding valley; which, as we advanced, began to a∫∫ume a ∫ofter form. The hills became cloathed with verdure; and the little rece∫∫es of the valley, ∫haded with wood. The∫e rece∫∫es al∫o, which were before ∫hut up, and confined by rocky barriers, now opened in different ∫hapes; and many of them were plea∫antly varied with wooded hillocs: while the ∫tony banks of the Derwent, began to change into meadows; ∫canty indeed; but affording pa∫turage for a few cattle; and a plea∫ant tint of verdure, as a contra∫t with the rocky ∫cenery in it's neighbourhood.

We were now in that part of the valley, which is properly called the valley of Borrodale -- a large, circular rece∫s, con∫i∫ting of much broken ground; and, except where the valley ∫till pur∫ues it's cour∫e, ∫urrounded by lofty mountains; from which pour innumerable rills and torrents, tho little intere∫ting in the ∫cene, as objects of picture∫que beauty.
In this deep retreat lies the village of Ro∫thwait; having at all times, little intercour∫e with the country; but during half the year, almo∫t totally excluded from all human commerce.
Here the ∫ons, and daughters of ∫implicity enjoy health, peace, and contentment, in the mid∫t of what city-luxury would call the extreme of human nece∫∫ity;

poem.line: Stealing their whole dominion from the wa∫te;
Repelling winter-bla∫ts with mud and ∫traw.

chap.p: Their ∫canty patches of arable land, and the∫e cultivated with difficulty; and their crops late-ripening, and often a prey to autumnal rains, which are violent in this country, ju∫t give them bread to eat. Their herds afford them milk; and their flocks, cloaths; the ∫hepherd him∫elf being often the manufacturer al∫o. No dye is nece∫∫ary to tinge their wool: it is naturally a ru∫∫et-brown; and ∫heep and ∫hepherds are cloathed alike; both in the ∫imple livery of nature.

The procuring of fuel is among their greate∫t hard∫hips. In mo∫t parts of the world
this article is ∫ought either in pits, or on the ∫urface of the earth. Here the inhabitants are obliged to get it on the tops of mountains; which abounding with mo∫∫y grounds, ∫eldom found in the vallies below, ∫upply them with peat. The difficulty lies in conveying it from ∫uch immen∫e heights. In doing this they have recour∫e to a ∫trange, and dangerous expedient; tho ∫imilar to the modes of conveyance, which nece∫∫ity dictates in other mountainous countries. They make their peat into bundles, and fa∫ten it upon ∫ledges; on each of which a man ∫its, and guides the machine with his foot down the precipice. We ∫aw many tracks along the ∫ides of mountains, made by the∫e ∫ledges; ∫everal of which were four of five hundred feet high, and appeared from the bottom almo∫t perpendicular.

After a long and fatiguing morning we refre∫hed our∫elves at the village of Ro∫thwait on eggs, and mils; and they who cannot be ∫atisfied with ∫uch a meal in a mountainous country, mu∫t carry their larder with them.

chap.title: Volume 1, Section XIV.
chap.head: SECT. XIV.
chap.p: FROM Ro∫thwait the valley pur∫ues it's cour∫e towards the ea∫t; and lo∫ing again it's milder features, grows every ∫tep more wild, and de∫olate. After a march of two miles farther, we came to the village of Satterthwait, ∫till more intrenched in mountains, than Ro∫thwait it∫elf. Here, in the depth of winter, the ∫un never ∫hines. As the ∫pring advances, his rays begin to ∫hoot over the ∫outhern mountains; and at high noon to tip the chimney tops of the village. That radiant ∫ign ∫hews the cheerle∫s winter to be now over; and rou∫es the hardy pea∫ant to the labours of the coming year.

A little beyond this ∫cene of de∫olation, the Derwent, on who∫e banks we ∫till continued, ru∫hes down a long declivity between two
mountains. At the fall of Lodoar the higher level comes abruptly upon the lower: here, the two levels are united by a gradual de∫cent. The ∫treams of cour∫e taking the ∫ame modes of precipitations as the land, the Lodoar forms a perpendicular fall; and the Derwent, a declivous one. But the fall of the Derwent is more ∫ingular; and is the only one of the kind perhaps in the country.

And here I cannot help remarking the ∫ingular character of this mountain-∫tream. There is not perhaps a river in England, which pa∫∫es through ∫uch a variety of different ∫cenes. What wild, romantic channel it ∫hapes, before it enter the vale of Borrodale, is to us unknown. There fir∫t we commenced our acquaintance with it. It's pa∫∫age through that mountain-cha∫m, is marked with objects, not only great in them∫elves; but rarely to be found el∫ewhere in ∫uch intere∫ting combinations.
From a mountain-∫tream it ∫oon a∫∫umes a new character, and changes into a lake; where it di∫plays the wonders, we have ju∫t ∫een.

From hence emerging, it again becomes a river: but ∫oon forms the lake of Ba∫∫enthwait;
of form, and dimen∫ions very different from that of Ke∫wick.

Contracting it∫elf again into a river, it puts on a character intirely new. Hitherto it has adorned only the wild, rough ∫cenes of nature. All the∫e it now relinqui∫hes -- rocks -- lakes -- and mountains; and enters a ∫weet delightful country, where all it's accompaniments are ∫oft, and lovely. Among other places it vi∫its the noble, and picture∫que ruins of Cockermouth-ca∫tle; under the walls of which it glides.

From hence it pa∫∫es to the ∫ea, which many ∫treams of greater con∫equence never meet under their own names; but are ab∫orbed by larger rivers: while the Derwent, after all the a∫tonishing ∫cenes it has adorned, adds to it's other beauties, tho∫e of an e∫tuary.

In this la∫t part of it's cour∫e it vi∫its Workington-hall, one of the grande∫t and mo∫t beautiful ∫ituations of the country. Be∫ides it's hanging woods, and ∫loping lawns, it is remarkable for having been the fir∫t pri∫on-hou∫e of the unfortunate Mary of Scotland, after ∫he had landed within the dominions of her rival. Here the Derwent becomes navigable; and forms the be∫t natural harbour in Cumberland.

I have often thought, that if a per∫on wi∫hed particularly to amu∫e him∫elf with picture∫que ∫cenes, the be∫t method he could take, would be to placed before him a good map of England; and to ∫ettle in his head the cour∫e of all the chief rivers of the country. The∫e rivers ∫hould be the great directing lines of his excur∫ions. On their banks he would be ∫ure, not only to find the mo∫t beautiful views; but would al∫o obtain a compleat ∫y∫tem of every kind of land∫cape. He would have no occa∫ion to keep ∫o clo∫e to the river he pur∫ued, as not to deviate a little, for the ∫ake of a beautiful ∫cene. Ca∫tles, and abbeys this plan would almo∫t univer∫ally comprehend; for mo∫t of them are ∫eated either on rocks, or knolls projecting into rivers; or in ∫ome ∫weet valley which opens to them. Bridges of cour∫e it would include; which make a plea∫ing ∫pecies of ∫cenery. Mountains, and lakes I need not mention: the former produce rivers; and the latter are produced by them. It would al∫o include ∫ea-coa∫t views; many of which are very intere∫ting, when the e∫tuary opens to
∫ome beautiful, winding ∫hore, with views of di∫tant country.

I once attempted to analyze the Thames in this way. But I was obliged to divide ∫o magnificent a ∫ubject. Indeed it naturally divided it∫elf into three parts -- from Oxford to Wind∫or -- from Wind∫or to London -- from London to the ∫ea. An imperial river, like the Thames, mu∫t be navigated; at lea∫t it's two lower divi∫ions: but inferior rivers are be∫t examined by an excur∫ion along their banks.

We left the Derwent in it's declivious cour∫e between two mountains. One of them, under who∫e ∫hadow the torrent pours, is called Eagle's-cragg; as it's tremendous rocks are the chief habitation of the∫e birds; and ∫eem to be con∫idered by them as a ∫ort of ca∫tle, which from time immemorial they have po∫∫e∫∫ed. It is a common ∫pecies of traffic in this country to ∫upply the curious with young eagles; in the taking of which the inhabitants are very expert. They ob∫erve the ne∫ts from the bottom; and judging of the age of the young birds, they catch the opportunity,
when the old eagles are abroad, and let them∫elves down by ropes from the ∫ummits of the cliffs. We ∫aw one which had been ju∫t taken. It was only ∫ix weeks old; and was nearly of the ∫ize of a turkey-hen. It ∫eemed to have acquired already a full ∫hare of ferocity; and ∫creamed violently, if we offered to touch it.

Many large birds we ∫aw among∫t the∫e mountains, ∫ailing about the air, which we imagine to be eagles: but one of our company, being a naturali∫t, bad us ob∫erve their tail feathers. If their tails were forked, they were of the buzzard ∫pecies: the tail of the eagle is circular.

Among the anecdotes we heard in this country of eagles, one was rather curious -- An eagle was ∫een at a di∫tance, to pounce on it's prey; which it carried, in a perpendicular a∫cent, aloft into the air; and hanging dubious for ∫ome time, it was at length ob∫erved to de∫cend in the ∫ame direct line; and it's fall, as it approached, ∫eemed attended with an odd, tumbling motion. The cau∫e was ∫oon di∫covered. It fell ∫tone dead on the ground; and a wea∫el, which it had carried up, and which had had the addre∫s to
kill it's adver∫ary in the air, being now at liberty, ran away.
We had accompanied the valley of Borrodale as far to the ea∫t, as Eagle's-cragg. It ∫tretches al∫o to the we∫t; tho in a more broken, and abrupt form.

Somewhat further, on this ∫ide, than Eagle's cragg lies on the other, ri∫e tho∫e mountains, where the celebrated black-lead mine is wrought. I could not help feeling a friendly attachment to this place, which every lover of the pencil mu∫t feel, as deriving from this mineral one of the be∫t in∫truments of his art; the free∫t and readie∫t expo∫itor of his ideas. We ∫aw the ∫ite of the mine at a di∫tance, marked with a dingy yellow ∫tain, from the ochery mixtures thrown from it's mouth, which ∫hiver down the ∫ides of the mountain.

During the periodical ∫ea∫on of working it, for it is opened only once in ∫even years, many people pick up a comfortable ∫ub∫i∫tence from the ∫craps of black-lead, which e∫cape among∫t the coar∫er ∫trata. The∫e are hone∫t gains. But a late prolific genius in fraud took a very indirect method of po∫∫e∫∫ing a
∫hare of this rich mineral. A part of the mountain, contiguous to the mine, was his property. Here, at the expence of great labour, he ∫ank a ∫haft, which he carried diagonally, till he entered the mine; where, with ∫ubterraneous wickedne∫s, he continued his depredations for ∫ome time undi∫covered. At length his fraud was brought to light; and he was tried at Carli∫le. The peculiarity of his ca∫e had no precedent. He ∫aved his life; but a law was obtained by the proprietors of the mine, to defend their property from ∫uch indirect attacks for the future.

The ∫un was now declining, and it was too late to take a nearer view of the mine: nor indeed did it promi∫e more on the ∫pot, than it di∫covered at a di∫tance. Be∫ides, the beauties of Watenlath had been ∫o ∫trongly repre∫ented to us; that we were re∫olved to go in que∫t of tho∫e ∫cenes, in preference to any other.

Watenlath is that tract of mountainous country (it∫elf ∫urrounded by mountains ∫till higher) which coming boldly forward, breaks down abruptly from the ∫outh, upon the vale
of Ke∫wick. The ∫tream, which forms the fall of Lodoar, adorns fir∫t the ∫cenes of Watenlath.
"Which way to Watenlath?" ∫aid ones of our company to a pea∫ant, as we left the vale of Borrodale. "That way," ∫aid he, pointing up a lofty mountain, ∫teeper than the tiling of a hou∫e.

To tho∫e, who are accu∫tomed to mountains, the∫e perpendicular motions may be amu∫ing: but to us, who∫e ideas were le∫s elevated, they ∫eemed rather peculiar. And yet there is ∫omething unmanly in conceiving a difficulty in traver∫ing a path, which, we were told, the women of the country would a∫cend on hor∫eback, with their panniers of eggs, and butter, and return in the night. To move upwards, keeping a ∫teady eye on the objects before us, was no great exerci∫e to the brain: but it rather gave it a rotation to look back on what was pa∫t -- an to ∫ee our companions below clinging, as it appeared, to the mountain's ∫ide; and the ri∫ing brea∫ts and bellies of their hor∫es, ∫training up a path ∫o ∫teep, that it ∫eemed, as if the lea∫t fal∫e ∫tep would have carried them rolling many hundred yards to the bottom.

We had another apprehen∫ion; that of mi∫taking our way. If a mi∫t had ∫uddenly over∫pread the mountain, which is a very common incident, we might have wandered all night: for we had not the precaution to take a guide. The que∫tion we a∫ked of the pea∫ant, at the bottom of the mountain; "Which way to Watenlath?" we found was a very improper one. We ∫hould have a∫ked, in what direction we were to ∫eek it? For way there was none; except here and there a blind path; which being it∫elf often bewildered, of cour∫e, ∫erved only to bewilder us. The inhabitants pay little attention to paths: they ∫teer along the∫e wilds by landmarks, which to us were unknown.

At length however, after a painful perpendicular march of near two miles, and many a breathing pau∫e, which our hor∫es required, we gained the top. Here we expected at lea∫t to be rewarded by an amu∫ing pro∫pect over the neighbouring country. But in this too we were di∫appointed. We found our∫elves in the mid∫t of a bog, with ∫till higher grounds around us: ∫o that after all our toil, we had a view only of a vile circum∫cribed wa∫te.

It was our bu∫ine∫s now to get out of this unplea∫ant ∫cene, as ∫oon as we could, which was a matter of no great difficulty. An ea∫y, and ∫hort de∫cent, on the other ∫ide of the mountain, brought us quickly to Watenlath. Here our labours were amply rewarded. We fell into a piece of ∫cenery, which for beauty, and grandeur, was equal, if not ∫uperior, to any thing we had yet ∫een.

The fir∫t object we found was a ∫mall lake, about two miles in circumference, through which flows the Lodoar, and after a cour∫e of three miles farther, forms that noble ca∫cade, which we had ∫een, in the morning, at the head of Derwentwater.
The accompaniments of this river, from the lake of Watenlath to it's fall, make the ∫cenery, of which we came hither in que∫t.

It is a valley ∫o contracted, that it affords room for little more than the river, and a path, at the bottom; while the mountains, on each ∫ide, are ∫o perpendicular, that their ∫ummits are ∫carce more a∫under than their ba∫es. It was a new idea. Many mountains we had ∫een hanging over the ∫ides of vallies:
but to be immured, through a ∫pace of almo∫t three miles, within a cha∫m of rifted rocks, (for that was in fact the idea pre∫ented by the ∫cene before us,) was a novel circum∫tance tho we had now been two or three days the inhabitants of mountains.

The form of this valley was very different from the valley of Borrodale. The one led us through a winding rout: the other is nearly a vi∫ta. Each hath it's mode of grandeur. The valley of Borrodale has more variety: but this is certainly the more maje∫tic ∫cene. The whole is only one va∫t effort. In point of immen∫ity indeed it yields to the vi∫ta at the entrance into Cumberland. It is not ∫o va∫t a whole: but being contracted within a ∫maller compa∫s, we examine it's limits with more ea∫e: and with regard to the grandeur and variety of the ∫everal objects, it lo∫es nothing. As we ∫tood under the beetling cliffs on each ∫ide, they were too near for in∫pection: their har∫h features wanted ∫oftening: but we had noble views of them all in order, both in pro∫pect, and retro∫pect. Not only the de∫ign, and compo∫ition, but the very ∫trokes of nature's pencil might be traced through the whole ∫cene; every fractured rock, and every
hanging ∫hrub, which adorned it, was brought within the compa∫s of the eye: each touch ∫o carele∫s, and yet ∫o determined: ∫o wildly irregular; and yet all conducing to one whole.

When we arrived at the clo∫e of the valley, the grandeur of the ∫cene increa∫ed. It opened into an amphitheatre, the area of which, like the valley, that led to it, was contracted; ∫carce containing the circumference of a mile: but the mountains, which invironed it, were grand and beautiful.

In mo∫t of the ∫cenes we had pa∫∫ed, we were obliged to look for contra∫t in the different modes of de∫olation: but here barrenne∫s was contra∫ted with all the tints of vegetation. The mountains in front, and on the left, were covered with wood, which mantled from the top to the bottom. Tho∫e on the right were barren; yet broken ∫o variou∫ly, as even in them∫elves to make a contra∫t. We admire the ruins of a Roman amphitheatre: but what are the mo∫t magnificent of the works of art, compared with ∫uch an amphitheatre as this? Were the Colo∫∫eum it∫elf brought hither, and placed within this area, the grandeur of the idea would be lo∫t;
and the ruin, magnificent as it is, would dwindle into the ornament of a ∫cene.

At the entrance of the amphitheatre, another bridge mountain-torrent joins the Lodaor from the ea∫t, and forms it into a more con∫iderable ∫tream. With increa∫ed velocity, (the ground growing every ∫tep more declivous) it now pours along with great rapidity; and throwing it∫elf into the thicke∫t of the woods, which clo∫e the ∫cene, di∫appears. The imagination pur∫ues it's progre∫s. It's roar is heard through the woods; and it is plain from the ∫ound, that it ∫uffers ∫ome great convul∫ion. But all is clo∫e; impervious rocks and thickets intervene, and totally exclude the ∫ight.

We indeed had been behind the ∫cenes; and knew we were, at that in∫tant, upon the ∫ummit of the fall of Lodaoar: but the imagination of a ∫tranger would be held in ∫timulating ∫u∫pen∫e. The grandeur of the ∫ound would proclaim the dignity of the fall; and his eye would wi∫h to participate of what his ear alone could inadequately judge.

Tho we had ∫een the fall of Lodoar from the bottom, we had a curio∫ity to ∫ee how
it appeared from the top; and di∫mounting, we contrived, by winding round the thickets, and clinging to the projections of the rocks, to get a dangerous peep down the aby∫s. There was nothing picture∫que in the view, but ∫omething immen∫ely grand. We ∫tood now above tho∫e two cheeks of the cha∫m, through which the water forced it's way; and which in the morning, when ∫een from the bottom, appeared towering to a great height, and were the mo∫t intere∫ting parts of the view. But amid∫t the greatne∫s of the objects, which now ∫urrounded them they were totally lo∫t; appearing le∫s than warts upon tho∫e va∫t limbs of nature, to which they adhered.

In our pa∫∫age through the valley of Watenlath, we met with many fragments of rocks, in which the ∫everal component ∫trata were very ∫trongly marked. In ∫ome they could not have been more regularly formed by a rule and chi∫∫el: and in a few, (who∫e ∫ofter lamina the weather had decayed,) as perfect cornices remained, as art could have produced.

Having taken a view of all this ∫cenery, and the evening beginning now to clo∫e, we thought it time to put a ∫top to our curio∫ity, and return to Ke∫wick; from which we were about four miles di∫tant. In the morning we rode along the edge of the lake: but as we were now upon the higher grounds, we were obliged to make a compa∫s round the mountains.

The∫e de∫olate grounds are very little inhabited. We heard of a de∫ign to introduce goats among them, with a view to make Ke∫wick as celebrated for drinking goat's-whey, as ∫everal of the mountainous parts of Scotland. In ∫ome places indeed, where there are valuable woods, the goat might be a pernicious inmate. But in many places, as we rode, the bare and craggy ∫ides of hills ∫eemed capable of feeding nothing el∫e. Frequent little plots of herbage grow every where among the rocks, inaccessible to any other animal. Even ∫heep on many of the∫e ∫loping ∫helves could find no footing. All this pa∫turage
therefore is lo∫t for want of goats to brouze it.

In a picture∫que light, no ornament is more adapted to a mountainous, and rocky country, than the∫e animals. Their colours are beautiful, (in tho∫e particularly of a darker hue) often playing into each other with great harmony. But among the∫e animals, (as among all others) the pied are the mo∫t unplea∫ing; in which oppo∫ite colour come full upon each other, without any intervening tint.
The ∫haggine∫s of the goat al∫o is as beautiful, as the colours, which adorn him; his hair depending in that ea∫y flow, which the pencil wi∫hes to imitate.

His actions are ∫till more plea∫ing. It would add new terror to a ∫cene, to ∫ee an animal brouzing on the ∫teep of a perpendicular rock; or hanging on the very edge of a projecting precipice. Virgil ∫eems to have looked at the∫e attitudes of terror with delight:

poem.line: ---- Ite, capellæ
Non ego vos po∫thac, viridi projectus in antro.
Dumosa pendere procul de rupe videbo.

chap.title: Volume 1, Section XV.
chap.head: SECT. XV.
chap.p: IN our rout to Borrodale, we pa∫∫ed through the ea∫tern, and ∫outhern parts of that mountainous country, which bounds the lake of Derwent: -- in our next expedition we propo∫ed to view the we∫tern.

From Ke∫wick we mounted the hills on the north-we∫t of the lake; and, on the other ∫ide, fell into the valley of Newlands, which we traver∫ed from end to end. It was a lovely ∫cene, totally different from the rude vallies we had yet met with. The mountains, in general, on this ∫ide of the lake wear a ∫moother form, than tho∫e either in the ea∫t, or on the ∫outh. Of this ∫moothne∫s of feature in the higher grounds the lower participate. The mountain vallies we had hitherto ∫een, were wild, rocky, and de∫olate. But here
the idea of terror was excluded. The valley of Newlands was even adorned with beauties of luxuriant nature. We travelled through groves, which were ∫ometimes open, and ∫ometimes clo∫e; with a ∫parkling ∫tream, the common attendant of the∫e vallies, accompanying us, through the whole ∫cene.

Having been amu∫ed with this ∫weet ∫cenery about three miles, we entered another valley, or rather a mountain rece∫s, called the valley of Ga∫cadale. I call it a rece∫s, becau∫e it is ∫oon terminated by a mountain running athwart, which denies any further pa∫∫age. In∫tead therefore of entering Ga∫cadale, we were obliged to climb the hill, which forms one of it's ∫ides: and from the ∫ummit, we had a view not only of Ga∫cadale, but of many other mountain rece∫∫es, all which participate more or le∫s, of the ∫moothne∫s of the high grounds in their neighbourhood. Some of them were ∫cooped, and hollowed into very beautiful forms; in which woods alone was wanting.

The valley of Ga∫cadale had nothing to recommend it, but novelty. It was (a ∫cene
wholly new in this rugged country) a deep mountain rece∫s, invironed on every ∫ide, except the entrance, by ∫mooth, ∫loping hills, which are adorned neither with wood, nor rock, nor broken ground; but ∫weep down from ∫ide to ∫ide, with the greate∫t regularity. We ∫carce remembered to have ∫een in any place, an operation of nature more completely formal. At the head of this rece∫s is a grand ca∫cade. We ∫uppo∫ed it to be no great object of beauty, as it was probably void of all accompaniments: but it's poverty hid beneath a veil. The clouds which were gathering upon the mountains, and ∫weeping along the vallies, began to intercept our view. Every thing was wrapped in ob∫curity. When we ∫tood even on the ∫ummit of the ca∫cade, we could only hear the torrent roar; but could not obtain the lea∫t glimp∫e of it, tho no object intervened. The whole valley of Ga∫cadale ∫moaked like a boiling caldron; and we got our ideas of it only by catches, as the volumes of clouds di∫per∫ed, at intervals, into purer air.

But what we lo∫t in one re∫pect by the gro∫∫ne∫s of the atmo∫phere, we gained in another. Tho it is probable ∫ome views were
ob∫cured, which might have plea∫ed us; it is equally probable, that many of tho∫e di∫gu∫ting features, with which we might have been pre∫ented, were ∫oftened, and rendered more agreeable to the eye. -- Here indeed the mi∫ty hue was, in general, laid on with too full a pencil. The face of nature was rather blotted out, than ob∫cured. The whole view was in that ∫tate, which Thom∫on ∫o well de∫cribes:

poem.line: ---- No more the mountain fills the eye
With great variety; but in a night
Of gathering vapour, from the baffled ∫en∫e,
Sinks dark and dreary. Thence expanding wide
The huge du∫k gradual, ∫wallows up the plain.
Vani∫h the woods. The dim ∫een river ∫eems
Sullen and ∫low to rowl the mi∫ty wave.

chap.p: Among the beautiful appearances of fogs, and mi∫ts, their gradually going off may be ob∫erved. A land∫cape takes a variety of plea∫ing hues, as it pa∫∫es, in a retiring fog, through the different modes of ob∫curity into full ∫plendor.

There is great beauty al∫o in a fog's partially clearing up at once, as it often does; and pre∫enting ∫ome di∫tant piece of land∫cape under great radiance; when all the ∫urrounding parts are ∫till in ob∫curity. The curtain is not intirely drawn up; it is only ju∫t rai∫ed, to let in ∫ome beautiful, tran∫ient view; and perhaps falling again, while we admire, leaves us that ardent reli∫h, which we have for plea∫ing objects ∫uddenly removed. -- Some very beautiful ideas of this kind were di∫played on the ∫ummits of Ga∫cadale. Tho the mountains around us, and the contracted vallies in our neighbourhood, were all ∫o much ab∫orbed in the dark atmo∫phere of clouds and vapours; we could di∫cover, in catches, through their thinner ∫kirts, the vale of Ke∫wick, at a di∫tance, over∫pread with ∫erenity and ∫un-∫hine.

The mountain, over which we pa∫∫ed, is called, in the language of the country, a haw∫e, or ∫toppage, in pa∫∫in from one di∫trict to another; the valley being clo∫ed, and no other way left. This haw∫e, tho not ∫o ∫teep as the mountain, which led us to Watenlath,
was of much longer continuance; and in ∫ome parts carried us very near the edges of precipices: but ∫urrounded by fogs, we kept the path before us; and if there was danger, we ∫eldom ∫aw it.

As we began to de∫cend, we breather a purer air; and got a ∫ight of the land∫cape before us. It was a ∫cene, unlike what we had ju∫t pa∫∫ed; but only, as the botani∫t ∫peaks, a variety of the ∫ame genus; corre∫ponding intirely with the character of the country, which we now traver∫ed. Three broad mountains, ∫loping into each other, formed a tripartite valley, centering in one point. The ∫urface of each mountain was ∫mooth to it's very ∫ummit; except that, here and there, a few large ∫tones lay ∫cattered about: ∫ome of them fixed in the ∫oil; but none of them de∫erving the appellation of a rock. Through two of the divi∫ions of this valley ran different ∫treams; each of them as unfringed, and ∫imple, as the mountains they ∫evered. The∫e ∫treams uniting in the centre, formed a third. The whole was a peculiar and novel ∫cene; but neither intere∫ting, nor picture∫que.
The∫e ∫mooth-coated mountains, tho of little e∫timation in the painter's eye, are however great ∫ources of plenty. They are the nur∫eries of ∫heep; which are bred here, and fatted in the vallies.

But the life of a ∫hepherd, in this country, is not an Arcadian life. His occupation ∫ubjects him to many difficulties, in the winter e∫pecially, when he is often obliged to attend his flock on the bleak ∫ide of a mountain, which engages him in many a painful vigil. An when the mountains are covered with ∫now, which is frequently the ca∫e, his employment becomes then a dangerous one. It ∫eldom happens, but that ∫ome part of his flock is ∫nowed up; and pre∫erving their lives, he mu∫t often expo∫e his own.

After winding about two miles along the edge of one of the∫e mountains, we dropped at once into a beautiful vale, called the vale of Butermer, the bottom of which was adorned by a lake of the ∫ame name.

This lake is ∫mall; about a mile and a half in length, and half a mile in breadth; of an oblong form; ∫weeping, at one end, round a woody promontory. But this ∫weep is rather forced; and from ∫ome points makes too acute an angle. It is one of tho∫e lines, which would have a better effect from a boat. A lower point would ∫often it's abruptne∫s. In other parts al∫o the lines of this lake are rather too ∫quare. The ∫cenery however about it is grand, and beautiful.
chap.note: See page 96.
chap.p: On the we∫tern ∫ide, a long range of mountainous declivity extends from end to end; falling every where precipitately into the water, at lea∫t it had that appearance to the eye: tho on the ∫pot probably a margin of meadow might ∫hoot from the bottom of the mountain, as we ob∫erved at Ke∫wick. Of the line, which the ∫ummit of this mountain formed, we could not ea∫ily judge; as it was in a great mea∫ure hid in clouds.

The ea∫tern ∫ide of the lake is woody; and contra∫ts happily with the we∫tern. But the wood is of that kind, which is periodically
cut down, and was not in perfection, when we ∫aw it.

Near the bottom of this lake, is the loftie∫t ca∫cade we had ever ∫een. It hardly, I think, falls through a le∫s de∫cent than three or four hundred yards. But it is an object of no beauty; it is barren of accompaniments; and appears, at a di∫tance, like a white ribbon bi∫ecting the mountain. The people of the country, alluding to the whitene∫s of it's foam, call it ∫our-milk-force.

The vale of Butermer is rather confined in that part, which the lake occupies. Below, it extends a con∫iderable way: but our rout led us fir∫t above, in que∫t of ∫ome rocky mountains, which are ∫uppo∫ed to be the highe∫t precipices in the country. The∫e ∫cenes, which are known by the name of Gate∫garth-dale, open at the head of the lake.
Here we found two vallies, formed by a mountain on each ∫ide, and one in the middle. The right hand valley was ∫oon clo∫ed by a haw∫e: that on the left led directly to the ∫cenes we ∫ought.

The tran∫ition here, contrary to the u∫ual proce∫s of nature, is abrupt. We had been travelling, all the morning, among mountains
perfectly ∫mooth, and covered with herbage; and now found our∫elves ∫uddenly among craggs and rocks, and precipices, as wild, and hideous, as any we had ∫een.

Gate∫garth-dale, into which we ∫oon entered, is indeed a very tremendous ∫cene. Like all the vallies we had yet found, it had a peculiar character. It's features were it's own. It was not a vi∫ta like the valley of Watenlath; nor had it any of the ∫udden turns of the valley of Borrodale: but would ∫lowly, and ∫olemnly in one large segment. It was a wider al∫o than either of tho∫e vallies; being at lea∫t half a quarter of a miles from ∫ide to ∫ide; which di∫tance it pretty uniformly ob∫erved; the rocky mountains, which invironed it, keeping their line with great exactne∫s; at lea∫t, never breaking out into any violent projections.

The area of this valley is, in general, concave; the ∫ides almo∫t perpendicular, compo∫ed of a kind of broken craggy rock, the ruins of which every where ∫trew the valley; and five it ∫till more the idea of de∫olation.

The river al∫o, which runs through it, and is the principal ∫upply of the lake, is as wild as the valley it∫elf. It has no banks, but the fragments of rocks; no bed, but a channel compo∫ed of rocky ∫trata, among which the water forces it's cour∫e. It's channel, as well as it's bank, is formed of loo∫e ∫tones, and fragments, which break, and divide the ∫tream into a ∫ucce∫∫ion of wild, impetuous eddies.

A ∫tream , which is the natural ∫ource of plenty, is perhaps when unaccompanied with verdure, the ∫tronge∫t emblem of de∫olations. It ∫hews the ∫pot to be ∫o barren, that even the greate∫t ∫ource of abundance can produce nothing. The whole valley indeed joined in impre∫∫ing the ∫ame idea. Fruitful nature, making in every part of her ample range, unremitting efforts to vegetate, could not here produce a ∫ingle germin.

As we proceeded, the grandeur of the valley increa∫ed. We had been prepared indeed to ∫ee the highe∫t precipices, which the country produced. Such a preface is generally productive of di∫appointment; but on this occa∫ion it did no injury. The fancy had ∫till it's ∫cope. We found the mountains ∫o over-hung with
clouds, that we could form little judgment of their height. Our guide told us, they were twice as high, as we could ∫ee: which however we did not believe from the ob∫ervations we were able to make, as the clouds, at intervals, floated pa∫t; and di∫covered, here and there, the ∫hadowy forms of the rocky ∫ummits. A great height however they certaily were; and the darkne∫s, in which they were wrapped, gave us a new illu∫tration of the grandeur of tho∫e ideas, which ari∫e from ob∫curity. "Dark, confu∫ed, uncertain images, Mr. Burk very ju∫tly ob∫erves, have a greater power on the fancy to form the grander pa∫∫ions, than tho∫e, which are more clear, and determinate. For hardly any thing can ∫trike the mind with it's greatne∫s, which does not make ∫ome ∫ort of approach towards infinity; which nothing can do, whil∫t we are able to perceive it's bounds, is one, and the ∫ame thing. A clear idea therefore is another name for a little idea."
chap.note: On the ∫ublime, and beautiful. Part II. Sect. IV.
chap.p: The middles of the valley is adorned, as the∫e vallies, in ∫ome part, often are, by a craggy hill; on the top of which ∫tands the fragment of a rock; that looks, in O∫∫ian's language, like the ∫tone of power -- the rude deity of de∫olation, to which the ∫cene is ∫acred.
This valley is not more than ∫ix miles from the black-lead mines; and would have led us to them, if we had pur∫ued it's cour∫e.

Having travelled about three miles in this dreary ∫cene; and having take ∫uch a view, as we could obtain, of the bold inclo∫ures, which contained it; we returned by the ∫ame rout we came, threading the valley, and ∫kirting the lake along it's ea∫tern coa∫t, till we arrived at the bottom of it. Here we fell into a country very different from that we had left.

The vale of Butermer, which extends many miles below the lake, is a wide, variegated ∫cene, full of ri∫ing and falling ground; woody
in many parts; well inhabited in ∫ome; fruitful, and luxuriant in all.

Here we found a village, where we made a luxurious repa∫t, as u∫ual, on eggs and milk; and met, in the chearful and health looks of the inhabitants, new proofs of the narrow limits, in which all the real wants of life are comprized.

chap.title: Volume 2, Section XVI.
chap.head: OBSERVATIONS
ON
Several PARTS of ENGLAND,
ESPECIALLY
The LAKES, &c.
SECT. XVI.
chap.p:
HAVING refre∫hed our∫elves, and our hor∫es, after a fatiguing morning, we proceeded along the vale of Butermer; and following the cour∫e of the river, as far as the inequalities of the ground would admit, we ∫oon came to another lake, ∫till more beautiful, than that we had left above. The two lakes bear a great re∫emblance to each other. Both are oblong: both wind
round promontories; and both are ∫urrounded by mountains. But the lower lake is near a mile longer, than the upper; the lines it forms are much ea∫ier; and tho it has le∫s wood on it's banks, the lo∫s is compen∫ated by a richer di∫play of rocky ∫cenery. The forms of the∫e rocks are in general, beautiful; mo∫t of them being broken into a grand ∫quare ∫urfaces. This ∫pecies, as we have already ob∫erved, are in a greater ∫tyle, than the cragg, which is ∫hattered into more diminutive parts.
chap.note: See Page, 108.
chap.p:
With this rocky ∫cenery much hilly ground is intermixed. Patches of meadow al∫o, here and there, on the banks of the lake, improve the variety. Nothing is wanting but a little more wood, to make this lake, and the vale in which it lies, a very inchanting ∫cene: or rather a ∫ucce∫∫ion of inchanting ∫cenes: for the hills and ri∫ing grounds, into which it every where ∫wells, acting in due ∫ubordination to the grand mountains, which inviron the whole vale, break and ∫eparate the area of it into ∫maller parts. Many of the∫e form
them∫elves into little vallies, and other rece∫∫es, which are very picture∫que.

Not far from the lake the mountain of Gra∫mer appears ri∫ing above all the mountains in it's neighbourhood. A lake of this name we had already ∫een in our road between Amble∫ide, and Ke∫wick; but there is no connection between the lake, and the mountain.

This mountain forms rather a va∫t ridge, than a pointed ∫ummit: and is connected with two or three other mountains of inferior dignity: it∫elf is ∫aid to be equal to Skiddaw; which is the common gage of altitude through the whole country; and therefore may be ∫uppo∫ed the highe∫t. No mountain a∫pires to be higher than Skiddaw: ∫ome boa∫t an equal height: but two or three only have real preten∫ions.

Gra∫mer, and the mountains in it's neighbourhood, form the ea∫tern boundary of the vale, which we now traver∫ed; a vale at lea∫t five miles in length, and one third of that ∫pace in breadth. Our road carried us near
the village of Brackenthwait, which lies at the bottom of Gra∫mer.

Here we had an account of an inundatation occa∫ioned by the bur∫ting of a water-∫pout. The particulars, which are well authenticated, are curious. But it will be nece∫∫ary fir∫t to exhibit the geography of the mountain.

In that part, where Gra∫mer is connected with the other high lands in it's neighbourhood, three little ∫treams take their origin; of which the Li∫∫a is the lea∫t incon∫iderable. The cour∫e of this ∫tream down the mountain is very ∫teep, and about a mile in length. It's bed, which is a deep gully, and the ∫ides of the mountain all around, are profu∫ely ∫pread with loo∫e ∫tones, and gravel. On leaving the mountain, the Li∫∫a divides the vale, through which we now pa∫∫ed; and, after a cour∫e of four or five miles, joins the Cocker.
On the 9th of September 1760, about midnight, the water-∫pout fell upon Gra∫mer, nearly, as was conjectured, where the three little ∫treams, ju∫t mentioned, i∫∫ue from their fountains.

At fir∫t it ∫wept the whole ∫ide of the mountain, and charging it∫elf with all the rubbi∫h it found there, made it's way into the vale, following chiefly the direction of the Li∫∫a. At the foot of the mountain it was received by a piece of arable ground; on which it's violence fir∫t broke. Here it tore away trees, ∫oil, and gravel; and laid all bare, many feet in depth, to the naked rock. Over the next ten acres it ∫eems to have made an immen∫e roll; covering them with ∫o va∫t a bed of ∫tones; that no human art can every again re∫tore the ∫oil

When we ∫aw the placed, tho twelve years after the even, many marks remained, ∫till flagrant, of this ∫cene of ruin. We ∫aw the natural bed of the Li∫∫a, a mere contracted rivulet; and on it's banks the ve∫tiges of a ∫tony channel, ∫preading far and wide, almo∫t enough to contain the waters of the Rhine, or the Danube. It was computed from the flood-marks, that in many parts the ∫tream mu∫t have been five or ∫ix yards deep; and near a hundred broad; and if it's great velocity be added to this weight of water, it's moment will be found equal to almo∫t any effect.

On the banks of this ∫tony channel, we ∫aw a few ∫cattered hou∫es, a part of the village of Brackenthwait, which had a wonderful e∫cape. They ∫tood at the bottom of Gra∫mer, rather on a ri∫ing ground; and the current, taking it's fir∫t direction towards them, would have undermined them in a few moments, (for the ∫oil was in∫tantly laid bare) had not a projection of native rock, the interior ∫tratum, on which the hou∫es had unknowingly been founded, re∫i∫ted the current, and given it a new direction. Unle∫s this had intervened, it is probable, the∫e hou∫es, and all the inhabitants of them (∫o in∫tantaneous was the ruin) had been ∫wept away together.

In pa∫∫ing farther along the vale, we ∫aw other marks of the fury of the inundation; where, bridges had been thrown down, hou∫es carried off, and woods rooted up. But it's effects upon a ∫tone-cau∫eway were thought the mo∫t ∫urprizing. This fabric was of great thickne∫s; and ∫upported, on each ∫ide, by an enormous bank of earth.
