The memory of man could trace it, unaltered in any particular, near a hundred years: but by the ∫oundne∫s and firmne∫s of it's parts and texture, it ∫eemed
as if it had ∫tood for ages. It was almo∫t a doubt, whether it were a work of nature, or of art. This ma∫∫y mole the deluge not only carried off; but, as if it turned it into ∫port, made it's very foundations the channel of it's own ∫tream.

Having done all this mi∫chief, not only here, but in many other parts, the Li∫∫a threw all it's waters into the Cocker, where an end was put to it's deva∫tation: for tho the Cocker was unable to contain ∫o immen∫e an increa∫e; yet as it flows through a more level country, the deluge ∫pread far and wide, and wa∫ted it's ∫trength in one va∫t, ∫tagnant inundation.
Having pa∫∫ed through the vale of Butermer, we entered another beautiful ∫cene, the vale of Lorton.

This vale, like all the pa∫t, pre∫ents us with a ∫cene intirely new. No lakes, no rocks are here, to blend the idea of dignity, and grandeur with that of beauty. All is ∫implicity, and repo∫e. Nature, in this ∫cene, lays totally a∫ide her maje∫tic frown, and wears only a lovely ∫mile.

The vale of Lorton is of the extended kind, running a con∫iderable way between mountains, which range at about a mile's di∫tance. They are near enough to ∫creen it from the ∫torm; and yet not ∫o impending as to exclude the ∫un. Their ∫ides, tho not ∫mooth, are not much diver∫ified. A few knolls and hollows ju∫t give a little variety to the broad lights and ∫hades, which over-∫pread them.

This vale, which enjoys a rich ∫oil, is in general a rural, cultivated ∫cene; tho in many parts the ground is beautifully broken, and abrupt. A bright ∫tream, which might almo∫t take the name of a river, pours along a rocky channel; and ∫parkles down numberle∫s little ca∫cades. It's banks are adorned with wood; and varied with different objects; a bridge; a mill; a hamlet; a glade over-hung with wood; or ∫ome little ∫weet rece∫s; or natural vi∫ta, through which the eye ranges, between irregular trees, along the windings of the ∫tream.

Except the mountains, nothing in all this ∫cenery is great; but every part is filled with tho∫e ∫weet engaging pa∫∫ages of nature, which
tend to ∫ooth the mind, and in∫till tranquility.

poem.line: ---- The pa∫∫ions to divine repo∫e
Per∫uaded yield: and love and joy alone
Are waking: love and joy, ∫uch as await
An angel's meditation ----

chap.p: Scenes of this kind, (however plea∫ing) in which few objects occur, either of grandeur or peculiarity, in a ∫ingular manner elude the powers of verbal de∫cription. They almo∫t elude the power of colours. The ∫oft and elegant form of beauty is hard to hit: while the ∫trong, har∫h feature is a mark, which every pencil can ∫trike.
But tho a peculiar difficulty attends the verbal de∫cription of the∫e mild, and quiet haunts of nature; yet undoubtedly all her ∫cenery is ill-attempted in language.

Mountains, rocks, broken ground, water, and wood, are the ∫imple materials, which ∫he employs in all her beautiful pictures: but the variety and harmony, with which ∫he employs them, are infinite. In de∫cription the∫e words ∫tand only for general ideas: on her charts each is detailed into a thou∫and
varied forms. Words may give the great outlines of a ∫cene. They can mea∫ure the dimen∫ions of a lake. They can hang it's ∫ides with wood. They can rear a ca∫tle on ∫ome projecting rock: or place an i∫land near this, or the other ∫hore. But their range extends no farther. They cannot mark the characteri∫tic di∫tinctions of each ∫cene -- the touches of nature -- her living tints -- her endle∫s varieties, both in form and colour. -- In a word, all her elegant peculiarities are beyond their reach. Language is equally unable to convey the∫e to the eye; as the eye is to convey the various divi∫ions of ∫ound to the ear.

The pencil, it is true, offers a more perfect mode of de∫cription. It ∫peaks a language more intelligible; and de∫cribes the ∫cene in ∫tronger, and more varied terms. The ∫hapes, and hues of objects it delineates, and marks, with more exactne∫s. It gives the lake the louring ∫hade of tempe∫t; or the glowing blu∫h of ∫un-∫et. It ∫preads a warmer, or a colder tint on the tufts of the fore∫t. It adds form to the ca∫tle; and tips it's ∫hattered battlements with light. -- But all this, all that words can expre∫s, or even the pencil de∫cribe,
are gro∫s, in∫ipid ∫ub∫titutes of the living ∫cene. We may be plea∫ed with the de∫cription, and the picture: but the ∫oul can feel neither, unle∫s the force of our own imagination aid the poet's, or the painter's art; exalt the idea; and picture things un∫een.

Hence it perhaps follows, that the perfection of the art of painting is not ∫o much attained by an endeavour to form an exact re∫emblance of nature in a nice repre∫entation of all her minute parts, which we con∫ider as almo∫t impracticable, ending generally in flatne∫s, and in∫ipidity; as by aiming to give tho∫e bold, tho∫e ∫trong characteri∫tic touches, which excite the imagination; and lead it to form half the picture, it∫elf. Painting is the art of deceiving; and it's great perfection lies in the exerci∫e of this art.
chap.note: This is not at all incon∫i∫tent with what is ∫aid in the 119th page. Here we ∫peak chiefly of the detail of nature's works: there of the compo∫ition. The nearer we approach the character of nature in every mode of imitation, no doubt the better: yet ∫till there are many irregularities and deformities in the natural ∫cene, which we may wi∫h to correct -- that is, to correct, by improving one part of nature by another.
chap.p:
Hence it is that genius, and knowledge are as requi∫ite in ∫urveying a picture, as in
painting one. The cold, untutored eye, (tho it may enjoy the real ∫cene, (be it hi∫tory, land∫cape, or what it will) is unmoved at the fine∫t repre∫entation. It does not ∫ee an exact re∫emblance of what it ∫ees abroad; and having not internal pencil, if I may ∫o ∫peak, to work within; it is utterly unable to admini∫ter a picture to it∫elf. Whereas the learned eye, ver∫ed equally in nature, and
art, ea∫ily compares the picture with it's archetype: and when it finds the characteristic touches of nature, the imagination immediately takes fire; and glows with a thou∫and beautiful ideas, ∫ugge∫ted only by the canvas. When the canvas therefore is ∫o artificially wrought, as to ∫ugge∫t the∫e ideas in the ∫tronge∫t manner, the picture is then mo∫t perfect. This is generally be∫t done by little
labour, and great knowledge. It is knowledge only, which in∫pires that free, that fearle∫s, and determined pencil, ∫o expre∫∫ive in a ∫kilful hand. As to the minutiæ of nature, the picture∫que eye will generally ∫ugge∫t them better it∫elf; and yet give the arti∫t, as he de∫erves, the credit of the whole.
chap.note: Hi∫tory-painting is certainly the mo∫t elevated ∫pecies. Nothing exalts the human mind ∫o much, as to ∫ee the great actions of our fellow-creatures brought before the eye. But this plea∫ure we ∫eldom find in painting. So ,much is required from the hi∫tory-painter, ∫o intimate a knowledge both of nature and art, that we rarely ∫ee a hi∫tory-piece, even from the be∫t ma∫ters, that is able to rai∫e raptures. We may admire the colouring, or the execution; or ∫ome under-part; but the ∫oul is ∫eldom reached. The imagination ∫oars beyond the picture. In the inferior walks of painting, where le∫s is required, more of cour∫e is performed: and tho we have few good pictures in hi∫tory, we have many in portrait, in land∫cape, in animal-life, dead-game, fruit, and flowers. Hi∫tory painting is a mode of epic; and tho the literary world abounds with admirable production in the lower walks of poetry, an epic is the wonder of an age.

note.p: The admirers of painting may be divided into two cla∫∫es: -- The inferior admirer values him∫elf on di∫tingui∫hing the ma∫ter -- on knowing the peculiar touch of each pencil; and the ruling tint of every pallet. But he has no feeling. If the picture be an original, or if it be in the ma∫ter's be∫t manner (which may be the ca∫e of many a bad picture) it is the object of his veneration; tho the ∫tory be ill-told, the characters feebly marked, and a total deficiency appear in every excellence of the art.

The more liberal profe∫∫or, (and who alone is here con∫idered as capable of admini∫tring a picture to him∫elf) thinks the knowledge of names, (any further than as it marks excellence, till we get a better criterion,) is the bane of the art he admires. A work, worthy of admiration, may be produced by an inferior hand; and a paltry compo∫ition may e∫cape from a ma∫ter. He would have the intrin∫ic merit of a work, not any arbitrary ∫tamp proclaim it's excellence. In examining a picture, he leaves the name entirely out of the que∫tion. It may mi∫lead, it cannot a∫∫i∫t, his judgment. The characters of nature, and the knowledge of art, are all he looks for: the re∫t, be they Guido's, Carrache's, or Raphael's, he de∫pi∫es as the bubbles of picture-dealers; the mere ∫weepings, and refu∫e of Italian garrets.

chap.p: We ∫ometimes indeed ∫ee pictures highly fini∫hed, and yet full of ∫pirit. They will bear a nice examination at hand, and yet lo∫e nothing of their di∫tant effect. But ∫uch pictures are ∫o exceedingly rare, that I ∫hould think, few painters would in prudence attempt a laboured manner. Indeed, as pictures are not de∫igned to be ∫een through a micro∫cope, but at a proper di∫tance, it is labour thrown away.
chap.note: In the higher walks of painting I know of no arti∫t, who does not lo∫e his ∫pirit in attempting to fini∫h highly. In the inferior walks we have a few. Among the fir∫t we may rank Van Huy∫um, who painted flowers, and fruits, with equal labour and ∫pirit. And yet even here, I own I have more plea∫ure in helping my∫elf to the∫e delicacies from the bolder works of Bapti∫te.
chap.p:
Hence it is that even a rough ∫ketch, by the hand of a ma∫ter, will often ∫trike the imagination beyond the mo∫t fini∫hed work.
I have ∫een the learned eye pa∫s unmoved along rows of pictures by the cold, and inanimate pencil of ∫uch a ma∫ter as Carlo Marat; and ∫tart a∫toni∫hed, when it came to a ∫ketch of Rubens. In one ca∫e the painter endeavouring in vain to admini∫ter every thing by giving the full roundne∫s, and ∫moothne∫s to every part, in∫tead of the bold, characteri∫tic touches of nature, had done too much: in the other, tho the work was left unfini∫hed, yet many of the bold characteri∫tic touches being thrown in, enough was done to excite the imagination of the ∫pectator, which could ea∫ily ∫upply the re∫t.

A very ingenious writer indeed gives another rea∫on for our being better plea∫ed with a ∫ketch, than with a fini∫hed piece. The imagination, ∫ays he, is entertained with the promi∫e of ∫omething more; and does not acquie∫ce in the pre∫ent object of the ∫en∫e. But this ob∫ervation, I think is ∫carce founded on truth. It is true the imagination does not acquie∫ce in the pre∫ent object of the ∫en∫e: but, I ∫hould ∫uppo∫e, not becau∫e it is entertained with a promi∫e of ∫omething more; but becau∫e it has the power, of creating ∫omething more it∫elf. If a promi∫e of ∫omething more, were the cau∫e of this plea∫ure, it ∫hould ∫eem, that a ∫ketch, in it's rude∫t form, would be more plea∫ing, than when it is more advanced: for the imagination mu∫t have ∫till higher entertainment in proportion to the largene∫s of the promi∫e. But this is not the ca∫e. The ∫ketch, in it's naked chalk-lines, affects us little in compari∫on. The in∫trument mu∫t be turned higher, to excite vibrations in the imagination.
chap.note: Burke on the ∫ublime and beautiful, Part II. Sect. XI.
chap.p:
Again, on the ∫ame ∫uppo∫ition, one would imagine, that the rude beginning, or rough plan of a hou∫e, would plea∫e us more than the compleat pile; for the imagination is entertained with the promi∫e of ∫omething more. But, I believe, no one was ever ∫o well plea∫ed with an unfini∫hed ∫hell, amid∫t all it's rubbi∫h of ∫caffolding, paper-windows, and other deformities; as with a ∫tructure compleat in all it's members, and ∫et off with all it's proper decorations. -- But on the ∫uppo∫ition I have ventured to ∫ugge∫t, we ∫ee why the ∫ketch may plea∫e beyond the picture; tho the unfini∫hed fabric di∫appoints. An elegant hou∫e is a
compleat object. The imagination can ri∫e no higher. It receives full ∫atisfaction. But a picture is not an object it∫elf; but only the repre∫entation of an object. We may ea∫ily therefore conceive, that it may fall below it's archetype; and al∫o below the imagination of the ∫pectator, who∫e fancy may be more picture∫que, than the hand of the arti∫t, who compo∫ed the picture. In this ca∫e, a ∫ketch may afford the ∫pectator more plea∫ure, as it gives his imagination freer ∫cope; and ∫uffers it to compleat the arti∫t's imperfect draught from the fund of it's own richer, and more perfect ideas.

The variety of ∫cenes, which nature exhibits; and their infinite combinations, and peculiarities, to which neither language, nor colours, unaided by imagination, can, in any degree, do ju∫tice; gave occa∫ion to the∫e remarks, which have carried me perhaps too far into digre∫∫ion.

We had to regret, that we ∫aw the vale of Lorton only in half it's beauty. It was at too late an hour; and the evening be∫ides was dark. The morning had been cloudy;
in ∫ome part of it rather tempe∫tuous; and we thought our∫elves then very happy in the di∫po∫ition of the weather: for as we had before ∫een the mountains in a clear atmo∫phere; it was a de∫irable variety to ∫ee the grand effects they produced in a ∫torm. A mountain is nan object of grandeur; and it's dignity receives new force by mixing with the clouds; and arraying it∫elf in the maje∫ty of darkne∫s. Here the idea of infinity produces ∫trongly the ∫ublime. But the chearful ∫cenes of ∫uch a vale as this, pretend not to dignity: they are mere ∫cenes of tranquillity. The early blu∫h of dawn, the noon-tide ∫hade, or evening-glow, are the circum∫tances, in which they mo∫t rejoice: a ∫torm, in any ∫hape, will injure them. Here therefore we might have di∫pen∫ed with more light, and ∫un∫hine. Or at the clo∫e of day we might have wi∫hed for a quiet, tranquil hour, when the glimmering ∫urfaces of things are ∫ometimes perhaps more plea∫ing -- at all times certainly more ∫oothing, than images of the brighte∫t hue:
chap.note: See Page, 228.

poem.line: When through the du∫k ob∫curely ∫een
Sweet evening-objects intervene.

chap.p: The evening, which grew more tempe∫tuous, began to clo∫e upon us, as we left the more beautiful parts of the vale of Lorton. We were ∫till about ∫ix miles from Ke∫wick; and had before us a very wild country, which probably would have afforded no great amu∫ement even in full day: but amid the ob∫curity, which now over∫pread the land∫cape, the imagination was left at large; and painted many images, which perhaps did not really exi∫t, upon the dead colouring of nature. Every great and plea∫ing form, whether clear, or ob∫cure, which we had ∫een during the day, now played, in ∫trong imagery before the fancy: as when the grand chorus cea∫es, ideal mu∫ic vibrates in the ear.

In one part, a view plea∫ed us much; tho perhaps, in ∫tronger light, it might have e∫caped notice. The road made a ∫udden dip into a little, winding valley; which being too abrupt for a carriage, was ea∫ed by a
bridge: and the form of the arch appeared to be what we commonly find in Roman aquaducts. The winding road; the woody valley, and broken ground below; the mountain beyond; the form of the bridge, which gave a cla∫∫ic air to the ∫cene; and the ob∫curity, which melted the whole into one harmonious ma∫s; made all together a very plea∫ing view.

But it ∫oon grew too dark even for the imagination to roam. It was now ten o'clock: and tho in this northern climate, the twilight of a clear ∫ummer-evening affords even at that late hour, a bright effulgence; yet now was all dark.

poem.line: ---- A faint, erroneous ray
Glanced from th' imperfect ∫urfaces of things,
Threw half an image on the ∫training eye.
While wavering woods, and villages, and ∫treams,
And rocks, and mountain-tops, that long retained
Th' a∫cending gleam, were all one ∫wimming ∫cene,
Uncertain if beheld ----

chap.p:
We could ju∫t di∫cern, through the dimne∫s of the night, the ∫hadowy forms of the mountains, ∫ometimes blotting out half the
∫ky, on one ∫ide; and ∫ometimes winding round, as a gloomy barrier on the other.

Often too the road would appear to dive into ∫ome dark aby∫s, a cataract roaring at the bottom: while the mountain-torrents on every ∫ide ru∫hed down the hills in notes of various cadence, as their quantities of water, the declivities of their fall, their di∫tances, or the intermi∫∫ion of the bla∫t, brought the ∫ound fuller, or fainter to the ear; which organ became now more alert, as the imagination depended rather on it, than on the eye for information.

The∫e various notes of water-mu∫ic, an∫wering each other from hill to hill, were a kind of tran∫lation of that pa∫∫age in the p∫alms, in which one deep is repre∫ented calling another becau∫e of the noi∫e of the water-pipes.

Among other images of the night, a lake (for the lake of Ba∫∫enthwait was now in view) appeared through the uncertainty of the gloom, like ∫omething of ambiguous texture, ∫preading a lengthened gleam of wan, dead light under the dark ∫hade of the incumbent mountains: but whether this light
was owing to vapours arising from the valley; or whether it was water -- and if water, whether it was an arm of the ∫ea, a lake, or a river -- tot the uninformed traveller would appear matter of great uncertainty. Whatever it was, it would ∫een ∫ufficient to alarm his apprehen∫ions; and to rai∫e in his fancy, (now in the que∫t of dangers,) the idea of ∫omething, that might ∫top his farther progre∫s.

A good turnpike-road, on which we entered near the village of Lorton, and a knowledge of the country, ∫et at naught all ∫uch ideas with us: but may ea∫ily be conceived, a that a traveller, wandering in the mid∫t of a ∫tormy night, in a mountainous country, unknown, and unbeaten by human foot∫teps, might feel palpitations of a very unea∫y kind.

We have in O∫∫ian ∫ome beautiful images, which accompany a night-∫torm in ∫uch a country as this. I ∫hall ∫ubjoin, with a few alterations, an extract from them; as it will illu∫trate the ∫ubject before us. It is contained in a note on Croma; in which ∫everal bards are introduced entertaining their patron with their re∫pective de∫criptions of the night.

The ∫torm gathers on the tops of the mountains; and ∫preads it's black mantle before the moon. It comes forward in the maje∫ty of darkne∫s, moving upon the wings of the bla∫t. It ∫weeps along the vale, and nothing can with∫tand it's force. The lightning from the rifted cloud fla∫hes before it: the thunder rolls among the mountains in its rear.
All nature is re∫tle∫s, and unea∫y.
The ∫tag lies wakeful on the mountain-mo∫s: the hind clo∫e by his ∫ide. She hears the ∫torm roaring through the branches of the trees. She ∫tarts -- and lies down again.
The heath-cock lifts his head at intervals; and returns it under his wing.
The owl leaves her unfini∫hed dirge; and ∫its ruffled in her feathers in a cleft of the bla∫ted oak.
The fami∫hed fox ∫hrinks from the ∫torm, and ∫eeks the ∫helter of his den.

The hunter alarmed, leaps from his pallet in the lonely hut. He rai∫es his decaying fire. His wet dogs ∫moke around him. He half-opens his cabin-door, and looks out: but he in∫tantly retreats from the terrors of the night.
For now the whole ∫torm de∫cends. The mountain-torrents join their impetuous ∫treams. The growing river ∫wells.

The benighted traveller pau∫es as he enters the gloomy dell. The glaring ∫ky di∫covers the terrors of the ∫cene. With a face of wild de∫pair he looks round. He recollects neither the rock above, nor the precipice below. Still he urges his bewildered way. His ∫teed trembles at the frequent fla∫h. The thunder bur∫ts over his head -- The torrents roar aloud. -- He attempts the rapid ford. -- Heard you that ∫cream? -- It was the ∫hriek of death.
How tumultuous is the bo∫om of the lake! The waves la∫h it's rocky ∫ides. The boat is brimful in the cove. The oars are da∫hed again∫t the ∫hore.

What melancholy ∫hade is that ∫itting under the tree on the lonely beach? -- I just di∫cern it faintly ∫hadowed out by the pale beam of the moon, pa∫∫ing through a thin-robed cloud. -- It is a female form. -- Her eyes are fixed upon the lake. Her di∫chevelled hair floats loo∫e around her arm, which ∫upports her pen∫ive head. -- Ah! mourn-
ful maid! do∫t thou ∫till expect thy lover over the lake? -- Thou ∫awe∫t his di∫tant boat, at the clo∫e of day, dancing upon the feathery waves. -- Thy brea∫t throbs with ∫u∫pence: but thou knowe∫t not yet, that he lies a corp∫e upon the ∫hore.

chap.title: Volume 2, Section XVII.
chap.head: SECT. XVII.
chap.p: AFTER a wet, and ∫tory night we rejoiced to ∫ee the morning ari∫e with all the ∫igns of a calm and ∫plendid day. We wi∫hed for the opportunity of ∫urveying Ulle∫water in ∫erene, bright weather. This was the next ∫cene we propo∫ed to vi∫it; and with which we intended to clo∫e our views of this picture∫que country.

From Ke∫wick we mounted a hill, on the great turnpike road to Penrith. At the ∫ummit we left our hor∫es; and went to examine a Druid temple, in a field on the right. The diameter of this circle is thirty-two paces; which, as nearly as could be judged from ∫o inaccurate a mode of men∫uration, is the diameter of Stonehenge; which I once mea-
∫ured in the ∫ame way. But the ∫tructures are very different; tho the diameters may be nearly equal. The ∫tones here are Sali∫bury-Plain. If Stonehenge were a cathedral in it's day; this circle was little more than a country church.

The∫e ∫tructures, I ∫uppo∫e, are by far the mo∫t ancient ve∫tiges of architecture (if we may call them architecture) which we have in England. Their rude workman∫hip hands down the great barbarity of the times of the Druids: and furni∫hes ∫trong proof of the ∫avage nature of the religion of the∫e heathen prie∫ts. Within the∫e magical circles we may conceive any incantations to have been performed; and any rites of ∫uper∫tition to have been celebrated. It is hi∫tory, as well as poetry, when O∫∫ian mentions the circles of ∫tones, where our ance∫tors, in their nocturnal orgies, invoked the ∫pirits which rode upon the winds -- the awful forms of their decea∫ed forefathers; through which, he ∫ublimely tells us, the ∫tars dimly twinkled.

As ∫ingular a part as the Druids make in the ancient hi∫tory, not only of Britain, but of other countries, I know not, that I ever ∫aw any of their tran∫actions introduced as the ∫ubject of a capital picture. They the can furni∫h a fund of excellent imagery for poetry we know: and I ∫ee not why the ∫cenes of Caractacus might not be as well ∫uited to picture∫que, as dramatic repre∫entation. -- And yet there is a difference. The drama depends at lea∫t as much on ∫entiment, as on repre∫entation. Whereas the picture depends intirely on the latter. The beautiful ∫entiments of the poet are lo∫t; and the ∫pectator mu∫t make out the dialogue, as he is able, from the energetic looks of the figures. -- Hence therefore it follows, that the ∫ame ∫ubjects are not equally calculated to ∫hine in poetry, and in painting.

Tho∫e ∫ubjects, no doubt, are be∫t adapted to the pencil, which tell them∫elves by action. In general, however, all animated ∫tories, which admit either of ∫trong action, or pa∫∫ion, are judiciou∫ly cho∫en. Unanimated ∫ubjects have little chance of producing an effect; parti-
cularly love-∫tories; which, of all others, I could wi∫h to exclude from canvas. The language of love is ∫o difficult to tran∫late, that I know not that I ever ∫aw a repre∫entation of lovers, who were not ∫trongly marked with the character of ∫impletons.

But be∫ides ∫uch ∫ubjects, as admit of ∫trong action, or pa∫∫ion, there are other of a more inanimate ca∫t, which, through the peculiarity of the characters, of which they con∫i∫t, can never be mi∫taken. Such is the ∫ettlement of Pen∫ylvania, painted by Mr. We∫t. From the mixture of Engli∫h, and Indian characters, and a variety of appo∫ite appendages, the ∫tory is not only well told; but, as every picture∫que ∫tory ∫hould be told, it is obvious at ∫ight.

Among ∫ubjects of this kind, are tho∫e, which occa∫ioned this digre∫∫ion -- druidical ∫ubjects. I know few of the le∫s animated kind, which would admit more picture∫que embelli∫hment, than a Druid-∫acrifice. The peculiar character, and ∫avage features of the∫e barbarous prie∫ts -- their white, flowing ve∫tments -- the branch of mi∫leto, which they hold -- the circular ∫tones (if they could be brought into compo∫ition) -- the ∫preading oak
-- the alter beneath it -- and the milk-white ∫teer -- might all together form a good picture.

I have often admired an etching by Teipolo, which I have always conceived to be a repre∫entation of this ∫ubject. He does not indeed introduce all the circum∫tances of a Druid-∫acrifice, which I have here enumerated: but the characters are ∫uch, as exactly ∫uit the ∫ubject; and the whole ∫eems to be an excellent illu∫tration of it.
chap.note: It is contained in a book of etchings on emblematical ∫ubjects.
chap.p: After we left the temple of the Druids, we met with little which engaged our attention, till we came to the vale of St. John. This ∫cene appeared from the ∫tand, where we viewed it, to be a circular area, of about ∫ix, or ∫even miles in circumference. It is ∫urrounded intirely by mountains; and is watered by a ∫mall river, called the Grata.

The vale of St. John is e∫teemed one of the mo∫t celebrated ∫cenes of beauty in the country: but
it did not an∫wer our expectation. The ground, con∫i∫ting of patches of fenced meadow, adorned with farm-hou∫es, and clumps of trees, was beautifully tumbled about in many parts: but the whole was rather rich, than picture∫que: and on this account, I ∫uppo∫e, it hath obtained it's celebrity. It's circular form, every where within the ∫cope of the eye, wanted that variety, which the winding vale affords; where one part is continually receding from another in all the plea∫ing gradations of per∫pective.
chap.note: See the ∫ame idea applied to water, page 184.
chap.p:
The kind of ∫cenery here, is much the ∫ame, as in the vale of Lorton: both are compo∫ed of rural objects; but the∫e objects are differently pre∫ented. In the vale of Lorton, the hou∫es, and hamlets, ∫eated on a wandering ∫tream, are confined to the ∫ame level; and appear of cour∫e, one after another, as ∫o many little ∫eparate ∫cenes. Here they are ∫cattered about the inequalities of the ground, through the area of a vale, circular at lea∫t in appearance; and offer the eye too much at once -- a confu∫ion, rather than a ∫uc-
ce∫∫ion, of ∫cenery. I ∫peak however only of the general appearance of the vale: it contains undoubtedly many beautiful ∫cenes, if we had had time to explore them.

The plan, or ground-plot, of the vale of Tempe was ∫omewhat ∫imilar to this of St. John. Nature ∫eems in both to have wrought on the ∫ame model; excepting only that the furniture of that very celebrated ∫cene of antiquity was more picture∫que.

The vale of Tempe, like this, was circular, and incompa∫∫ed with mountains. But it's area was compo∫ed of level lawns, (at lea∫t, we ∫uppo∫e, not ri∫ing uniformly before the eye,) inter∫per∫ed with wood; which in many parts was thick, and clo∫e; and mu∫t every where have intercepted ∫ome portion of the mountain-line, and broken the regularity of a circular ∫hape.

The mountains too in Tempe were of a more beautiful ∫tructure; abrupt, hung with rock, and finely adorned with wood. -- At the head of the vale was a grand, rocky cha∫m, ∫haded with a profu∫ion of wood ∫cenery; through which the whole weight of
the river Peneus forced it's way, with a tremendous ∫ound; and having been da∫hed into foam and vapours by the fall, reunited it's ∫trength at the bottom, and poured through the vale in a wild, impetuous torrent, roaring over rocks and ∫helves, till it found an exit, through the folding of the mountains on the oppo∫ite ∫ide.

Elian indeed tells us, that the ∫tream was ∫mooth: but as Ovid's de∫cription is more picture∫que, the reader will give me leave to con∫ider his authority as more deci∫ive. His view of Tempe is very noble: but as he meant principally to de∫cribe the palace of a river god, which lay among the caverns, and rece∫∫es of the rocky cha∫m at the entrance of the vale, his ∫ubject naturally led him to dwell chiefly on the ca∫cade, which was undoubtedly the greate∫t ornament of the place.

poem.line: E∫t nemus Æmoniæ, prærupta quod undique claudia
Silva: vocant Tempe: per quæ Peneus ab imo
E∫∫u∫us Pindo, ∫pumo∫is volvitur undis;
Dejectuque gravi renues agitantia fumos
Nubila conducit; ∫umma∫que a∫pergine ∫ilvas
Impluit: & ∫onitu plus quam vicina fatigat.
Hæc domus, hæ ∫edes, hæc ∫unt penetralia magni
Amnis: in hoc re∫idens facto de cautibus antro,
Undis jura dabat. ----

chap.p: A vale thus circum∫tanced is ∫o plea∫ing, that other poets have ∫eized the idea in their de∫criptions. I could multiply quotations: but I ∫hall ∫elect two, in which the ∫ame ∫ubject is treated in a different manner. In one the natural grandeur of the ∫cene is ∫oftened by little circum∫tances of chearfulne∫s: in the other, it ∫trikes in the full majesty of the ∫ublime. The former is more the vale of St. John: the latter approaches nearer the idea of the The∫∫alian vale.

stanza.line: Into a fore∫t far they thence him led,
Where was their dwelling in a plea∫ant glade,
With mountains round about invironed,
And mighty woods that did the valley ∫hade,
And like a ∫tately theatre it made,
Spreading it∫elf into a ∫pacious plain.
And in the mid∫t a little river played
Among∫t the pumy ∫tones, which ∫eemed to plain,
With gentle murmur that is cour∫e they did re∫train.
---- The hills
Of Æta, yielding to a fruitful vale,
Within their range half-circulating had inclo∫ed
A fair expan∫e in verdure ∫mooth. The bounds
Were edged by wood, o'erhung by hoary cliffs,
Which from the clouds bent frowning. Down a rock,
Above the loftie∫t ∫ummit of the grove,
A tumbling torrent wore the ∫hagged ∫tone;
Then gleaming through the intervals of ∫hade,
Attaired the valley, where the level ∫tream
Di∫∫u∫ed refre∫hment ----

chap.p: The vale of St. John was, ∫ome years ago, the ∫cene of one of tho∫e terrible inundations, which wa∫ted lately the vale of Brackenthwait. I ∫hall relate the circum∫tances of it, as they were given to me on the ∫pot: but as we had them not perhaps on the be∫t authority, they may, in ∫ome particulars, be overcharged.

It was on the 22d of Augu∫t 1749, that this di∫a∫ter happened. That day, which had been preceded by weather uncommonly clo∫e and ∫ultry; ∫et in with a gloomy a∫pect. The blackne∫s gathered, more, and more, from every quarter. The air was hot beyond ∫ufferance. The whole atmo∫phere, and every thing around was in a ∫tate of perfect ∫tagnation. Not a leaf was in motion.

In the mean time, the inhabitants of the vale heard a ∫trange noi∫e in various parts around them: but whether it was in the air, or whether it aro∫e from the mountains, they could not a∫certain. It was like the hollow
murmur of a ri∫ing wind, among the tops of trees. This noi∫e (which in a ∫maller degree is not an uncommon prelude to a ∫torm) continued without intermi∫∫ion about two hours; when a tempe∫t of wind, and rain, and thunder, and lightning ∫ucceeded; which was violent, beyond any thing, remembered in former times; and la∫ted, without pau∫e, near three hours.

During this ∫torm the cataract fell upon the mountain, on the north of the vale; or as ∫ome people thought, tho ∫hould ∫uppo∫e without any probability, bur∫t from the bowels of it. The ∫ide of that mountain is a continued precipice, through the ∫pace of a mile. This whole tract, we were told, was covered, in an in∫tant, with one continuous ca∫cade of roaring torrent (an appearance, which mu∫t have equalled the fall of Niagara) ∫weeping all before it from the top of the mountain to the bottom. There, like that other inundation, it followed the channel of the brooks it met with; and ∫hewed ∫imilar effects of it's fury.

One of the∫e effects was a∫toni∫hing. The fragments of rock, and deluges of ∫tone, and ∫and, which were ∫wept from the mountain
by the torrent, choked on the ∫treams, which received it at the bottom. The water, thus pent up, and receiving continually va∫t acce∫∫ion of ∫trength, after rolling ∫ullenly about that part of the vale in frightful whirl-pools, at length forced a new channel through a ∫olid rock, which we were informed, it disjointed in ∫ome fracture crevice, and made a cha∫m at lea∫t ten feet wide. Many of the fragments were carried to a great di∫tance; and ∫ome of them were ∫o large, that a dozen hor∫es could ∫carce move them. We were ∫orry afterwards, that we had not ∫een this remarkable cha∫m: but we had not time to go in que∫t of it.

From the vale of St. John we a∫cended a ∫teep hill, called Branthwait-cragg; where being obliged to leave the great road in our way to Ulle∫water, and inve∫tigate a pathle∫s de∫ert over the mountains, which invironed us; we put our∫elves under the conduct of a guide.

The∫e mountains were covered with a profu∫ion of huge ∫tones, and detached rocks; among which we found many old people,
and children, from the neighbouring villages, gathering a ∫pecies of white lychen, that grows upon the craggs; and which we heard had been found very u∫eful in dying a murray-colour.

Among the difficulties of our rout over the∫e mountains, the bogs and mora∫∫es we met with, were the mo∫t trouble∫ome. We were often obliged to di∫mount; and in ∫ome parts the ∫urface could hardly bear a man. Where ru∫hes grew, our guide informed us, the ground was firme∫t. We endeavoured therefore, as much as po∫∫ible, to make the little tu∫∫ocks of the∫e plants the ba∫is of our foot∫teps. But as we could not convey this intelligence to our hor∫es, they often plunged very deep.

In ∫everal parts of our ride, we had a view of that grand clu∫ter of mountains, which forms a circle in the heart of Cumberland; and makes a back ground to the central views from almo∫t every part of the extremities of that county. The∫e mountains unite on the ∫outh with tho∫e of We∫tmoreland. The ∫ide next us was compo∫ed of Skiddaw -- Threlkate-
fell, a part of which is called Saddle-back -- and Gri∫edale-fell. As we rode nearer the northern limit of this chain, Skiddaw, which is by much the highe∫t mountain, appeared, in per∫pective, the lea∫t. Behind the∫e mountains ari∫e, in order, Mo∫edale-fell -- Carric -- and Caudbeck -- the tops of which we ∫ometimes ∫aw, from the higher grounds, peering, in their blue attire, over the concave parts of the browner mountains, which ∫tood nearer the eye.

Between us, and this circular chain, which occupied the whole horizon on the left, was ∫pread a very exten∫ive vale; ∫tretching from ∫ide to ∫ide hardly le∫s than ∫even or eight miles; and in length winding out of ∫ight. It is a ∫cene of little beauty, except what ari∫es from the gradation of di∫tance: but it ∫ugge∫ts and idea of greatne∫s; which ∫pace, and grand boundaries, however unadorned, will always ∫ugge∫t.

This idea hath ∫ometimes mi∫led the ta∫tele∫s improver of little ∫cenes. He has heard, that ∫pace gives beauty; but not knowing how to accommodate the rule to circum∫tances, he
often ∫hews all that is to be ∫een; when, in fact, he ∫hould have hid half of it, as a deformity. Mere ∫pace gives the idea of grandeur, rather than of beauty. Such an idea the ocean pre∫ents. But a little ∫cene cannot pre∫ent it. Grandeur therefore is not attained by attempting it; while beauty is often lo∫t.

Along this vale ran the great road we had ju∫t left; which was no little ornament to it. The mazy cour∫e of a river is a ∫till nobler object of the ∫ame kind: but a great road is no bad ∫ub∫titute; and is in ∫ome re∫pects ∫uperior. The river being on a level, and contained without banks, is generally too much hid, unle∫s it be viewed from an elevated point: but the road following the inequalities of the ground, is ea∫ily traced by the eye, as it winds along the ∫everal elevations and depre∫∫ions it meets with; and has therefore more variety in it's cour∫e.

On the right, forming the other ∫ide of this exten∫ive vale, ari∫e ∫everal very high
mountains; among which Hara-∫ide, and White-pike are the mo∫t magnificent. At the bottom of the∫e, verging towards the ∫kirts of the vale, are other hills le∫s formidable: but two of them, called the Mell-fells, are very remarkable; being ∫haped like earthen graves, in a country church-yard.

A little before we approached the Mull-fells, the path we pur∫ued, led us under a towering rocky hill, which is known by the name of Wolf's-cragg, and is probably one of the monuments of this animal remaining in Britain. It is a fortre∫s intirely adapted to a garri∫on of wolves; from whence they might plunder the vale, which was ∫pread before them; and make prey of every thing, as far as the eye could reach. Such a ∫cene, in painting, would be highly characterized by ∫uch appendages. It would have plea∫ed Ridinger. If that picture∫que naturali∫t had been in que∫t of a wolf-∫cene, he could not have found a better.

When we had pa∫∫ed this range of mountains, we got more into a beaten path, leading to the village of Matterdale, about a mile only from Ulle∫water; which was ∫till intirely excluded from our ∫ight by high grounds. Here we di∫mi∫∫ed our guide, and were directed into Gobray-park, which is the northern boundary of the lake.

This part of the country we found well inhabited; and the roads, at this ∫ea∫on, much frequented. It was about the time of a ∫tatute-fair; when the young people of the country leave their old ∫ervices, and go to their new and we were not a little entertained with the ∫implicity, and variety of the ∫everal groups and figures we met, both on hor∫eback, and on foot.

The∫e are the picture∫que inhabitants of a land∫cape. The dre∫∫ed-out figures, and gaudy carriages, along the great roads of the capital, afford them not. The pencil rejects with indignation the ∫plendor of art. In grand ∫cenes, even the pea∫ant cannot be admitted,
if he be employed in the low occupations of his profe∫∫ion: the ∫pade, the ∫cythe, and the rake are all excluded.

Moral, and picture∫que ideas do not always coincide. In a moral light, cultivation, in all it's parts, is plea∫ing; the hedge, and the furrow; the waving corn field, and the ripened ∫heaf. But all the∫e, the picture∫que eye, in que∫t of ∫cenes of grandeur, and beauty, looks at with di∫gu∫t. It ranges after nature, untamed by art, and bur∫ting wildly into all it's irregular forms.

poem.line: ---- Juvat arva videre
Non ra∫tris hominum, non ulli abnoxia curæ

chap.p:
It is thus al∫o in the introduction of figures. In a moral view, the indu∫trious mechanic is a more plea∫ing object, than the loitering pea∫ant. But in a picture∫que light, it is otherwi∫e. The arts of indu∫try are rejected; and even idlene∫s, if I may ∫o ∫peak, adds dignity to a character. Thus the lazy cow-herd re∫ting on his pole; or the pea∫ant lolling on a rock, may be allowed in the grande∫t ∫cenes; while the laborious mechanic, with his impliments of labour, would be repul∫ed.
The fi∫herman, it is true, may follow his calling upon the lake: but he is indebted for this privilege, not to his art; but to the picture∫que apparatus of it -- his boat, and his nets, which qualify his art. They are the objects: he is but an appendage. Place him on the ∫hore, as a ∫ingle figure, with his rod, and line; and his art would ruin him. In a chearful glade, along a purling brook, near ∫ome mill, or cottage, let him angle, if he plea∫e: in ∫uch a ∫cene the picture∫que eye takes no offence. But let him take care not to introduce the vulgarity of his employment in a ∫cene of grandeur.

At the ∫ame time, we mu∫t ob∫erve, that figures, which thus take their importance merely from not mixing with low, mechanic arts, are at be∫t only picture∫que appendages. They are of a negative nature, neither adding to the grandeur of the idea, nor taking from it. They merely and ∫imply adorn a ∫cene.
The characters, which are mo∫t ∫uited to the∫e ∫cenes of grandeur, are ∫uch as impre∫s us with ∫ome idea of greatne∫s, wildne∫s, or ferocity; all which touch on the ∫ublime.
Figures in long, folding draperies; gyp∫ies; banditti; and ∫oldiers, -- not in modern regimentals; but as Virgil paints them,

poem.line: ---- longis adnixi ha∫tis, et ∫cuta tenentes;

chap.p: are all marked with one or other of the∫e characters: and mixing with the magnificence, wildne∫s, or horror of the place, they properly coale∫ce; and reflecting the ∫ame images, add a deeper tinge to the character of the ∫cene.

For the truth of all the∫e remarks I might appeal to the deci∫ive judgment of Salvator Ro∫a; who ∫eems to have thoroughly ∫tudied propriety in figures, e∫pecially in ∫cenes of grandeur. His works are a model on this head. We have a book of figures, particularly compo∫ed for ∫cenery of this kind, and etched by him∫elf. In this collection there is great variety, both in the characters, groups, and dre∫∫es: but I do not remember, either there, or in any other of his works, a low, mechanic character. All his figures are either of (what I have called) the negative kind; or marked with ∫ome trait of greatne∫s, wildne∫s, or ferocity. Of this la∫t ∫pecies his
figures generally partook: his grand ∫cenes being inhabited chiefly by banditti.
I met with a pa∫∫age, not a little illu∫trative of the∫e remarks on figures, in the travels of Mr. Thickne∫s through Spain.

"The wor∫t ∫ort of beggars, ∫ays he, in Spain are the troops of male, and female gyp∫ies. They are of the genuine breed, and differ widely from all other gyp∫ies; and I may ∫ay, from all other human beings. I often met troops of the∫e people; and when an interview happens in roads very di∫tant from towns, or dwellings, it is not very plea∫ing;: for they a∫k, as if they knew they were not to be refu∫ed; and I dare ∫ay often commit murders, when they can commit them by ∫urprize. They are extremely ∫warthy, with hair as black as jet; and form very picture∫que groups under the ∫hade of the rocks and trees of the Pyrænean mountains, where they ∫pend their evenings: and live ∫uitably to the climate; where bread, and water, and idlene∫s, are preferable to better fare, and hard-labour."

chap.title: Volume 2, Section XVII.
chap.head: SECT. XVII.
chap.p: ON de∫cending the hill from Matterdale, before we came to the lake, we had a beautiful ∫pecimen (as the naturali∫ts ∫peak) of what in this country is called a gill. The road carried us along the edge of one of it's precipices: but the cha∫m was ∫o intirely filled with wood, that when we looked down, we could not ∫ee into it. Even the ∫un-beams, unable to enter, re∫ted only on the tufted foliage of the trees, which grew from the ∫ides. -- But though the eye was excluded, the ear was ∫oothed by the harmony of an invi∫ible torrent; who∫e notes, ∫ounding along innumerable broken falls, and ∫oftened by a∫cending through the trees, were very melodious.

A winding road brought us to the bottom; where the torrent tumbling out of the wood, received us. We had a ∫hort view into the
deep rece∫∫es of the ∫cene, through the branches of the trees, which ∫tretched over the ∫tream; but we had not time, to penetrate the alluring ∫hade.
Having pa∫∫ed over more high grounds, we came at length in view of the lake. The fir∫t catch of it was thus pre∫ented.

A road occupied the neare∫t part of the land∫cape, winding around a broken cliff; which ro∫e con∫iderably on the left. A portion of a di∫tant mountain appeared on the right, with a ∫mall part of the lake at it's foot. The fore-ground was well-di∫po∫ed; and the di∫tant mountain, which fell into the lake, beautifully tinted. The compo∫ition, as far as it went, was very correct: but we yet ∫aw only enough to excite our curio∫ity; and to give us, from the bearing of the land, a general idea of the lake.

Ulle∫water is the large∫t lake in this country, except Windermere; being eight miles long; and about two broad in the wide∫t part; tho, in general, it rarely exceeds a mile in
breadth. It points nearly north, and ∫outh; as mo∫t of the∫e lakes do; but being placed at an extremity of the barrier-mountains, it affords a greater variety than is exhibited by ∫uch lakes, as are invironed by them. The∫e having few accompaniments, receive their character chiefly from the ∫urrounding de∫olation. Such a lake is Wythburn. Windermere, on the other hand, Ke∫wick, Butermer, and Ulle∫water may all be called boundary-lakes. One end of each participates more of the rugged country; and the other of the cultivated: tho each end participates, in ∫ome degree, of both. A few traits of romantic ∫cenery are added to the tamene∫s of one end; and the native horror of the other is ∫oftened by a few chearful appendages.

The form of Ulle∫water re∫embles a Z; only there is no angular acutene∫s in it's line. It ∫preads every where in a ea∫y curve; beautifully broken in ∫ome parts by promontories. -- The middle reach contains in length near two thirds of the lake. The ∫outhern ∫ide is mountainous; and becomes more ∫o, as it verges towards the we∫t. As the mountains approach the north, they glide (as we have ∫een is u∫ual in boundary-lakes) into meadows
and pa∫tures. The northern and we∫tern ∫ides contain a great variety of woody and rocky ∫cnes; but the∫e al∫o, as they approach the ea∫t, become ∫mooth and fertilized. At the ∫outhern point, under impending mountains, lies the village of Patterdale. -- With this general idea of Ulle∫water, let us return to the de∫cent from Matterdale, where we caught the fir∫t view of it.
As we de∫cended a little further, the whole ∫cene of the lake opened before us; and ∫uch a ∫cene, as almo∫t drew from us the apo∫trophe of the inraptured bard,

poem.line: Vi∫ions of glory, ∫pare my aching ∫ight!

chap.p:
Among all the vi∫ions of the inchanting country, we had ∫een nothing ∫o beautifully ∫ublime, ∫o correctly picture∫que as this. -- And yet I am aver∫e to make compari∫ons; e∫pecially on ∫eeing a country but once. Much depends on the circum∫tances of light, and weather. I would wi∫h therefore only to ∫ay, that I was more plea∫ed with Ulle∫water, than with any lake I had ∫een; adding, at the ∫ame time, that we were fortunate in a concurrence
of incidents, that aided it's beauty. We had hitherto ∫een all the lakes we had vi∫ited, under a rough, or cloudy ∫ky: and tho their dignity was certainly increa∫ed by the circum∫tance; yet the beauty of a lake in ∫plendid, ∫erene weather, aided, at this time, by the powers of contra∫t, made a wonderful impre∫∫ion on the imagination.

"The effect of the ∫ublime, Mr. Burke informs us, is a∫toni∫hment; and the effect of beauty, is plea∫ure: but when the two ingredients mix, the effect, he ∫ays, is in a good mea∫ure de∫troyed in both. They con∫titute a ∫pecies ∫omething different both from the ∫ublime and beautiful, which I have before called fine: but this kind, I imagine, has not ∫uch a power on the pa∫∫ions, either as va∫t bodies have, which are endowed with the corre∫pondent qualities of the ∫ublime; or as the qualities of beauty have, when united in a ∫mall object. The affection produced by large bodies, adorned with the ∫poils of beauty, is a tention conti-
nually relieved; which approaches to the nature of mediocrity."
chap.note: Sublime and beautiful, part IV. ∫ect. 25.
chap.p: This refined rea∫oning does not ∫eem intirely grounded on experience. -- I do not remember any ∫cene in which beauty and ∫ublimity, according to my idea, are more blended than in this: and tho Mr. Burke's ideas of beauty are perhaps more exceptionable, than his ideas od the ∫ublime; yet it happens, that mo∫t of the qualities, which hee predicates of both, unite al∫o in this ∫cene. Their effect therefore, according to his argument, ∫hould be de∫troyed. But the feelings of every lover of nature, on viewing the∫e ∫cenes, I adre be bold to ∫ay, would reevolt from ∫uch rea∫oning.

The fore-ground of the grand view before us, is a part of Gobray-park, which belongs to the duke of Norfolk; rough, broken, and woody. Among the old oaks, which inriched it, herds of deer, and cattle grazed in groups. Beyond this is ∫pread an exten∫ive reach of the lake, winding round a rocky promontory on the left;
which is the point of a mountain, called Martindale-fell, or Place-fell; the ∫outhern boundary of the lake. This promontory uniting with the mountain, lets it ea∫ily down into the water, as by a ∫tep. An he∫itation, if I may ∫o call it, of this kind, ea∫es greatly the heavine∫s of a line. In a di∫tance, it is of le∫s con∫equence: but in all the nearer grounds, it is nece∫∫ary. I ∫peak chiefly however of tho∫e ∫cenes, in which beauty, and grandeur are combined. In tho∫e of ∫imple grandeur, and ∫ublimity, as in that of Penmanmaur, for in∫tance, in north wales, the heavy line, which is very remarkable in that ∫cene, perhaps ∫trengthens the effect.
Martindale-fell is intirely unplanted: but it's line, and ∫urface are both well varied. Numberle∫s breaks (little vallies, and knolls) give it a lightne∫s, without injuring it's ∫implicity.

Such was the di∫po∫ition of the objects, on the left of the lake: on the right, two woody promontories, pur∫uing each other in per∫pective, made a beautiful contra∫t with the ∫mooth continuity of Martindale-fell.

In front, the di∫tance was compo∫ed of mountains, falling gently into the lake; near
the edge of which lies the village of Patterdale.

We took this view at a point, which had ju∫t ∫o much elevation, as to give a variety to the lines of the lake. As we de∫cended to the water, the view was ∫till grand, and beautiful, but had lo∫t ∫ome of it's more picture∫que beauties: it had lo∫t the fore-ground: it had lo∫t the ∫weeping line round the mountain on the left: and it had lo∫t the rece∫s between the two woody promontories on the right. The whole margin of the lake was nearly reduced to one ∫traight line. -- The beauty of a view, e∫pecially in lake-∫cenery, we have before ob∫erved, depends greatly on the nice po∫ition of it's point.
chap.note: See page 96. Vol. I.
chap.p:
Having ∫pent ∫ome time in examining this very inchanting ∫cene, we ∫kirted the lake towards Patterdale, on a tolerable road, which runs from one end of it to the other: on the ∫outh it is continued to Amble∫ide; on the north, to Penrith. I call it a tolerable road; but I mean only for hor∫es. It has not the
quartering and commodious width of a carriage road.

As we left Gobray-park, we took our rout along the margin of the fir∫t of tho∫e woody promontories on the right. We were carried by the ∫ide of the lake, through clo∫e lanes, and thick groves: and yet no ∫o thick, but that we had every where, through the openings of the trees, and windings of the road, views in front, and on the right, into woody rece∫∫es; ∫ome of which were very plea∫ing: and on the left, the lake and all it's di∫tant furniture, broke frequently upon us.

After ∫kirting the fir∫t wooded promontory, which carried us about a mile, the road turned ∫uddenly to the right, and led us round into the ∫econd, ri∫ing a con∫iderable height above the water. -- In this promontory, a new ∫cene opened: the woods became intermixed with rock; and a great variety of very beautiful fore-grounds were produced. The rocks, through which the road was ∫ometimes cut, were chiefly on our right. -- In this promon-
tory al∫o, as well as in the other, we were amu∫ed with catches of the lake, and of Martindale-fell, through the tree.

Scenes, like the∫e, are adapted to every ∫tate of the ∫ky. They were beautiful in the calm ∫ea∫on, in which we ∫aw them; and in which indeed we wi∫hed to ∫ee them. But they would have received peculiar advantages al∫o from ∫torm. The objects are all in that great ∫tyle, which is ∫uited to the violences of nature. The imagination would have ri∫en with the tempe∫t, and give a double grandeur to every awful form. -- The trees, in the mean time, which rear them∫elves ∫tage above ∫tage, upon the mountain's brow, and ∫pread down to the very road, would have made a noble in∫trument for the hollow bla∫t to ∫ound, con∫i∫ting of various notes: while the ∫urges of the lake, re∫ounding among the caverns, and da∫hing again∫t the rocks, many fathoms below, would have aided the concert with new notes of terrific harmony.

poem.line: ---- There is a mood,
(I ∫ing not to the vacant and the young)
There is a kindly mood of melancholy,
That wings the ∫oul, and points her to the ∫ky.
While winds, and tempe∫ts ∫weep the various lyre,
How ∫weet the diapa∫on! ----

chap.p: The mind is not always indeed in uni∫on with ∫uch ∫cenes, and circum∫tances, as the∫e. When it does not happen to be ∫o, no effect can be produced. Sometimes indeed the ∫cene may draw the mind into uni∫on; if it be not under the impre∫∫ion of any ∫trong pa∫∫ion of an oppo∫ite kind; but in a ∫ort of neutral ∫tate. The effect however will always be ∫tronge∫t, when the mind happens to be po∫∫e∫∫ed of ideas congenial to the ∫cene -- when, in a kindly mood of melancholy, it feels it∫elf ∫oother by the objects around.

But be∫ides the mu∫ic of winds are tempe∫ts, the ecchoes, which are excited in different parts of this lake, are ∫till more grand, and affecting. More or le∫s they accompany all lakes, that circum∫cribed by lofty, and rocky ∫cenes. We found them on Windermere; we found them on Derwentwater. But
every lake, being ∫urrounded by rocks and mountains of a ∫tructure peculiar to it∫elf, forms a variety of in∫truments and, of cour∫e, a variety of ∫ounds. The ecchoes therefore of no two lakes are alike; unle∫s they are mere monotoni∫ts.

We took notice of a very grand eccho on the we∫tern ∫hores of the great i∫land in Windermere: but the mo∫t celebrated ecchoes are ∫aid to be found on Ulle∫water; in ∫ome of which the ∫ound of a cannon is di∫tinctly reverberated ∫ix, or ∫even times. It fir∫t rolls over the head in one va∫t peal. -- Then ∫ub∫iding a few ∫econds, it ri∫es again in a grand, interrupted bur∫t, perhaps on the right. -- Another ∫olemn pau∫e en∫ues. Then the ∫ound ari∫es again on the left. -- Thus thrown from rock to rock, in a ∫ort of aerial per∫pective, it is caught again perhaps by ∫ome nearer promontory; and returning full on the ear, ∫urprizes you, after you thought all had been over, with as great a peal as at fir∫t.

But the grande∫t effect of this kind is produced by a ∫ucce∫∫ive di∫charge of cannon;
at the interval of a few ∫econds between each di∫charge. The effect of the fir∫t is not over, when the ecchoes of the ∫econd, the third, or perhaps of the ∫econd, the third, or perhaps of the fourth, begin. Such a variety of awful ∫ounds, mixing, and commixing, and at the ∫ame moment heard from all ∫ides, have a wonderful effect on the mind; as if the every foundations of every rock on the lake were giving way; and the whole ∫cene, from ∫ome ∫trange convul∫ion, were falling into general ruin.
chap.note: The duke of Portland, who has property in this neighbourhood, has a ve∫∫el on the lake, with bra∫s guns, for the purpo∫e of exciting ecchoes.
chap.p: The∫e ∫ounds, which are all of the terrific kind, are ∫uited chiefly to ∫cenes of grandeur during ∫ome moment of wildne∫s, when the lake is under the agitation of a ∫torm. In a calm, ∫till evening, the gradations of an eccho, dying away in di∫tant thunder, are certainly heard with mo∫t advantage. But that is a different idea. You attend then only to the ecchoes them∫elves. When you take the ∫cene into the combination; and attend to the effect of the whole together; no doubt ∫uch ∫ounds, as are of the mo∫t violent kind, are be∫t ∫uited to moments of the greate∫t uproar.

But there is another ∫pecies of ecchoes, which are as well adapted to the lake in all it's ∫tillne∫s, and tranquillity, as the others
are to it's wildne∫s, and confu∫ion: and which recommend them∫elves chiefly to tho∫e feelings, which depend on the gentler movements of the mind. In∫tead of cannon, let a few French-horns, and clarionets be introduced. Softer mu∫ic than ∫uch loud wind-in∫truments, would ∫carce have power to vibrate. The effect is now wonderfully changed. The ∫ound of a cannon is heard in bur∫ts. It is the mu∫ic only of thunder. But the continuation of mu∫ical ∫ounds forms a continuation of mu∫ical ecchoes; which reverberating around the lake, are exqui∫itely melodious in their ∫everal gradations; and form a thou∫and ∫ymphonies, playing together from every part. The variety of notes is inconceivable. The ear is not equal to their innumerable combinations. It li∫tens to a ∫ymphony dying away at a di∫tance; when other melodious ∫ounds ari∫e clo∫e at hand. The∫e have ∫carce attracted the attention; when a different mode of harmony ari∫es from another quarter. In ∫hort, every rock is vocal, and the whole lake is transformed into a kind of magical ∫cene; in which every promontory ∫eems peopled by aerial beings, an∫wering each other in cele∫tial mu∫ic.

poem.line: --- How often from the ∫teep
Of ecchoing hill, or thicket, have we heard
Cele∫tial voices to the midnight air,
Sole, or re∫pon∫ive each to other's note,
Singing their great Creator? Oft in bands
While they keep watch, or nightly rounding walk,
With heavenly touch of in∫trumental ∫ounds,
In full harmonic number joined, their ∫ongs
Divide the night, and lift our thoughts to heaven.

chap.p: We had now almo∫t ∫kirted the two woody promontories in our rout to Patterdale. The conclu∫ion is the grande∫t part of the whole ∫cenery. It is a bold projection of rock finely marked, and adorned with hanging woods; under the beetling ∫ummit of which the road makes a ∫udden turn. This is the point of the ∫econd promontory; and, I believe, is known by the name of Stibray-cragg.
The trees which compo∫e the whole ∫cenery through both the∫e promontories, are in general, oak.

From hence through lanes of the ∫ame kind, though le∫s ∫uperbly decorated, we came to the village of Patterdale; ∫ituated on ri∫ing ground, among two or three little
rivers, or branches of a river, which feed the lake. It lies in a cove of mountains, open in front to the ∫outhern reach of the lake; beyond which appear the high and woody lands of Gobray-park. The ∫ituation is magnificent.

Among the cottages of this village, there is a hou∫e, belonging to a per∫on of a ∫omewhat better condition; who∫e little e∫tate, which he occupies him∫elf, lies in the neighbourhood. As his property, incon∫iderable as it is, is better than that of any of his neighbours, it has gained him the title of King of Patterdale, in which his family name is lo∫t. His ance∫tors have long enjoyed the title before him. We had the honour of ∫eeing this prince, as he took the diver∫ion of fi∫hing on the lake; and I could not help thinking, that if I were inclined to envy the ∫ituation of any potentate in Europe, it would be that of the king of Patterdale. The pride of Wind∫or and Ver∫ailles would ∫hrink in a compari∫on with the magnificence of his dominions.
The great ∫implicity of this country, and that rigid temperance, and economy, which nece∫∫ity injoins to all it's inhabitants, may be exemplified by the following little hi∫tory.

A clergyman, of the name of Matti∫on, was mini∫ter of this place ∫ixty years; and died lately at the age of ninety. During the early part of his life, his benefice brought him in only twelve pounds a year. It was afterwards increa∫ed, (I ∫uppo∫e by the queen's bounty,) to eighteen; which it never exceeded. On this income he married -- brought up four children -- lived comfortably among his neighbours -- educated a ∫on, I believe, at college -- and left upwards of 1000£. behind him.

With that ∫ingular ∫implicity, and inattention to forms which characterize a country like this; he him∫elf read the burial-∫ervice over his mother; he married his father to a ∫econd wife; and afterwards buried him al∫o. He publi∫hed his own banns of marriage in the church, with a woman, whom he had formerly chri∫tened; and him∫elf married all his four children.

From this ∫pecimen, the manners of the country may ea∫ily be conceived. At a di∫tance from the refinements of the age, they are at a di∫tance al∫o from it's vices. Many ∫age writers, and Monte∫quieu in particular, have ∫uppo∫ed the∫e rough ∫cenes of nature to have a great effect on the human mind: and have found virtues in mountainous countries, which were not the growth of tamer regions. Many opinions perhaps have pa∫∫ed current among mankind, which have le∫s foundation in truth. Monte∫quieu is in que∫t chiefly of political virtue -- liberty -- bravery -- and the arts of bold defence: but, I believe, private virtue is equally befriended by the∫e rough ∫cenes. It is ∫ome happine∫s indeed to the∫e people, that they have no great roads among them; and that their ∫imple villages, on the ∫ides of lakes, and mountains, are in no line of communication with any of the bu∫y haunts of men. Ignorance is ∫ometimes called the mother of vice. I apprehend it to be as often the nur∫e of innocence.
chap.note: Book XVIII. Ch. II.
chap.p: Much have tho∫e travellers to an∫wer for, who∫e ca∫ual intercour∫e with this innocent, and ∫imple people tends to corrupt them; di∫∫eminating among them ideas of extravagance, and di∫∫ipation -- giving them a ta∫te for plea∫ures, and gratifications, of which they had no ideas -- in∫piring them with di∫content at home -- and tainting their rough, indu∫trious manners with idlene∫s, and a thir∫t after di∫hone∫t means.

If travellers would frequent this country with a view to examine it's grandeur, and beauty -- or to explore it's varied, and curious regions with the eye of philo∫ophy -- or, if that could be hoped, to adore the great Creator in the∫e his ∫ublimer works -- if, in their pa∫∫age through it, they could be content with ∫uch fare as the country produces; or, at lea∫t reconcile them∫elves to it by manly exerci∫e, and fatigue (for there is a time, when the ∫tomach, and the plaine∫t food will be found in perfect harmony) -- if they could thus, in∫tead of corrupting the manners of an innocent people; learn to amend their own,
by ∫eeing in how narrow a compa∫s the wants of human life may be compre∫∫ed -- a journey through the∫e wild ∫cenes might be attended perhaps with more improvement, than a journey to Rome, or Paris. Where manners are poli∫hed into vicious refinement, ∫implifying is the be∫t mode of improving; and the example of innocence is a more in∫tructive le∫∫on, than any that can be taught by arti∫ts, and literati.

But the∫e ∫cenes are too often the re∫ort of gay company, who are under no impre∫∫ions of this kind -- who have no ideas, but of extending the ∫phere of their amu∫ements -- or, of varying a life of di∫∫ipation. The grandeur of the country is not taken into the que∫tion: or, at lea∫t it is no otherwi∫e con∫idered, than as affording ∫ome new mode of plea∫urable enjoyment. Thus even the diver∫ions of Newmarket are introduced -- diver∫ions, one would imagine, more foreign to the nature of this country, than any other. A number of hor∫es are carried into the middle of a lake in a flat boat. A plug is drawn from the bottom: the boat ∫inks, and the hor∫es are left floating on the ∫urface. In dif-
ferent directions they make to land; and the hor∫e, which ∫oone∫t arrives, ∫ecures the prize.

poem.line: Strenua nos exercet inertia: navibus atque
Quadrigis petimus bene vivere. Quod petis, hic e∫t:
E∫t Ulubris; animus ∫i te non de∫icit æuus.

chap.title: Volume 2, Section XIX.
chap.head: SECT. XIX.
chap.p: HAVING ∫pent two hours at Patterdale, in refre∫hing our hor∫es, and in ∫urveying the beauty of it's ∫ituation; we left it with regret, and ∫et out for Penrith.
We had now the whole length of the lake to ∫kirt; part of which we had already traver∫ed in our rout from Gobray-park: but we felt no reluctance at taking a ∫econd view of it.

As we traver∫ed the two woody promontories, which we had pa∫∫ed in the morning, we had a grand exhibition of the middle reach of the lake; which, I have ob∫erved, is by far the longe∫t. Martindale-fell, ∫hooting into the water, which before adorned the left
of the land∫cape, now took it's ∫tation on the right. The left was compo∫ed of the high woody grounds about Gobray-park. -- In the center, the hills gently declining, formed a boundary at the bottom of the lake; ∫tretching far to the ea∫t. -- As a fore-ground, we had the woods, and rocks of the two promontories, through which we pa∫∫ed.
Such were the outlines, and compo∫ition of the view before us; but it's colouring was ∫till more exqui∫ite.

The ∫un was now de∫cending low, and ca∫t the broad ∫hades of evening athwart the land∫cape: while his beams, gleaming with yellow lu∫tre through the vallies, ∫pread over the inlightened ∫ummits of the mountains, a thou∫and lovely tints -- in ∫ober harmony, where ∫ome deep rece∫s was faintly ∫hadowed -- in ∫plendid hue, where jutting knolls, or promontories received the fuller radiance of the diverging ray. The air was ∫till: the lake one va∫t expan∫e of cry∫tal mirror. The mountain-∫hadows, which ∫ometimes give the water a deep, black hue (in many circum∫tances, extremely picture∫que;) were ∫oftened here
into a mild, blue tint, which ∫wept over half the ∫urface. The other half received the fair impre∫∫ion of every radiant form, that glowed around. The inverted land∫cape was touched in fainter colours, than the real one. Yet it it was more than laid in. It was almo∫t fini∫hed. The la∫t touches alone were wanting.

What an admirable ∫tudy for the pallet is ∫uch a ∫cene as this! infinitely beyond the camera's contracted bounds. Here you ∫ee nature in her full dimen∫ions. You are let into the very my∫tery -- into every artifice, of her pencil. In the reflected picture, you ∫ee the ground ∫he lays in -- the great effects pre∫erved -- and that veil of expre∫∫ive ob∫curity thrown over all, in which what is done, is done ∫o exqui∫itely, that if you wi∫h the fini∫hing touches, you wi∫h them only by the ∫ame inimitable hand that gave ∫ketch. Turn from the ∫hadow to the reality, and you have them. There the ob∫curity is detailed. The picture, and the ∫ketch reflect mutual graces on each other.

I dwell the longer on this ∫cene, becau∫e during five days, which we ∫pent in this romantic country, where we took a view of ∫o
many lakes, this was the only moment, in which we were ∫o fortunate, as to ∫ee the water in a pure, reflecting ∫tate. Partial exhibitions of this kind we had often met with: but here we were pre∫ented with a ∫cene of the utmo∫t magnificence.
Having examined this very lowly land∫cape, ∫o perfect both in compo∫ition, and in colouring, we proceeded in our rout along the lake.

We now re-entered Gobray-park; which afforded us, for near three miles, a great variety of beautiful ∫cenes on the left, compo∫ed of rocky, and broken-ground, fore∫t-trees, cop∫e-wood, and wooded-hills: while the lake, and mountains, who∫e ∫ummits were now glowing with the full ∫plendor of an evening ∫un, were a continued fund of varied entertainment on the right. The eye was both amu∫ed, and relieved by ∫urveying the two different modes of ∫cenery in ∫ucce∫∫ion: the broad ∫hades, and bright diver∫ified tints, of the di∫tant mountains, on one ∫ide; and the beautiful forms, and objects of the fore-ground, on the other.

One part of the fore-ground was marked with ∫ingular wildne∫s. It was a kind of rocky pa∫s near the margin of the lake; known, I believe, by the name Yew-cragg. If Cæ∫ar had ∫een it, it would have ∫truck him in a military light; and he would have de∫cribed it as a defile, "angu∫tum, & difficile, inter montem, & lacum; quo vix ∫inguli carri ducerentur. Mons alti∫∫imus impendebat; ut facile perpauci tra∫itum prohibere po∫∫ent."
chap.note: Cæs. Com. lib. I.
chap.p: But our imaginations were more amu∫ed with picture∫que, than military ideas. It ∫truck us therefore merely as an object of beauty. -- It's features were the∫e.

At a little di∫tance from the lake, the broken ∫ide of a mountain falls abruptly to the ground in two noble tiers of rock; both which are ∫hattered in every direction. This rocky ∫cene was ornamented in the riche∫t manner with wood. The road ∫kirted the lake; and between it and the rocks, all was rough, broken-ground, intangled with brakes, and impa∫∫ible. Among the rocks aro∫e a grove of fore∫t-trees
of various height, according to the inequality of the ground. Here and there, a few ∫cattered oaks, the fathers of the fore∫t, reared there peeled, and withered trunks acro∫s the glade; and ∫et off the vivid green of the more luxuriant trees. The deer ∫tarting from the brakes, as the feet of our hor∫es approached, added new wildne∫s to the native character of the view; while the ∫creams of a hernery (the wilde∫t notes in nature) allowed the ear to participate in the ∫cene.

The illumination of this grand ma∫s of rock was as intere∫ting, as the compo∫ition of it. It was over∫pread, when we ∫aw it, with a deep evening-∫hadow, with many a darker tint in the clo∫er rece∫∫es. A mild ray, ju∫t tinged with the blu∫h of a ∫etting ∫un, tipped the ∫ummits of the trees:

poem.line: While, ru∫hing through the branches, rifted cliffs
Dart their white heads, and glitter through the gloom.

chap.p:
Were a man di∫po∫ed to turn hermit, I know not where he could fix his abode more agreeably than here. The projecting rocks would
afford a ∫heltered ∫ituation for his cell; which would open to a ∫cene every way fitted for meditation. He might wander along the bottom of a mountain; and by the ∫ide of a lake, almo∫t unfrequented, except by the foot of curio∫ity, or of ∫ome ha∫ty ∫hepherd, ∫eeking for the ∫tragglers of his flock. Here he might enjoy the contemplation of nature in all her ∫implicity and grandeur. This ∫ingle ∫cene, the mere invirons of his cell, under all the varieties of light, and ∫hade -- ∫un-∫hine, and ∫torm -- morning, and evening, would it∫elf afford an inexhau∫ted fund of entertainment: while the ample tome expanded daily before his eye, would bani∫h the littlene∫s of life; and naturally impre∫s his mind with great ideas.

From this wild ∫cene we ∫oon entered another of a different ca∫t. It was a circular plain, about half a mile in diameter; ∫urrounded by mountains, with an opening to the lake. The plain was ∫mooth, but varied: the mountains, rather low, but rugged.

A valley, like this, con∫idered as a whole, has little picture∫que beauty. But a picture∫que eye will find it's objects even here. It will inve∫tigate the hills, and pick out ∫uch portions, as are mo∫t plea∫ing. The∫e it will form into back-grounds, and inrich the fore-ground (which can only be a plain) with cattle, trees, or other objects. -- Even ∫uch ∫imple ∫cenes, by the aid of judicious lights, may form pictures.

We had the ∫ame kind of ∫cene, ∫oon after, repeated, -- a circular valley, ∫urrounded with mountains, tho varied in many particulars from the other. Both however were equally unadored; and as bother were capable, by a few well-cho∫en accompaniments, of being formed into good pictures; ∫o likewise both were capable of being made delightful ∫cenes in nature, by a little judicious planting; tho we mu∫t ∫till have wi∫hed this planting to have had the growth of a century.

It is remarkable, that we find ∫carce any di∫po∫ition of ground, that belongs to a mountainous country, of which Virgil has not taken notice. The ∫cenes we now examined, he exactly de∫cribes: only he has given his hills the ornament of wood, which he knew was their mo∫t picture∫que dre∫s.

poem.line: ---- Tendit
Gramineum in campum, quem collibus undique curvis
Cingebant ∫ylvæ, mediaque in valle theatri
Circus erat. ----

chap.p: Not far from the∫e circular plains appears Gobray-hall; once the capital of the∫e domains; but now a neglected man∫ion. If ∫ituation can recommend a place, this ∫eems to enjoy one in great perfection. It ∫tands on high ground, with higher ∫till behind it. We did not ride up to the hou∫e; but it ∫eemed to command a noble view of the lake, and of the ∫cenery around it.

Nearly at the point where Ulle∫water makes it's la∫t curve, ∫tands the village of Water-
-Mullock; ∫ituated rather within the land. Through this place the road carried us to the la∫t reach of the lake; which is the lea∫t beautiful part. Here the hills grow ∫mooth, and lumpi∫h; and the country, at every ∫tep, lo∫es ∫ome of the wild ∫trokes of nature; and degenerates, if I may ∫o ∫peak, into cultivation.

At the end of the lake ∫tands Dunmallet, a remarkable hill, which overlooks the la∫t reach; but is it∫elf rather a di∫gu∫ting object. Shaped with conic exactne∫s; planted uniformly with Scotch firs; and cut as uniformly into walks verging to a center, it becomes a vile termination of a noble ∫cene. -- Once probably it was more intere∫ting; when the Roman eagle was planted, as it formerly was, upon it's ∫ummit -- when it's bold, rough ∫ides were in uni∫on with the objects around -- and a noble ca∫tle frowned, from it's precipices over the lake. This fortre∫s, who∫e ramparts may yet ea∫ily be traced, mu∫t once have been of con∫iderable importance, as it commanded all the avenues of the country.

We had now fini∫hed our view of Ulle∫water, which contains a wonderful variety of grand, and picture∫que ∫cenes, compre∫∫ed within a very narrow compa∫s. -- In one part, not far from Water-Mullock, the road carried us to the higher grounds, from whence we had a view of the whole lake, and all it's va∫t accompaniments together -- a troubled ∫ea of mountains; a broken ∫cene -- amu∫ing, but not picture∫que.

In our evening's ride, we had ∫kirted only one ∫ide of the lake; and wi∫hed our time would have allowed us to ∫kirt the other al∫o. It is probable the ∫outhern coa∫t might have afforded very noble di∫tant views of the woods, and rocks of Gobray-park, and the adjacent loft grounds.

We could have wi∫hed al∫o to have navigated the lake: for though views from the water, are in general le∫s beautiful, than the ∫ame views from the land, as they want the
advantage of a fore-ground, and al∫o bring the horizon too low; yet it is probable the grand reaches of this lake, and the woody promontories, round which the water winds, would have di∫played many beautiful pa∫∫ages from a boat.
chap.note: See Page. 96
chap.p: One view from the water, we heard much commended, that of the la∫t reach of the lake, towards the conic hill of Dunmallet. The ∫ides of the lake -- it's gliding away into the river Eamot, which carries it off -- Poolybridge, which is thrown over that river, at the bottom of the lake -- and the country beyond -- were all much extolled: but we could not conceive, that any views, at this end of the lake, could be comparable to what we had ∫een near the ∫hores of Patterdale: e∫pecially any views, in which the regular form of Dunmallet made ∫o con∫iderable a part.

It would have added al∫o to our amu∫ement, to have taken a view of the lake by moon-
light. For tho it is very difficult in painting to manage ∫o feeble an effu∫ion of light in ∫uch a manner, as, at the ∫ame time, to illuminate objects, and produce an effect; yet the reality, in ∫uch ∫cenes as the∫e, is attended often with a wonderful ∫olemnity and grandeur. That ∫hadowy form of great objects, which is ∫ometimes traced out by a ∫ilver thread, and ∫ometimes by a kind of bright ob∫curity on a darker ground, almo∫t oppre∫∫es the imagination with ∫ublime ideas. Great effects al∫o we ∫ometimes ∫ee of light and ∫hade, tho only faintly marked. In the ab∫ence of colour, the clair-ob∫cur is more ∫triking;

poem.line: ---- one expanded ∫heet of light
Diffu∫ing: while the ∫hades from rock to rock
Irregularly thrown, which ∫olemn gloom
Diver∫ify the whole. ----

chap.p:
I cannot leave the ∫cenes of Ulle∫water, without taking notice of an uncommon fi∫h, which frequents it's waters; and which is equally the object of the naturali∫t, and of the epicure. It is of the trout-∫pecies; beautifully clad in ∫cales of ∫ilver; firm, and finely
flavoured; and of ∫uch dimen∫ions, that it has ∫ometimes been known to weigh between thirty, and forty pounds.

Having now pa∫t the limits of the lake, we traver∫ed a very plea∫ant country in our road to Penrith, keeping the Eamot commonly within view on our right; and leaving on the left, the ruins of Dacre-ca∫tle, the ancient ∫eat of the noble family of that name.

No part of Cumberland is more inhabited by the genteeler families of the county, than this. Within the circumference of a few miles ∫tand many of their hou∫es; ∫ome of which have formerly been ca∫tles: but the road carried us in view only of two or three of them.

Before we arrived at Penrith, one of the∫e fortre∫∫es, which is known by the name of Penrith-ca∫tle, pre∫ented us with a very noble ruin; and under the mo∫t intere∫ting circum∫tances. The ∫un, which, through the length
of a ∫ummer-day, had befriended us with all his morning, noon, and evening powers; preparing now, with farewell ∫weet, to take his leave, gave us yet one more beautiful exhibition.

A grand broken arch pre∫ented it∫elf fir∫t in deep ∫hadow. Through the aperture appeared a part of the internal ∫tructure, thrown into per∫pective to great advantage; and illumined by the departing ray. Other fragments of the ∫hattered towers, and battlements were ju∫t touched with the ∫plendid tint: but the body of light re∫ted on tho∫e parts, which were ∫een through the ∫hadowed arch.

In the offskip, beyond the ca∫tle, aro∫e a hill, in ∫hadow likewi∫e; on the top of which ∫tood a lonely beacon. The windows an∫wering each other, we could ju∫t di∫cern the glowing horizon through them -- a circum∫tance, which however trivial in de∫cription, has a beautiful effect in land∫cape.

This beacon is a monument of tho∫e tumultuous times, which preceded the union; and the only monument of the kind now remaining in the∫e parts; though ∫uch beacons were formerly ∫tationed over the whole country;
and could ∫pread intelligence, in a few ∫econds, from one end of it to the other.

At this later day the∫e ca∫tles and po∫ts of alarm, adorning the country, they once defended, rai∫e plea∫ing reflections on a compari∫on of pre∫ent times with pa∫t -- tho∫e turbulent times, when no man could ∫leep in ∫afety unle∫s ∫ecured by a fortre∫s. In war he feared the inva∫ion of an open enemy: and in peace a mi∫chief ∫till more formidable, the ravages of banditti; with whom the country was always at that time infe∫ted. The∫e wretches were compo∫ed of the outlaws from both nations; and inhabiting the fa∫tne∫∫es of the bogs, and mountains, u∫ed to ∫ally out, and plunder in all directions.
Penrith is a neat town, ∫ituated not unplea∫antly, under mountains; and in the neighbourhood of lakes.

In the church-yard we ∫aw an ancient monument, which has occa∫ioned much ∫peculation among antiquarians. It con∫i∫ts of two rough pillars, with four ∫emicircular ∫tones, fixed in the ground between them. Dr. Todd, an antiquarian of the la∫t age, found out four
wild-boards, and other ingenious devices, on the different parts of this monument. We examined it with attention: but could not find even the mo∫t di∫tant re∫emblance of any form in nature. The whole ∫urface ∫eemed to be nothing more than a piece of rough chi∫∫el work. -- In the church, which is a hand∫ome, plain ∫tructure, is placed a ∫tone, recording the ravages of the plague among the ∫everal towns of this neighbourhood, in the year 1598.
