As we leave Penrith, which is within twenty miles of Carli∫le, we enter that va∫t wa∫te, called Inglewood-fore∫t, through which we rode at lea∫t nine miles; in all which ∫pace there is ∫care a tree to be ∫een: and yet were it well planted, as it once probably was, many parts of it might be admired: for the ground makes bold and noble ∫wells; the back ∫cenery is compo∫ed of a grand ∫weep of mountains; and on the left, are di∫tant views into a cultivated country.

The mountains, which adorn the∫e ∫cenes, are the ∫ame we ∫aw, as we left Ke∫wick; only the more northern part of that circular
chain is now turned towards us. In this view, the ridge of Saddle-back a∫∫umes that ∫hape, from which it derives it's appellation.

That part of Inglewood-fore∫t, which lies neare∫t the town, is known by the name of Penrith-fell, con∫i∫ting of rough, and hilly grounds. One of the highe∫t hills is occupied by the beacon, of which we had a di∫tant view, as we examined the ruins of Penrith-ca∫tle.

On this ∫pot, in the year 1715, the Cumberland militia a∫∫embled to oppo∫e the rebels in their march to the ∫outh. But a militia without di∫cipline, is never formidable. The whole body fled, as the van of the rebels appeared marching round an oppo∫ite hill.

Nicol∫on, bi∫hop of Carli∫le, a ∫trenuous man, who had been very in∫trumental in bringing them together, and now attended their march; was ∫o chagrined, and mortified at their behaviour, that in a fit of ob∫tinate vexation, he would not quit the field. The
enemy was coming on apace. His ∫ervants rode up to the coach for orders. The bi∫hop ∫at mute with indignation. All thoughts of him∫elf were lo∫t in the public di∫grace. His coachman however, who∫e feelings were le∫s delicate, thinking the management of affairs, in this interruption of government, now devolved upon him, la∫hed his hor∫es, and carried his ma∫ter off the field.

On the verge of the fore∫t, at a place called Plumpton, a large Roman ∫tation (or ∫tative camp) runs a quarter of a mile, on the right. You trace the ground broken variou∫ly, where tents, kitchens, and earthen tables probably ∫tood, not unlike the ve∫tiges of a modern encampment. On the left appear the lines of a ∫ort of con∫iderable dimen∫ions, about one hundred and fifty yards ∫quare, which was once the citadel of this military colony. The ramparts, and ditches may ea∫ily be traced on every ∫ide.

The great road indeed, which we travelled, is intirely Roman; and is laid almo∫t by a line over the fore∫t. You ∫eldom ∫ee a winding road of Roman con∫truction. Their ∫urvey-
ors, and pioneers had no idea of the line of beauty; nor ∫tood in reverence of any inclo∫ures; but always took the ∫horte∫t cut; making the Appian way the model of all their provincial roads.

At Ragmire, about a mile farther, where the road cro∫∫es a bog, large wooden frameworks, yet uninjured by time, were lately dug up; which the Romans had laid, as a foundation for their cau∫ey, over that un∫table ∫urface.
On leaving Inglewood-fore∫t, the road enters an enclo∫ed country, in which is little variety, and ∫carce an intere∫ting object, till we arrive at Carli∫le.

The approach to that city, from the ri∫ing ground, near the little village of Hereby, is grand. The town, which terminates a vi∫ta of a mile in length, takes a very compact form; in which no part is ∫een, but what makes a hand∫ome appearance. The ∫quare, and ma∫∫y tower of the ca∫tle ri∫es on the right: in the middle, the cathedral ri∫es ∫till
higher; and contiguous to it, on the left, appear the round towers of the citadel; which was built by Henry VIII, in the form of all his ca∫tles on the Hamp∫hire, and Kenti∫h coa∫ts.
The beauty however of this approach is ∫oon lo∫t. As we de∫cend the hill from Hereby, the town ∫inks into the in∫ignificance of it's invirons.
The entrance is ∫till beautiful; the road winding to the gate round the towers of the citadel.

chap.title: Volume 2, Section XX.
chap.head: SECT. XX.
chap.p: FEW towns offer a fairer field to an antiquary, than Carli∫le. It's origin, and hi∫tory, are remote, curious and ob∫cure. It was unque∫tionably a place of con∫equence in Roman times. Severus's wall ju∫t includes it in the Briti∫h pale. The ve∫tiges of that barrier run within half a mile of it's gates; and it probably figured fir∫t under the character of a fortre∫s, on that celebrated rampart.

In after ages it had it's ∫hare ∫ucce∫∫ively in the hi∫tory of Saxons, Danes, and Cots; and during the revolutions of the∫e ∫everal nations, was the ∫cene of every vici∫∫itude of war. It hath been frequently be∫ieged, pillaged, burnt, and rebuilt. Once it lay buried in it's ruins for the ∫pace of two centuries. Rufus brought it again into exi∫tence. The pre∫ent town is founded on the ve∫tiges of
former towns; which in many parts have rai∫ed the ground within, nearly to the height of the walls. The foundations of a hou∫e are rarely dug without di∫turbing the ruins of ∫ome other hou∫e. It has been the re∫idence; and it has been the pri∫on of kings. An old a∫h-tree is ∫till ∫hewn, near the gate of the ca∫tle; which is ∫aid to have been planted by the unfortunate Mary of Scotland, who ∫pent a part of her captivity in this fortre∫s; whither ∫he was ∫oon brought, after her landing at Workington. Many princes al∫o have ∫hed their royal favours on this ancient town; and made it's fortifications their care.

Now all it's military honours are di∫graced. Northern commotions are no longer dreaded. It's gates ∫tand always open; and it's walls, the object of no farther attention, are falling fa∫t into ruin. The firing of a morning and an evening gun from the ca∫tle, which was the la∫t garri∫on-form that remained, hath been di∫continued the∫e ∫ix years, to the great regret of the country around, who∫e hours of labour it regulated.

But I mean not to enter into the hi∫tory of Carli∫le: it concerns me only as an object of beauty. Within it's walls indeed it contains little that de∫erves notice. The ca∫tle is heavy in all it's parts, as the∫e fabrics commonly are. It is too perfect to afford much plea∫ure to the picture∫que eye; excepts as a remote object, ∫oftened by di∫tance. Hereafter, when it's ∫hattered towers, and buttre∫∫es, give a lightne∫s to it's parts, it may adorn ∫ome future land∫cape.

The cathedral de∫erves ∫till le∫s attention. It is a heavy, Saxon pile; and there is nothing about it, that is beautiful; except the ea∫t-window, which is a rich, and very elegant piece of Gothic ramification.

The fratry, as it is called, or chapter-hou∫e, in the abbey, is the only building that de∫erves notice. On one ∫ide, where it has formerly been connected with the cloy∫ters, it has little beauty: but on the other, next the deanery, it's proportions and ornaments are elegant. It ∫eems to be of that ∫tyle of architecture, which prevailed rather before the two later Henries.

But thought Carli∫le furni∫hes little amu∫ement within it's walls; yet it adds great beauty, as a di∫tant object, to the country around. Few towns enjoy a better ∫ituation. It ∫tands on a ri∫ing ground, in the mid∫t of meadows, watered by two con∫iderable rivers; which flowing on different ∫ides of the city, unite a little below it; and form the whole ground-plot, on which it ∫tands, into a kind of penin∫ula. Beyond the meadows, the ground ri∫es, in almo∫t all parts, at different di∫tances.

The meadows around it, e∫pecially along the banks of the river Eden, want only a little more woods to make them very beautiful. In high floods, which happen two or three times in the cour∫e of a winter, they exhibit a very grand ∫cene. The town appears ∫tanding out, like a promontory in the mid∫t of a va∫t lake.

The ∫hort ∫iege which Carli∫le ∫u∫tained in the rebellion of the year 1745, together with ∫ome awkward circum∫tances that attended it, threw
a general odium upon the town; and many believed, among whom was the late duke of Cumberland, that it was very ill-affected to the government. No ∫u∫picion was ever more unju∫t. I dare take upon me to ∫ay, there were ∫carce half a dozen people in the whole place, who wi∫hed well to the rebellion.
The following anecdote, known but to few; and totally unknown, till many years after the event, will throw ∫ome light on it's ha∫ty ∫urrender; which brought it into ∫uch di∫grace.

When the rebels came before it, it was garri∫oned only by two companies of invalids; and two raw, undi∫ciplined regiments of militia. General Wade lay at Newca∫tle with a con∫iderable force: and the governor of Carli∫le informing him, how unprovided he was, begged a reinforcement. The ∫ingle hope of this relief, enabled the gentlemen of the country, who commanded the militia, to keep their men under arms.

In the mean time the rebels were known to be as ill-prepared for an attack, as the town was for a defence. They had now lain a week before it; and found it was impracticable, for
want of artillery, to make any attempt. They feared al∫o an interruption from general Wade: and be∫ides, were unwilling to delay any longer their march towards London. Under the∫e difficulties, they had come to a re∫olution to abandon their de∫ign.

At this critical time the governor of Carli∫le received a letter from general Wade, informing him, he was ∫o circum∫tanced, that he could not po∫∫ibly ∫end the reinforcement that had been de∫ired. This mortifying intelligence, tho not publickly known, was however communicated to the principal officers; and to ∫ome others; among whom was a bu∫y attorney, who∫e name was H----s.

H----s was then addre∫∫ing a young lady, the daughter of Mr. F----r, a gentleman of the country; and to a∫∫i∫t his cau∫e, and give him∫elf con∫equence with his intended father in law, he whi∫pered to him, among his other political ∫ecrets, the di∫appointment from general Wade.

The whi∫per did not re∫t here. F----r frequented a club in the neighbourhood; where ob∫erving (in the jollity of a chearful evening) that only friends were pre∫ent, he gave his company the information, he had ju∫t received from H----s.

There was in that company, one S----d, a gentleman of ∫ome fortune near Carli∫le, who, tho a known papi∫t, was however at that time, thought to be of very intire affection to the government. This man, po∫∫e∫∫ed of ∫uch a ∫ecret, and wi∫hing for an opportunity to ∫erve a cau∫e, which he favoured in his heart, took hor∫e that very night, after he left the club-room, and rode directly to the rebel-camp; which he found under orders to break up the next morning. He was carried immediately to the Duke of Perth, and others of the rebel leaders, to whom he communicated his intelligence; and a∫∫ured them, they might expect a mutiny in the town, if they continued before it, one day longer. Counter orders were immediately i∫∫ued; and the next day the Cumberland and We∫tmoreland militia, being under no di∫cipline, began to mutiny, and di∫per∫e; and the town defended now only by two companies of invalids, was thought no longer tenable. The governor was tried by a court-martial; and acquitted: and nobody ∫uppo∫ed that either the militia-officers, or their men, were impre∫∫ed by an motive wor∫e than fear.

In ∫o variegated a country, as England, there are few parts, which do not afford many plea∫ing, and picture∫que ∫cenes. The mo∫t probably way of finding them, as I ob∫erved a little above, is to follow the cour∫e of the rivers. About their banks we ∫hall generally find the riche∫t ∫cenery, which the country can produce. This rule we followed in the few excur∫ions which we had time to make from Carli∫le: and fir∫t we took a view of the river Cauda.

Near the town this river is broken into ∫o many ∫treams; and throws up, every where, ∫o many barren beds of pebbles, that there is no great beauty in this part of it's cour∫e. But above, where higher banks confine it's impetuo∫ity, it becomes more intere∫ting. The vales of Sebergham and Dal∫ton, we heard much commended. The former we did not vi∫it: the latter we followed with great plea∫ure, along it's winding cour∫e, for many miles; and found our∫elves often in the mid∫t of very beautiful ∫cenes; the river being ∫hut up ∫ometimes
by clo∫e, and lofty banks, and ∫ometimes flowing through meadows edged with wood.

Among other ∫ituations on the Cauda we were much plea∫ed with that of Ro∫e-ca∫tle, the ∫eat of the bi∫hop of Carli∫le; which ∫tands on a gentle ri∫e, in a wide part of the vale; the river winding round it, in a ∫emi-circular form, at about half a mile's di∫tance. The ground between the ca∫tle, and the river, con∫i∫ts of beautiful meadows; and beyond the river, the lofty bank, which winds with it, is well-planted; and forms a ∫weep of hanging wood. The ca∫tle compo∫ed of ∫quare towers, tho no object on the ∫pot, is a good ornament to the ∫cene.

Between Ro∫e-ca∫tle and Wigton the country abounds with the relicks of Roman incampments. At a place, called Chalk-cliff (which, by the way, is a cliff of red ∫tone) this lefionary in∫cription is engraved in the native rock.

poem.line: LEG II AVG
MILITES FEC.
COH III COH IIII

chap.p: From the Cauda, our next excur∫ion was along the Eden. On the banks of this river, we were informed of many intere∫ting ∫cenes. At Kirko∫wal, and Nunnery particularly, the country was repre∫ented as very engaging; but Corby-ca∫tle, about five miles from Carli∫le, was the only place above the town, which we had time to vi∫it.

At Wetherall we ferried over the river; and landed under the ca∫tle, which ∫tands on the edge of a lofty bank. This bank ∫tretches at lea∫t three miles along the cour∫e of the river, partly below, but chiefly above, the ca∫tle. I give it it's ancient title; tho it is now a mere modern hou∫e, without the lea∫t ve∫tige of it's primeval dignity. Below the ca∫tle, the bank is rocky, and falls precipitately into the water: above, it makes a more gentle de∫cent; and leaves an edging, which, in ∫ome parts, ∫preads into little winding meads, and where it is narrowe∫t, is broad enough for a hand∫ome walk. The whole bank, both above, and below the ca∫tle, is covered with wood; large oak, and a∫h; and in many places the ∫cenery is rocky al∫o. But the rocks are not of the grey kind,
∫tained with a variety of different tints -- the ∫axa circumlita mu∫co; but incline rather to a ∫andy red, which is not the mo∫t coale∫cing hue. They give however great ∫pirit, and beauty to the ∫cene.

The bank of the river, oppo∫ite to the ca∫tle, is likewi∫e high; in many parts woody; in others affording an intermixture of wood, and lawn. Here ∫tand the ruins of Wetherall-abbey; tho little more of it is left, than a ∫quare tower, which is ∫ome ornament, tho no very picture∫que one, to the ∫cene. The∫e ruins were once exten∫ive, and, I have heard, beautiful; but the dean and chapter of Carli∫le, to whom the place belongs, ∫ome years ago carried off the ∫tones, with more œconomy than ta∫te, to build a prebendal hou∫e.

On this ∫ide of the river al∫o, an object pre∫ents it∫elf, known by the name of Wetherall-∫afeguard, which is e∫teemed a great curio∫ity. It con∫i∫ts of three chambers cut in the ∫olid rock, which being in this part, almo∫t a precipice, the acce∫s to the∫e chambers is very difficult. It is ∫uppo∫ed to have been an appendage of the abbey; where the monks, in times of di∫order, ∫ecreted their wealth. Some antiquarians ∫uppo∫e it to have been
inhabited by a religious devotee, and call it St. Con∫tantine's cell. It is rather a curious place, than any great ornament to the ∫cene.

To the natural advantages of the ∫cenery about Corby-ca∫tle, the improvements of art have added little. The late proprietor, who had ∫een nothing him∫elf; and imagined from the re∫ort of ∫trangers to ∫ee the beauty of his ∫ituation, that they admired his ta∫te, re∫olved to make Corby one of the mo∫t ∫umptuous placed in Europe. With this view, he ∫cooped his rocks into grottos -- fabricated a ca∫cade, con∫i∫ting of a lofty flight of regular ∫tone ∫teps -- cut a ∫traight walk through his woods, along the banks of the river; at the end of which he reared a temple: and being re∫olved to add every ornament, that expence could procure, he hired an arti∫t of the country, at four-pence a day (for labour was then cheap) to make ∫tatues. Numberle∫s were the works of this genius. Diana, Neptune, Polyphemus, Nymphs and Satyrs in abundance, and a variety of other figures, became ∫oon the ornaments of the woods; and met the eye of the ∫pectator wherever he turned. A pun∫ter, who was remarkable for making only one good pun in his life, made it here. Pointing to one of the∫e
∫trange figures, he called it a ∫atyr upon the place.

But the ta∫te of the pre∫ent age hath de∫troyed the pride of the la∫t. The pre∫ent proprietor hath done well. The rocks indeed ∫cooped into holes, can never be re∫tored to their native ∫implicity, and grandeur. Their bold projections are for ever effaced. Nor could a century re∫tore tho∫e trees which were rooted up to form the vi∫ta. But the ∫tatues, like the ancient ∫culpture of the Egyptians, are now no more. The temple is going fa∫t into ruins and the ca∫cade (∫o frivolous, if it had even been good in it's kind, on the banks of a great, and rapid river) is now overgrown with thickets. The old line of the walk could not ea∫ily be effaced: but a new one, beyond the temple, is carried on, which follows naturally the cour∫e of the river. And indeed this part of the walk admits more beauty, than any other; for the varieties of ground are greater; the bank, and edging of meadow, are more irregular; and the river more ∫inuous.

The path having conducted us along the river, through the∫e plea∫ing irregularities about two miles from the ca∫tle, climbs to higher grounds, and returns through and beautiful ∫heep walks, which lie on the ∫ides, and ∫ummit of the banks.
Through the whole of this walk, both at the top, and bottom, are many plea∫ant views; but they are all of the more confined kind.

Many parts of this walk were wrought by the manual labour of the prie∫t of the family, which is a popi∫h branch of the Howards. He belongs to an order, which injoins it's members to work in the ground ∫o many hour a day; laying them, with admirable wi∫dom, under the whole∫ome nece∫∫ity of acquiring health and ∫pirits. I am per∫uaded, that if a ∫tudious man were obliged to dig three or four hours a day, he would ∫tudy the better, during the remaining part of it. We had been recommended to the civilities of this eccle∫ia∫tic (the family being then in France,) and found him at work in the garden. He received us politely; and di∫covered the manners of a gentleman, under the garb of a day-labourer, without the lea∫t apology for his dre∫s, and occupation. There is ∫omething very plea∫ing
in the ∫implicity and manline∫s of not being a∫hamed of the nece∫∫ary functions of any ∫tate, which we have made our option in life. -- This eccle∫ia∫tic ∫ucceeded Father Wal∫h, who has lately engaged the attention of the public. -- I have dwelt the longer on this ∫cene, as it is the mo∫t admired one in Cumberland.

From Corby-ca∫tle to Warwick, which lies about two miles nearer Carli∫le, on the banks of the ∫ame river, the road is beautiful. Many admire the ∫ituation of Warwick al∫o. It ∫eems to be a ∫weet, retired ∫cene; but we had not time to view it.

The antiquarian's eye is immediately caught here by the pari∫h-church; the chancel of which, forming the ∫egment of a circle, and being pierced with ∫mall lancet-windows, ∫hews at once, that it is of Norman origin. Tho every other mark were obliterated, he will tell you, that this is evidence ∫ufficient of it's antiquity.

chap.title: Volume 2, Section XXI.
chap.head: SECT. XXI.
chap.p: HAVING ∫een as much of the river Eden, above Carli∫le, as our time would allow, we made our next excur∫ion towards it's mouth, where Brugh-mar∫h attracted our attention. In our way we had many plea∫ing river views.

Brugh-mar∫h lies at the extremity of the Engli∫h border; running up as far as Solway-frith, which, in this part, divides England from Scotland. It is a va∫t extended plain, flat as the ∫urface of a quiet ocean. I do not remember that land, every gave me before ∫o va∫t an idea of ∫pace. The idea of this kind, which ∫uch ∫cenes as Sali∫bury-Plain ∫ugge∫ts, is much le∫s pure. The inequality of the ground there, ∫ets bounds to the idea. It is
the ocean in a ∫torm; in which the idea of exten∫ion is greatly broken, and intercepted by the turbulence of the waves. Brugh-mar∫h indeed gives us the idea of ∫olid water, rather than of land, if we except only the colour:

poem.line: --- Interminable meads,
And va∫t ∫avannahs, where the wandering eye
Unfixt, is in a verdant ocean lo∫t.

chap.p:
Brugh-mar∫h is one of tho∫e extended plains, (only more exten∫ive, than ∫uch plains commonly are) from which the ∫ea, in a cour∫e of ages, hath retired. It is difficult to compute it's limits. It ranges many leagues, in every direction, from a centre (for ∫pace ∫o diffu∫e a∫∫umes of cour∫e a circular appearance) without a hedge, or even a bu∫h, to intercept it's bounds; till it ∫oftens into the azure mountains of the horizon. Nothing indeed, but mountains, can circum∫cribe ∫uch a ∫cene. All inferior boundaries of woods, and ri∫ing grounds are lo∫t. On the Engli∫h ∫ide it is bounded by that circular chain, in the heart of Cumberland, in which Skiddaw is pre-eminent. Nothing intermediate appears. On the Scotch ∫ide it's cour∫e is interrupted, through the ∫pace of a few leagues, by Solway-
frith; which ∫preads, when the tide is at ebb, into a va∫t ∫tretch of ∫and. The plain however is ∫till pre∫erved: and having pa∫∫ed this ∫andy ob∫truction, it changes it's hue again into vivid green, and ∫tretches far and wide into the Scotch border, till it's progre∫s at length is ∫topped by the mountains of Galloway, and Nidd∫dale. This exten∫ion is as much as the eye can well comprehend. Had the plain been boundle∫s, like an Arabian de∫ert, I know not whether it would not have lo∫t that idea of ∫pace, which ∫o va∫t a circum∫cription gives it.

The whole area of Brugh-mar∫h, (which from it's denomination we ∫hould ∫uppo∫e to be ∫wampy,) is every where perfectly firm; and the turf, ∫oft, bright, and pure. Scarce a weed rears it's head. Nothing appears of ∫tatelier growth, than a mu∫hroom, which ∫preads here in very luxuriant knots.
This va∫t plain is far from being a de∫ert wa∫te. Innumerable herds of cattle pa∫ture at large in it's rich verdure, and range, as in a ∫tate of nature.

But tho the primary idea, which this ∫cene pre∫ents, ari∫es purely from ∫pace, and is therefore an idea rather grand than picture∫que; yet is it not totally incapable of picture∫que embelli∫hment. It is true, it wants almo∫t every ingredient of land∫cape; on the fore-ground, it wants objects to pre∫erve the keeping; and in the offskip, that profu∫ion of little parts, which in a ∫cene of cultivation gives richne∫s to di∫tance. In treating therefore a ∫ubject of this kind on canvas, recour∫e mu∫t be had to adventitious objects. Cattle come mo∫t naturally to hand; which being ∫tationed, in various groups, at different di∫tances, may ∫erve both as a fore-ground to the land∫cape, and as a gage to the per∫pective.

Brugh-mar∫h is farther remarkable for having been the ∫cene of one of the greate∫t cata∫trophes of the Engli∫h hi∫tory -- the death of Edward the I. Here, after the third revolt of Scotland, that prince, drew together the mo∫t pui∫∫ant army, which England had ever ∫een. The Scots from their borders, ∫aw the whole plain whitened with tents: but they
knew not how nearly their deliverance approached. The greate∫t events generally arrive unlooked for. They ∫aw a delay; and afterwards a confu∫ion in the mighty ho∫t before them; but they heard not, till three days after, that the ∫oul, and ∫pirit of the enterprize was gone; and that their great adver∫ary lay breathle∫s in his camp.

Edward had been taken ill at Carli∫le; where he had met his parliament. But neither di∫ea∫e, nor age (for he was now near ∫eventy) could repre∫s his ardour. Tho he could not mount his hor∫e, he ordered him∫elf to be carried in a litter to the camp; where the troops received him with acclamations of joy. But it was ∫hort-lived. The motion had irritated his di∫order into a violent dy∫entery; which immediately carried him off.

The Engli∫h borderers long revered the memory of a prince, who had ∫o often cha∫ti∫ed an enemy, they hated: and in gratitude reared a pillar to his name; which ∫till te∫tifies the ∫pot, on which he died. It ∫tands rather on
the edge of the mar∫h, and bears this ∫imple in∫cription.

poem.line: MEMORIÆ ÆternÆ
EDVARDI,
REGIS ANGLIÆ LONGÈ CLARISSIMI,
QUI, IN BELLI APPARATU
CONTRA SCOTOS OCCUPATUS,
HIC IN CASTRIS OBIIT,
7 JULII A. D. 1307.

chap.p: Among other places in the neighbourhood of Carli∫le, we made an excur∫ion into Gills-land, with an intention chiefly to ∫ee Naworth-ca∫tle, the vale and ruins of the Abbey of Lanerco∫t; and the ruins of Scaleby-ca∫tle.

As we leave Carli∫le, along the great military road to Newca∫tle, the view of the river Eden from Stanwix-bank, is very plea∫ing. The curve it de∫cribes; the beautiful meadows it winds through; and the mountains, which clo∫e the ∫cene, make all together a very amu∫ing combination of objects. Wood only is wanting.

On cro∫∫ing the river Irthing, about ∫even miles from Carli∫le, the country, which was before unplea∫ing, becomes rich, and intere∫ting. Here we enter the barony of Gill∫land, an exten∫ive di∫trict, which con∫i∫ts, in this part, of a great variety of hill, and dale. The hills are ∫andy, bleak, and unplea∫ant: but the vallies, which are commonly of the contracted kind, are beautiful. They are generally woody, and each of them watered by ∫ome little bu∫y ∫tream. -- From the∫e vallies, or gills, (as the country-people call them,) with which the whole barony abounds, Campden ∫uppo∫es it to have taken the name of Gill∫land.

On a delightful knoll, gently gliding into a ∫inuous gill, ∫urrounded with full-grown oak, and overlooking the vale of Lanerco∫t, ∫tands Naworth-ca∫tle. The hou∫e, which con∫i∫ts of two large ∫quare towers, united by a main body, is too regular to be beautiful, unle∫s thrown into per∫pective. It was formerly one of tho∫e fortified places, in which
the nobility and gentry of the borders were obliged to live, in tho∫e times of confu∫ion, which preceded the union. And indeed the whole internal contrivance of this ca∫tle appears calculated either to keep an enemy out; or to elude his ∫earch, if he ∫hould happen to get in. The idea of a comfortable dwelling has been totally excluded. The ∫tate-rooms are few, and ordinary: but the little apartments, and hiding holes, acce∫∫ible only by dark pa∫∫ages, and blind ∫tair-ca∫es, are innumerable. Many of the clo∫e rece∫∫es, which it contains, are probably at this time, unknown. Nothing indeed can mark in ∫tronger colours the fears, and jealou∫ies, and caution of tho∫e times, than the internal ∫tructure of one of the∫e ca∫tles.

Naworth-ca∫tle was formerly the capital man∫ion of the barons of Gill∫land; who, at ∫o great a di∫tance from court, and ∫eated in a country, at that time, untamed by law, are ∫aid to have exerci∫ed very extraordinary powers. The Lord William Howard, who is remembered by the name of bald Willy, is ∫till the object of invective for his acts of tyranny. His pri∫ons are ∫hewn; and the ∫ite of his gibbets; where, in the phra∫e of
the country, he would head, and hang with out judge, or jury. -- But it is probable, that his memory is injured. He acted under a ∫tanding commi∫∫ion of oyer, and terminer from Elizabeth; and was one of tho∫e bold ∫pirits, which are nece∫∫ary to repre∫s the violence of lawle∫s times. Many acts of power undoubtedly he committed: but his difficult ∫ituation compelled him. This part of the kingdom was mo∫t hara∫∫ed by tho∫e troops of mi∫chievous banditti; whom I have ju∫t had occa∫ion to mention. They were a numerous, and not an ill-regulated, body; acting under leaders, whom a ∫pirit of enterprize rai∫ed to power. The∫e mi∫creants, in times even of profounde∫t peace, called for all the warine∫s and activity of the chiefs of the country. Sometimes they would plunder in large bodies; and ∫ometimes in little pilfering bands. When they were taken in the fact; or, as it was called, by the bloody hand, they were put to in∫tant death. In other ca∫es a jury impannelled.

The active chief, who gave occa∫ion to this digre∫∫ion, ∫eems to have lived in as much terror him∫elf, as he ∫pread among others. He had contrived a ∫ort of citadel in his own
ca∫tle; a room, which is ∫till ∫hewn, with an iron door, where he con∫tantly ∫lept, and where his armour lies ru∫ting to this day. From him the earls of Carli∫le are de∫cended; and have been, in succe∫∫ion, the proprietors of Naworth-ca∫tle.

As we left this old fortre∫s, and de∫cended the hill towards the ruins of the abbey of Lanerco∫t, which lie about two miles farther, the whole vale, in which they are ∫eated, opened before us. It is e∫teemed one of the ∫weete∫t ∫cenes in this country; and indeed we found it ∫uch. It's area is about half a mile in breadth, and two or three miles in length, con∫i∫ting of one ample ∫weep. The ∫ides, which are gentle declivities, are covered thick with wood, in which larger depredations have been lately made, than are con∫i∫tent with picture∫que beauty. -- At the di∫tant end of the vale, where the woods appear to unite, the river Irthing enters; which is con∫iderable enough, tho divided into two channels, to be fully adequate to the ∫cene. -- The banks of the river, and indeed the whole area of the vale, are ∫prinkled with clumps,
and ∫ingle trees; which have a good effect in breaking the lines, and regular continuity of the ∫ide-∫creens; and in hiding, here and there, the cour∫e of the river; and e∫pecially the bridges, which would otherwi∫e be too bare and formal.

Near that extremity of the vale, which is oppo∫ite to Naworth-ca∫tle, lies the abbey. At a di∫tance it forms a good object, ri∫ing among the woods. As you approach, it begins to rai∫e a di∫appointment: and the ∫pot, it is but an unplea∫ing ruin. The whole is a heavy, Saxon pile; compre∫∫ed together without any of that airy lightne∫s, which accompanies the Gothic. Scarce one detached fragment appears in any point of view. The tower is low, and without either form, or ornament; and one of the great ailes is modernized into an awkward pari∫h-church. The only beautiful part of the whole is the ea∫t end. It is compo∫ed of four broken ailes; every wall of which con∫i∫ts of two tiers of arches, affording, a very unu∫ual appearance; and at the ∫ame time a very amu∫ing confu∫ion, from the uncommon multiplication of ∫o many arches, and pillars. -- This part of the abbey ∫eeems to have been a ∫eparate
chapel; or perhaps an oratory belonging to the noble family of Dacre, which had once po∫∫e∫∫ions in the∫e parts. Here lie the remains of ∫everal ancient chiefs of that hou∫e; who∫e ∫epulchral honours are now almo∫t intirely obliterated. Their blazoned arms, and Gothic tombs, many of which are ∫umptuous, are ∫o matted with briars, and thi∫tles, that even the foot of curio∫ity is kept at a di∫tance.
Except the∫e remains of the abbey-church no other parts of this ancient mona∫tery are now left; except an old gateway; and a ∫quare building, patched into a farm-hou∫e, which has no beauty.
In returning to Carli∫le we pa∫∫ed through the valley of Cambeck, which contains ∫ome plea∫ing ∫cenery; and a very con∫iderable Roman ∫tation, on a high bank at Ca∫tle-∫teeds.

Rivers often pre∫ent uys with very moral analogies; their characters greatly re∫embling tho∫e of men. The violent, the re∫tle∫s, the , the active, the ∫luggi∫h, the gentle, , and many other epithets, be- to both. The little ∫tream,
which divides the valley of Cambeck, ∫ugge∫ted the analogy. It's whole cour∫e is marked with acts of violence. In every part you ∫ee heaps of barren ∫and, and gravel, which in it's furious moods it has thrown up, ∫ometimes on one ∫ide, and ∫ometimes on another; de∫troying every where the little ∫cenes of beauty, and plots of cultivation.
About three miles further ∫tand the ruins of Scaleby-ca∫tle. This was another of tho∫e fortified hou∫es, which are ∫o frequent in this country.

It ∫tands, as ca∫tles rarely do, on a flat; and yet, tho it's ∫ite be ill-adapted to any modes of defence, it has been a place of more than ordinary ∫trength. Rocks, knolls, and bold, projecting promontories, on which ca∫tle u∫ually ∫tand, ∫ugge∫t various advantages of ∫ituation; and generally determine the kind of ∫tructure. On a flat, the engineer was at liberty to choo∫e his own. Every part was alike open to a∫∫ault.

He fir∫t drew two circular motes round the ∫pot he de∫igned to fortify: the circumference of the outward circle was about a mile.
The earth, thrown out of the∫e two motes, which were broad and deep, ∫eems to have been heaped up at the centre, where there is a con∫iderable ri∫e. On this was built the ca∫tle, which was entered by two draw-bridges; and defended by a high tower, and a very lofty wall.

At pre∫ent, one of the motes only remains. The other is filled up; but may ∫till be traced. The ca∫tle is more perfect, than ∫uch buildings commonly are. The walls are very intire; and great part of the tower, which is ∫quare, is ∫till left. It pre∫erved it's perfect form, till the civil wars of the la∫t century; when the ca∫tle, in too much confidence of it's ∫trength, ∫hut it's gates again∫t Cromwell, then marching into Scotland; who made it a monument of his vengeance.

What ∫hare of picture∫que genius Cromwell might have, I know not. Certain however it is, that no man, ∫ince Henry the eighth, has contributed more to adorn this country with picture∫que ruins. The difference between the∫e two ma∫ters lay chiefly in the ∫tyle of ruins, in which they compo∫ed. Henry adorned his land∫capes with the ruins of abbeys; Cromwell, with tho∫e ca∫tles.
I have ∫een many pieces by this ma∫ter, executed in a very grand ∫tyle; but ∫eldom a finer monument of his ma∫terly hand than this. He has rent the tower, and demoli∫hed two of it's ∫ides; the edges of the other two he has ∫hattered into broken lines. The cha∫m di∫covers the whole plan of the internal ∫tructure -- the ve∫tiges of the ∫everal ∫tories -- the in∫ertion of the arches, which ∫upported them -- the windows for ∫peculation; and the brea∫twork for a∫∫ault.

The walls of this ca∫tle are uncommonly magnificent. They are not only of great height, but of great thickne∫s; and defended by a large ba∫tion; which appears to be of more modern workman∫hip. The greate∫t part of them is chambered within, and wrought into ∫ecret rece∫∫es. A ma∫∫y portcullis gate leads to the ruins of what was once the habitable part of the ca∫tle, in which a large vaulted hall is the mo∫t remarkable apartment; and under it, are dark, and capacious dungeons.

The area within the mote, which con∫i∫ts of ∫everal acres, was originally intended to ∫upport the cattle, which ∫hould be driven thither in times of alarm. When the hou∫e
was inhabited, (who∫e chearful and better days are ∫till remembered,) this area was the garden; and all around, on the out∫ide of the mote ∫tood noble trees, irregularly planted, the growth of a century. Beneath the trees ran a walk round the ca∫tle; to which the ∫ituation naturally gave that plea∫ing curve, which in modern days hath been ∫o much the object of art. This walk might admit of great embelli∫hment. On one hand, it commands the ruins of the ca∫tle in every point of view; on the other, a country, which, tho flat, is not unplea∫ing; con∫i∫ting of exten∫ive meadows, (which a little planting would turn into beautiful lawns,) bounded by lofty mountains.

This venerable pile has now undergone a ∫econd ruin. The old oaks and elms, the ancient natives of the ∫cene, are felled. Weeds and ∫piry gra∫s have taken po∫∫e∫∫ion of the courts, and obliterated the every plan of a garden: while the hou∫e it∫elf, (who∫e ho∫pitable roof de∫erved a better fate,) is now a ∫cene of de∫olation. Two wretched families, the only inhabitants of the place, occupy the two ends of the vaulted hall; the fragment of a tattered curtain, reaching half way to
the top, being the ∫imple boundary of their re∫pective limits. All the re∫t is wa∫te: no other part of the hou∫e is habitable. The chambers unwindowed, and almo∫t unroofed, fluttering with rags of ancient tape∫try, are the haunts of daws, and pigeons; which bur∫t out in the clouds of du∫t, when the doors are opened: while the floors, yielding to the tread, make curio∫ity dangerous. A few pictures, heir-looms of the wall, which have long de∫erved oblivion, by I know not what fate, are the only appendage of this di∫∫olving pile, which have triumphed over the injuries of time.

Shake∫pear's ca∫tle of Macbeth could not be more the haunt of ∫wallows and martins, than this. You ∫een them every where about the ruins; either twittering on broken coins'; threading ∫ome fracture arch; or pur∫uing each other, in ∫creaming circles, round the walls of the ca∫tle.
chap.note: In this old ca∫tle the author of this tour was born, and ∫pent his earl youth; which mu∫t be his apology for dwelling ∫o long upon it. -- Since this de∫cription was written, it has, in ∫ome degree, been repaired.

chap.title: Volume 2, Section XXII.
chap.head: SECT. XXII.
chap.p: OUR la∫t expedition, in the neighbourhood of Carli∫le, was to ∫ee the improvements of Mr. Graham of Netherby; and the ∫cene of de∫olation, occa∫ioned by the late overflowing of Solway-mo∫s.

Mr. Graham's improvements are not confined to a garden, or the ∫pace of a mile or two around his hou∫e. The whole country is changed; and from a barren wa∫te, hath a∫∫umed the face -- if not of beauty, at lea∫t of fertility.

The domain of Netherby lies on the very ∫kirts of the Engli∫h border. The Romans con∫idered it as a part of Caledonia; and ∫hut it from the Briti∫h pale. In after ages the di∫trict around it a∫∫umed the name of the
Debateable-land, and was the great rendezvous of tho∫e crews of outlawed banditti, who, under the denomination of Mo∫s-troopers, plundered the country. We have already had occa∫ion to mention them. In this neighbourhood were the ∫trong holds of many of their chiefs; particularly of Johnny Arm∫trong of famous memory; the moted ruins of who∫e ca∫tle are ∫till extant.
Among the∫e people the arts of tillage were unknown. It was ab∫urd to be at the trouble of ∫owing land them∫elves, when they could ∫o ea∫ily plunder the lands of others.

Tho the union of the two kingdoms put an end to the∫e ravages on the borders; yet the manners of the inhabitants, in ∫ome re∫pects, ∫uffered little change. Their native lazine∫s, and inattention to all the arts of hu∫bandry, remained. They occupied large tracts of excellent land at ea∫y rates: but having no idea of producing yearly crops from the ∫ame ∫oil by culture; they ploughed their patches of ground alternately, leaving them to recover their fertility by fallows. An indolent and ∫canty maintenance was all they wi∫hed; and this they obtained from a ∫mall portion of their land, with a ∫mall portion of their labour. Their
lords in the mean time, never lived on the ∫pot; and knew little of the ∫tate either of the country, or of it's inhabitants.

Mr. Graham immediately ∫et him∫elf to alter this ∫tate of things. He built a noble man∫ion for him∫elf; which makes a grand appearance, ri∫ing on the ruins of a Roman ∫tation. Without the pre∫ence of the lord, he knew it was in vain to expect reformation. He divided his lands into moderate farms; and built commodious farm-hou∫es. As his lands improved, he rai∫ed his rents: and his tenants in proportion found it nece∫∫ary to increa∫e their labour. Thus he has double his own income, and introduced a ∫pirit of indu∫try into the country. The∫e indolent inhabitants of the borders begin now to work like other labourers; and notwith∫tanding they pay higher rents, live more comfortably: for idlene∫s can never be attended with the comforts of indu∫try.

To bring about this great change, Mr. Graham thinks it nece∫∫ary to rule his ∫ubjects with a rod of iron. While he makes them labourers, he keeps them ∫laves. -- Perhaps indeed the rough manners of the people in
tho∫e parts, could not ea∫ily be moulded by the hand of tenderne∫s.

The feudal idea of va∫∫alage, which has long di∫appeared in all the internal parts of England, remains here in great force; and throws a large ∫hare of power into the hands of the landholder. Mr. Graham's e∫tates, which are very exten∫ive, contain about ∫ix hundred tenants; all of whom, with their families, lie in a manner at his mercy for their ∫ub∫i∫tence. Their time and labour he commands, by their mode of tenure, whenever he plea∫es. Under the denomination of boon-days, he expects, at any time, their per∫onal ∫ervice; and can, in a few hours, mu∫ter the ∫trength of five or ∫ix hundred men and hor∫es.

Once he had occa∫ion to call them together on military ∫ervice. On a ∫uppo∫ed injury, which, about two years ago, he had done the
Scotch-borders, by intercepting the ∫almon in the E∫k, a body of three hundred of the∫e people marched down upon him with an intention to de∫troy his works. He had intelligence of their de∫ign, and i∫∫uing his precepts, mu∫tered, in a few hours, above four hundred men before his gates, armed as the exigence would allow: and if the Scotch, on finding ∫uch ∫uperiority, had not retreated, Mr. Graham, who told us the ∫tory him∫elf, ∫aid he believed, that all the ∫pirit and animo∫ity of ancient times would have revived on this occa∫ion.
chap.note: I have heard ∫ince, that this injury has been proved to be a real one; and that reparation hath been made.
chap.p:
In a civil light he acts on as large a ∫cale. His manor-courts are kept with great ∫trictne∫s; in which his attorney, with a jury, ∫its regularly to try cau∫es; and the tenants are injoined, at the hazard of being turned out of their farms, to bring into the∫e courts every ∫uit under the value of five pounds. Thus he prevents much ill-blood among them, by bringing their di∫putes to a ∫peedy i∫∫ue; and giving the quarrel no time to rankle. He ∫aves them al∫o much expence: for a ∫uit, which in the
king's courts would at lea∫t co∫t five or ∫ix pounds; may in his, be carried through all it's forms for eight-pence. -- At Patterdale we found a nominal king. Here we found almo∫t a king in reality.

The works on the E∫k, which gave ∫o much offence to the Scotch-borderers, de∫erve more notice. They con∫i∫ted of a ma∫∫y head thrown acro∫s the river, con∫tructed at a great expence, hewn ∫tone. This mole was formed at right angles with the bank; but the floods of the en∫uing winter ∫wept it away. It was attempted a ∫econd time on the ∫ame plan; but was a ∫econd time de∫troyed. Mr. Brindley was then ∫ent for, who∫e works near Manche∫ter had given him ∫o high a reputation. He changed the plan; and in∫tead of carrying the mole in a direct line acro∫s the river, formed it in a curve, arching again∫t the ∫tream: ∫o that it re∫i∫ts the current, as a bridge does the incumbent weight. This work has ∫tood ∫everal very great floods, and ∫eems ∫ufficiently
firm. From the curvature of it's form the fall of the water appears al∫o to more advantage. It now forms a ∫emi-circular cove, which has a fine effect.
chap.note: Since this was written, I am informed, Mr. Brindley's work was de∫troyed from an un∫u∫pected quarter, when the water was low. On the breaking of a fro∫t, a great quantity of ice coming down the river, and collecting at this ∫toppage, ∫ome of it edged under the loo∫er parts of the foundation, and being pre∫∫ed on with a continued acce∫∫ion of ∫trength, the whole blew up.
chap.p: The chief end which this work had in view, was a fi∫hery. At this place ∫almon-coops are placed; where all the fi∫h, which enter the E∫k, are taken. But be∫ides this, and other purpo∫es of utility, it adds great beauty to the neighbourood. The E∫k, which was before in compari∫on, a ∫hallow ∫tream, gliding un∫een beneath it's banks, is now a noble piece of water, rai∫ed to a level with them, and ∫een to great advantage from the hou∫e, and every part of the ground.

It was in this part of the country where that dreadful inundation, from the over-flowing of
Solway-mo∫s, de∫troyed lately ∫o large a di∫trict. T ∫ee the effects of this, was the object of our next expedition.

Solway-mo∫s is a flat area, about ∫even miles in circumference. The ∫ub∫tance of it is a gro∫s fluid, compo∫ed of mud, and the putrid fibres of heath, diluted by internal ∫prings, which ari∫e in every part. The ∫urface is a dray cru∫t, covered with mo∫s, and ru∫hes; offering a fair appearance over an unfound bottom -- ∫haking under the lea∫t pre∫∫ure. Cattle by in∫tinct know, and avoid it. Where ru∫hes grow, the bottom is ∫ounde∫t. The adventrous pa∫∫enger therefore, who ∫ometimes, in dry ∫ea∫ons, traver∫es this perilous wa∫te to ∫ave a few miles, picks his cautious way over the ru∫hy tuffocks, as they appear before him. If his foot ∫lip, or if he venture to de∫ert this mark of ∫ecurity, it is po∫∫ible he may never more be heard of.

At the battle of Solway, in the time of Henry VIII, Oliver Sinclair was imprudently ∫et over the Scotch army, which had no confidence in him. A total rout en∫ued; when an unfortunate troop of hor∫e, driven by their fears, plunged into this mora∫s, which in∫tantly clo∫ed upon them. The tale, which
was traditional; was generally believed; but is now authenticated. A man and hor∫e in compleat armour were lately found by the peat-diggers, in the place, where it was always ∫uppo∫ed the affair had happened; and are pre∫erved at the hou∫e of a Scotch baronet, if I mi∫take not, of the name of Maxwell; as we were informed by a gentleman of the borders, who a∫∫ured us he had ∫een them him∫elf. The ∫keleton of each was well pre∫erved; and the different parts of the armour ea∫ily di∫tingui∫hed.
chap.note: Jo∫eph Dacre, E∫q; of Kirklinton, near Longtown.
chap.p: Solway-mo∫s is bounded on the ∫outh by a cultivated plain, which declines gently, through the ∫pace of a mile, to the river E∫k. This plain is rather lower than the mo∫s it∫elf, being ∫eparated from it by a brea∫twork formed by digging peat, which makes an irregular, tho perpendicular, line of low, black boundary.

It was the bur∫ting of the mo∫s through this peat brea∫twork, over the plain between it and the E∫k, which occa∫ioned that dreadful ruin, the effects of which we came hither to explore. -- The more remarkable circum∫tances, re-
lating to this calamitous event, as we had them on the be∫t authority, were the∫e.

On the 16th of November, 1771, in a dark tempe∫tuous night, the inhabitants of the plain were alarmed with a dreadful cra∫h, which they could in no way account for. Many of them were then abroad in the fields, watching their cattle; le∫t the E∫k, which was ri∫ing violently in the ∫torm, ∫hould carry them off. None of tho∫e mi∫erable people could conceive the noi∫e they heard to proceed from any cau∫e, but the overflowing of the river in ∫ome ∫hape, tho to them unaccountable. Such indeed, as liver nearer the ∫ource of the eruption, were ∫en∫ible, that the noi∫e came in different direction; but were equally at a lo∫s for the cau∫e.

In the mean time the enormous ma∫s of fluid ∫ub∫tance, which had bur∫t from the mo∫s, moved ∫lowly on, ∫preading it∫elf more and more, as it got po∫∫e∫∫ion of the plain. Some of the inhabitants, though the terror of the night, could plainly di∫cover it advancing, like a moving hill. This was in fact the ca∫e; for the gu∫h of mud carried before it,
through the fir∫t two or three hundred yards of it's cour∫e, a part of the brea∫twork; which, tho low, was yet ∫everal feet in perpendicular height. But it ∫oon depo∫ited this ∫olid ma∫s; and became a heavy fluid. One hou∫e after another, it ∫pread round -- filled -- and cru∫hed into ruin; ju∫t giving time to the terrified inhabitants to e∫cape. Scarce any thing was ∫aved; except their lives: nothing of their furniture: few of their cattle. Some people were even ∫urprized in their beds, and had the additional di∫tre∫s of flying naked from the ruin.

The morning-light explained the cau∫e of this amazing ∫cene of terror; and ∫hewed the calamity in it's full extent: and yet, among all the conjectures of that dreadful night, the mi∫chief which really happened, had never been ∫uppo∫ed. Who could have imagined, that a brea∫twork, which had ∫tood for ages, ∫hould at length give way? or that tho∫e ∫ubterraneous floods, which had been bedded in darkne∫s, ∫ince the memory of man, ∫hould ever bur∫t from their black abode?

This dreadful inundation, tho the fir∫t ∫hock of it was the mo∫t tremendous, continued ∫till ∫preading for many weeks, till it covered the whole plain -- an area of five hundred acres; and, like molten metal poured into a mould, filled all the hollows of it, lying in ∫ome parts thirty of forty feet deep, reducing the whole to one level ∫urface. The overplus found it's way into the E∫k; where it's quantity was ∫uch, as to annoy the fi∫h; no ∫almon, during that ∫ea∫on, venturing into the river. We were a∫∫ured al∫o, that many lumps of earth, which had floated out at ∫ea, were taken up, ∫ome months after, at the i∫le of Man.

As we de∫cended from the higher grounds to take a nearer view of this ∫cene of horror, it exhibited a very grand appearance. The whole plain was covered by a thick ∫moke, occa∫ioned by a ∫mothering fire ∫et to it in various parts, with a view to con∫ume it; and brought before us that ∫imple, and ∫ublime idea of the ∫moke of a country going up like the ∫moke of a furnace.

When we came to plain on that ∫ide, which is next the E∫k, it had ∫o forbidding an a∫pect, as far as we could di∫cover through the ∫moke, that we almo∫t de∫paired of cro∫∫ing to the cha∫m, as we had intended. On hor∫e-back it was impo∫∫ible; and when we had alighted, we ∫tood he∫itating on the brink, whether it were prudent, even on foot, to attempt ∫o dangerous a march.

While we remained in this ∫ituation, we ob∫erved ∫everal groups of pea∫ants working in the ruins: and beckoning to the neare∫t, one of the group came forward. He was an elderly man, ∫trengthening his ∫teps with a long mea∫uring wand. His feature, and gait, tho hard and clowni∫h, were marked with an air of vulgar con∫equence. As he approached, one of our company, who knew him, acco∫ted him by the name of Wil∫on; and we found he was the per∫on who conducted the works which were ∫et on foot to clear the ∫oil of this melancholy incumbrance.

On informing him of our difficulties, and a∫king, where we might venture acro∫s the plain; he bad us, like Cæ∫ar, with an air of a∫∫urance, follow him, and fear nothing. From one tu∫∫ock to another, we followed,
∫ometimes ∫tepping -- ∫ometimes leaping -- and ∫ometimes he∫itating, whether to go on, or to return. In very difficult places, our guide conde∫cended to lay us a plank. In the mid∫t of our perplexity, one of our company, ∫traying a ∫tep from the right path, fell in; but the mud being ∫hallow in that part, he ∫ank only to the knees. Mr. Wil∫on helped him out; but reprimanded his carele∫∫ne∫s. The reproof and the example having a good effect upon us all, we followed our guide, like pack-hor∫es in a ∫tring, and at length compleated our undertaking.

When we got to the gulph, from whence all this mi∫chief had i∫∫ued, the ∫pectacle was hideous. The ∫urface of the mo∫s it∫elf had ∫uffered little change. Near the cha∫m it appeared indented, through a ∫pace of ∫everal yards: but not in any degree, as one would have expected from ∫o ca∫t a di∫charge. The mouth of the cha∫m was heaped round by mon∫trous piles of ruin, formed by the broken brea∫twork, and the ∫hell of the mo∫s, on the fir∫t great bur∫t; and a black, mo∫∫y tincture continued ∫till to i∫∫ue from it. If this continue to run, as it probably will, it may be a fortunate circum∫tance; and ∫ave the country
from any farther mi∫chief, by draining this bloated ma∫s through a perpetual di∫charge.

As we ∫tood on the higher ground, and got to windward of the ∫moke, we obtained a clear idea of the plain, and of the cour∫e of the irruption over it. Many fragments of a very large ∫ize, which had been carried away in the fir∫t full ∫tream of the di∫charge, appeared thrown to a con∫iderable di∫tance. The∫e were what made that moving bulwark, which ∫ome of the inhabitants had ∫een in the night. Fragments of a ∫maller ∫ize, (and yet many of the∫e con∫iderable) appeared ∫cattered over the plain, as the heavy torrent was able to carry them. The inter∫tices between the fragments, which had been filled with fluid mo∫s, were now baked by the heat of the ∫un, and cru∫ted over like the great ∫urface of the mo∫s it∫elf. Here and there, along this ∫urface, the broken rafters of a hou∫e, or the top of a bla∫ted tree were ∫een; and made an odd appearance, ri∫ing as it were, out of the ground. But through the whole wa∫te, there was not the lea∫t ∫ign left of any culture; tho this plain had once been the pride of the country. Lands, which
in the evening would have let for twenty ∫hillings an acre, by the morning-light were not worth ∫ix-pence.

On this well cultivated plain twenty-eight families had their dwellings, and little farms; every one of which, except perhaps a few, who lived near the ∫kirts of it, had the world totally to begin again. -- Mr. Graham, agreeably to the prudential maxims he has ever ob∫erved, affords them little a∫∫i∫tance him∫elf; and di∫courages the bounty of others. -- He ∫eems to wi∫h his dominions ∫hould thrive by indu∫try alone; and would have his ∫ubjects depends on this great virtue for the ∫upply of every want, and the reparation of every lo∫s. If the maxim, in ∫o full an extent, be good; it requires at lea∫t, a great hardine∫s of re∫olution to carry it into practice.

Whether the immen∫e work of clearing this plain can ever totally be effected, is a doubt with many. It is attempted however with great ∫pirit, through the united force of the two powerful elements of fire and water.

All the ∫kirts, and other parts of it which are drier than the re∫t, are reduced by fire; which occa∫ioned the great ∫moke from the plain, as we have de∫cended into it; and which, at that di∫tance, appeared to ari∫e from the whole.

But this method is not found very effectual; as it reaches only a little below the ∫urface. Much more is expected from the application of water; which is the part our guide Mr. Wil∫on has undertaken. -- How well qualified he is for the undertaking, and in what manner he propo∫es to accompli∫h it, may be conceived from the following ∫tory.

Mr. Graham's hou∫e ∫tands on an eminence, with higher grounds above it. A little on one ∫ide of the front, ∫tood a knoll, which made a di∫agreeable appearance before his windows. -- Being de∫irous therefore of removing it, he ∫ent to Newca∫tle for a per∫on accu∫tomed to works of this kind. The undertaker came, ∫urveyed the ground, and e∫timated the expence at thirteen hundred pounds.

While the affair was in agitation, Mr. Graham heard, that Wil∫on had ∫aid, the earth
might be removed at a much ea∫ier rate. He was examined on the ∫ubject; and his an∫wers appeared ∫o rational, that he was ∫et to work. He had already ∫urveyed the higher grounds, where he fir∫t collected all the ∫prings he found, into two large re∫ervoirs; from which he cut a precipitate channel, points at an abrupt corner of the knoll. He cut al∫o a channel of communication between his two re∫ervoirs. The∫e being both filled, he opened his ∫luices, and let out ∫uch a continued torrent of water, (the upper pool feeding the lower) that he very ∫oon carried away the corner of the knoll, again∫t which he had pointed his artillery. He then charged again, and levelled again∫t another part with equal ∫ucce∫s. In ∫hort, by a few efforts of this kind, he carried away the whole hill; and told Mr. Graham, with an air of triumph, that, if he plea∫ed, he would carry away his hou∫e next. The work was compleated in a few days; and Mr. Graham him∫elf informed us, that the whole expence did not amount to twenty pounds.

This man, with ∫o much genius about him, lives in the lowe∫t ∫tile of life; and works for the lowe∫t wages. When we regretted, that he was paid ∫o inadequately to his worth, we
were a∫∫ured, as his appearance indeed te∫tified, that he had no higher idea of happine∫s, than to get drunk after his day's labour: and that better wages would only de∫troy him ∫ooner.

I have ∫ince heard, that one hundred and fifty acres of the plain are now cleared by the ingenuity of this man; and that there is rea∫on to believe, he will in time clear a con∫iderable part of it. From the re∫ervoirs formed by a little ∫tream at the highe∫t part of the over-flowed ground, he cut channels in various directions to the E∫k: and when the water was let off, he placed numbers of men by the ∫ide of the ∫tream, who rolled into it large ma∫∫es of mo∫∫y earth, which were hardened by the ∫un.

chap.title: Volume 2, Section XXII.
chap.head: SECT. XXII.
chap.p: HAVING ∫een ∫uch parts of the country on the borders of England, as were mo∫t curious; we ∫et out on our return. But, in∫tead of taking the Ke∫wick-road, we propo∫ed to vary our rout, by the mountains of Brugh..
chap.note: See page 168, Vol. I.
chap.p: At Penrith the road divides. We turned to the left, towards Appelby; and ∫oon fell into a rich, and beautiful vale, in which the river Lowther, gliding under lofty woody banks, bore us company a con∫iderable way.

When we cro∫∫ed that river, the ∫ituation of Brougham-ca∫tle, one of the ∫eat of the
celebrated counte∫s of Pembroke, attracted our notice. It had not e∫caped the notice of the Romans; who fixed here a ∫tation to command the country. It appears as great, at the time, in a picture∫que light, as it did formerly in a military one. But we had not time to ride up to it; contenting our∫elves with viewing it only as the ornament of a ∫econd di∫tance.

At Clifton the road opens again into a wild ∫cene. Here we examined the ∫pot, where, in the year 1745, the rebels entering an inclo∫ed country, made a ∫tand; and lined the hedges to retard the duke of Cumberland's pur∫uit. Sir Jo∫eph York, in his road from Ireland, had been there, we found, a few days before. He had accompanied the duke in his expedition again∫t the rebels; and ∫topped a little at Clifton to review the ∫cene. He left the people, we were informed, much plea∫ed with his remembering a gallant action, which had been achieved, about that time, by a heroine of the country, who had carried a letter acro∫s the fire of the rebels, when no other me∫∫enger could be obtained.

From Clifton, we turned a little a∫ide to ∫ee Lowther-hall, the ∫eat of lord Lond∫dale. It is only a temporary hou∫e, the old man∫ion having been burnt in the time of the late lord. But materials are now collecting for a grand ∫tructure. It is ∫ituated in an exten∫ive park, which contains a great variety of beautiful ∫cenery.
From Lowther-hall, we pur∫ued our rout to Appelby, keeping on our left that va∫t tract of barren country, called Wingfield-fore∫t.

The ∫ituation of Appelby-ca∫tle, which belongs to the earl of Thanet, is magnificent. It ∫tands on a rocky eminence, falling precipitately into the river Eden; which half incircles it. The banks of the river, and the ∫ides of the precipice, are finely hung with wood. The ca∫tle is ∫till in good repair; and is a noble pile. But, in a picture∫que light, it lo∫es half it's beauty, from it's being broken into two parts. A ∫maller break from a grand pile removes heavine∫s; and is a ∫ource
of beauty. We have ∫een the principle exemplified in mountains, and other objects. But here the whole is divided into two parts, of ∫uch equal dimen∫ions, that each a∫pires to pre-eminence. Each therefore becomes a ∫eparate whole: and both together di∫tract the eye. The detached part ∫hould always ob∫erve a due inferiority.
chap.note: See page 55, Vol. II.
chap.p: We had not time to take a view from the ca∫tle; which mu∫t command a very beautiful di∫tance, over the woody vale of Eden, and the mountains, which ari∫e beyond it.
Appelby-ca∫tle was the Apallaba of the Romans; and pre∫erves it's origin clearer in it's etymology, than the generality of Roman ∫tations.

This ca∫tle was formerly the favourite man∫ion of Ann, counte∫s of Pembroke, Dor∫et, and Montgomery. As this very extraordinary lady is ∫till the object of great veneration in the∫e parts; as her hi∫tory is curious, and le∫s known than it ought to be; and as it is ∫o
intimately connected with all this country; the reader will excu∫e the following digre∫∫ion.

She was the daughter of George Clifford, earl of Cumberland; one of the heroes of the gallant age of Elizabeth. This noble per∫on di∫tingui∫hed him∫elf chiefly by his naval expeditions; on which he was ∫uffered, in tho∫e frugal times, to expend a great portion of his patrimony. In return for his patrioti∫m, he was appointed by his royal mi∫tre∫s, her champion in all tilts and tournaments; where the grace, and dignity of his behaviour, and his ∫kill and addre∫s in arms, were equally admired. The rich armour he wore, on the∫e occa∫ions, is ∫till ∫hewn in this ca∫tle.

Lady Ann Cilfford was only ten years of age, when her father died. But her education was conducted by two excellent women -- her mother, a daughter of the earl of Bedford -- and afterwards by her aunt the counte∫s of Warwick.

In her early youth ∫he married lord Buckhur∫t, earl of Dor∫et; with whom during a few years ∫he lived very happily. But he ∫oon leaving her a widow; ∫he married, ∫ix years after, Philip earl of Pembroke, and Montgomery.

This nobleman, through the favour of James I, as a reward for his great ∫kill in the arts of hunting, and hawking, po∫∫e∫∫ed a prodigious e∫tate; not le∫s, at that time, than eighteen thou∫and pounds a year. His manner of living was ∫umptuous beyond example; and his apparatus for field-∫ports magnificent beyond belief. His dog-kennels were ∫uperb; and his ∫tables vied with palaces. But his falconry was his chief pride; which he had furni∫hed, at a wonderful expence, with birds of game; and proper per∫ons to manage, train, and exerci∫e them.

Here ends the hi∫tory of Philip early of Pembroke -- unle∫s we add, that in private life, he was vicious, ignorant, and unlettered in a ∫urprizing degree; and that his public character was ∫tained with ingratitude, and tergiver∫ation, by the noble hi∫torian of tho∫e unfortunate times.
With this worthle∫s man his unhappy lady lived near twenty years. During the latter part of his life indeed he became ∫o di∫∫olute, that ∫he was obliged to leave him.

About the time of his death ∫he found her∫elf po∫∫e∫∫ed of a very ample fortune. For, it ∫eems, her immediate ∫ucce∫∫ion to the large e∫tates of her ance∫tors in the north, had been di∫puted by an uncle, who inherited the title: and an award had been given again∫t her by James I, to which indeed ∫he would never ∫ubmit. The uncle, and his ∫on however both dying, the great e∫tates of the Cliffords, tho con∫iderably impaired by her father's genero∫ity, came to her without any farther mole∫tation. She had be∫ides two great jointures. That which ∫he received from her fir∫t hu∫band, was between three, and four thou∫and, a year; and that from the early of Pembroke was nearly equal to it.
On the event of the earl of Pembroke's death, ∫he immediately laid out the whole plan of her future life; determining to retire into the north; and ∫pend it on her own e∫tate.

In ancient times the earls of Cumberland po∫∫e∫∫ed five noble ca∫tles in the three counties of York∫hire, We∫tmoreland, and Cumberland. -- Skipton -- Pendragon -- Appelby -- Brougham -- and Brugh. The tower of Bardon al∫o was another fortified ∫eat, where they ∫ometimes re∫ided. But all the∫e ca∫tles had ∫uffered in the late civil wars; and were reduced, more or le∫s, to a ∫tate of great decay.

The counte∫s of Pembroke however determined, on her coming into the north, to repair and furni∫h them all. This great work ∫he compleated during the years 1657, and 1658; and placed over the gate of each ca∫tle the following in∫cription:

THIS CASTLE WAS REPAIRED BY THE LADY AN CLIFFORD, COUNTESS DOWAGER OF PEMBROKE, &c. IN THE YEAR -- AFTER THE MAIN PART OF IT HAD LAIN RUINOUS EVER SINCE 1648, WHEN IT WAS DEMOLISHED, ALMOST TO THE GROUND BY THE PARLIAMENT THEN SITTING AT WESTMINSTER, BECAUSE IT HAD BEEN A GARRISON IN THE CIVIL WARS. IS. LVIII. 12. LAUS DEO!

Oliver Cromwell was, at this time, at the head of affairs; who∫e hypocri∫y and villany the counte∫s of Pembroke dete∫ted: and as ∫he had too much ∫pirit to conceal her ∫entiments, it is probable, the protector was enough informed, how little ∫he e∫teemed him. Her friends therefore, knowing the jealou∫y of his temper, advi∫ed her not to be ∫o profu∫e in building; as they were well a∫∫ured that as ∫oon as ∫he had built her ca∫tles, he would order them to be de∫troyed. But ∫he an∫wered with great ∫pirit, "Let him de∫troy them if he will: but he ∫hall ∫urely find, that as often as he de∫troys them, I will rebuild them, while he leaves me a ∫hilling in my pocket."

She ∫hewed her contempt for Cromwell, and her own high ∫pirit, on another occa∫ion. Her uncle had left her affairs ∫o involved, that ∫he found her∫elf under a nece∫∫ity of recovering ∫ome of her rights by a tedious law∫uit. The affair being repre∫ented to Cromwell by the oppo∫ite party, he offered his mediation. But ∫he an∫wered loftily, ∫he would never accept it, while there was any
law to be found in England. "What! ∫aid ∫he, does he imagine, that I, who refu∫ed to ∫ubmit to king James, will ∫ubmit to him?"

But, notwith∫tanding her ∫pirit, neither her ca∫tles, nor her e∫tates were injured. Some a∫cribed this lenity to Cromwell's reverence of her virtue; which is very improbable: others, to her numerous friends, with whom the protector wi∫hed to keep fair; which, it is mo∫t likely, was the truth.

Her di∫like to Cromwell was not founded on party; but on principle. She had the ∫ame di∫like to Charles, when ∫he became acquainted with the ∫pirit of his government. On being pre∫∫ed by her friends, ∫ometimes after the re∫toration, to go to court; "By no means, ∫aid ∫he; unle∫s I may be allowed to wear blinkers."
chap.note: Blinkers are tho∫e blinds affixed to the bridles of coach-hor∫es, which prevent their ∫eeing what they ought not to ∫ee.
chap.p:
Be∫ides her ca∫tles, ∫he found likewi∫e in ruins, almo∫t all the churches, belonging
to the ∫everal villages on her e∫tates. The ∫pire of one had been beaten down: another had been turned into a magazine: a third into a ho∫pital. Seven of them were in this ruinous condition: each of which ∫he either built from the ground, or repaired; furni∫hing them all with decent pews; that her tenants, in every part of her e∫tates, might have churches in their neighbourhood.
Her ∫everal buildings, and repairs, at her fir∫t coming into the north, did not co∫t her le∫s, than forty thou∫and pounds.

At each of her ca∫tles ∫he re∫ided a part of every year; regularly moving from one to the other; thus over-looking the whole of her va∫t e∫tates; and ble∫∫ing the country, wherever ∫he went. For ∫he was every where the common patrone∫s of all, who were di∫tre∫∫ed. Her heart was as large, as her ability: and mi∫ery of every kind, that could get it's ∫tory fairly repre∫ented to her, was ∫ure of relief.
Nor was ∫he content with occa∫ional acts of charity; but made many of her charitable intentions permanent by endowments. The greate∫t of the∫e works were two ho∫pitals, which ∫he founded.

One little plea∫ing monument of this kind ∫tands by the ∫ide of the road, between Penrith and Appelby. It is a monument indeed rather of her filial piety, than of her charity. On this ∫pot, in her early youth, ∫he had parted with her beloved mother; whom ∫he never afterwards ∫aw. She always remembered this parting-∫cene with the tendere∫t feelings: and, when ∫he came into We∫tmoreland, among her other buildings, ∫he rai∫ed a pillar to record it; with a ∫tone-table at it's ba∫e. The pillar, which is ∫till known in the country by the name of Counte∫s-pillar, is decorated with her arms; a ∫undial, for the benefit or travellers; and the following in∫cription.

THIS PILLAR WAS ERECTED IN THE YEAR 1656, BY ANN COUNTESS DOWAGER OF PEMBROKE, &c. FOR A MEMORIAL OF HER LAST PARTING, IN THIS PLACE, WITH HER GOOD AND PIOUS MOTHER, MARGARET, COUNTESS DOWAGER OF CUMBERLAND, ON THE 2d OF APRIL 1616: IN MEMORY WHEREOF SHE HATH LEFT AN ANNUITY OF £4. TO BE DISTRIBUTED TO THE POOR OF THE PARISH OF BROUGHAM, EVERY 2d DAY OF APRIL FOR EVER, UPON THE STONE-TABLE PLACED HARD BY. LAUS DEO!

Her very hou∫e-hold was a noble charity. Her ∫ervants were generally the children of her tenants; and were ∫ure of a provi∫ion, if they behaved well. Her women-∫ervants had always little portions given them, to begin the world with, if they married to plea∫e her.

The calamities of the times al∫o, during Cromwell's government, particularly the di∫tre∫∫ed ∫ituation of ∫everal ejected mini∫ters of the church, furni∫hed her with ample opportunities of exerting her genero∫ity. Among others, ∫he was particularly kind to King, afterwards bi∫hop of Chiche∫ter; and Duppa, and Morley, both afterwards bi∫hops of Winche∫ter. To each of the∫e ∫he allowed 40£. a year; and when, in their di∫tre∫∫es abroad, they informed her, that a ∫um of money would be of more ∫ervice to them, than the annuities ∫he was plea∫ed to give them; ∫he remitted a thou∫and pounds to be divided among them.
She was a lady of uncommon prudence in the management of her affairs. Be∫hope Rainbow ∫ums up her character on this head, in two words, by calling her a perfect mi∫tre∫s of foreca∫t, and afterca∫t.

For the numberle∫s acts of bounty, that flowed from her ∫he depended on two things --
her exactne∫s in keeping accounts; and her great economy.

With regard to the former, in whatever ca∫tle ∫he re∫ided, an office was kept, in which all her receipts, and di∫bur∫ements were entered with commercial punctuality. Of her private charities, ∫he kep an account her∫elf: but was ∫o exact, that, at any time by comparing it with her public accounts, ∫he had, at once, a compleat view of the ∫ituation of her affairs.

Her economy was equal to her exactne∫s. Nothing was ∫pent in vanity. Nothing was trifled away. All her family-expences were under the article of nece∫∫aries: and the very form of regularity, in which they con∫tantly ran, made one year a check upon another.

The ∫pirit, which ∫he ∫hewed in defending her rights, may perhaps be mentioned al∫o among her plans of economy. It was a ∫pirit not often exerted; but when it was rai∫ed, it always carried her vigorously to the end of the que∫tion; and, no doubt, ∫ecured her from many contentions, which might otherwi∫e have di∫turbed her, in the mid∫t of ∫o complex a property; and in tho∫e dubious
days, when legal rights were ∫o much unhinged. I have mentioned her ∫pirit, in one ∫uit, with regard to an affair of con∫equence. We have an account of another of le∫s importance.

It was a cu∫tom, on all her e∫tates, fro each tennant to pay, be∫ides his rent, an annual boon-hen, as it was called. This had ever been acknowledged a ju∫t claim; and is, I believe, to this day, paid on many of the great e∫tates in the north; being generally con∫idered as a ∫teward's perquisite.

It happened, that a rich clothier from Halifax, one Murgatroyd, having take a tenement near Skipton, was called upon by the ∫teward of the ca∫tle for his boon-hen. On his refu∫al to pay it, the counte∫s ordered a ∫uit to be commenced again∫t him. He was ob∫tinate; and ∫he determined; ∫o it was carried into length. At la∫t ∫he recovered her hen; but at the expence of 200£. -- It is ∫aid, that after the affair was decided, ∫he invited Mr. Murgatroyd to dinner; and drawing the hen to her, which was ∫erved up as the fir∫t di∫h, "Come, ∫aid ∫he, Mr. Murgatroyd, let us now be good friends: Since
you al the hen to be dre∫∫ed at my table, we'll divide it between us."

She had mind improved, and cultivated in many parts of learning. Dr. Donn, in his humourous manner, u∫ed to ∫ay, ∫he knew how to conver∫e of every thing; from prede∫tination to ∫lea-∫ilk. But hi∫tory ∫eems to have been her chief amu∫ement; to the ∫tudy of which ∫he was probably fir∫t led, by examining the hi∫tory of her own ance∫tors. This indeed comprehended, in a great degree, the hi∫tory of England from the times of the conque∫t: for there were few ∫cenes of public life, in which her progenitors, the Veteriponts and the Cliffords, an active race of men, were not deeply engaged.
chap.note: A kind of raw ∫ilk u∫ed, at that time, in embroidery.
chap.p:
She ∫eems to have entertained a de∫ign of collecting two materials for a hi∫tory of the∫e two potent northern families. At a great expence ∫he employed learned men to make collections, for this purpo∫e, from the records in the tower; the rolls; and other depo∫itaries of
public papers; which being all fairly tran∫cribed, filled three large volumes. This work, which contains a great variety of original characters, exerting them∫elves on very important occa∫ions, exerting them∫elves on very important occa∫ions, is ∫till among the family-records at Appelby-ca∫tle.

While ∫he was thus careful to pre∫erve the honour of her ance∫tors; ∫he in∫tituted a very ∫evere hi∫torical re∫traint, if I am ∫o call it, on her∫elf. In a large folio volume, which made a part of her equipage, when ∫he travelled from one ca∫tle to another, ∫he ordered an entry to be made, under her own in∫pection, of the tran∫actions of every day. To what particulars this journal extended, I have not learned. But if it was kept, as it probably was, by a confidential ∫ecretary, it might have included very minute particulars. What an intere∫ting collection of valuable anecdotes might be furni∫hed from the incidents of ∫uch a life! What a ∫atyr would it be on the vanity, the di∫∫ipation, and frivolous employments of the generality of the great! This work, I am informed, is ∫till extant; and in the hands of the earl of Thanet.

But the mo∫t con∫picuous part of the character of this illu∫trious lady, was her piety, and great attachment to religion. No doubt the amiable in∫tructors of her youth had given her di∫po∫ition, which was naturally ∫erious, a proper direction: but perhaps the be∫t ∫chool, in which ∫he had learned to think ju∫tly, was, that ∫chool of affliction, the hou∫e of her ∫econd hu∫band, the earl of Pembroke; who∫e di∫∫ipated, abandoned life taught her, more than any thing el∫e, the vanity of all earthly things, unle∫s u∫ed for the purpo∫es they were given.

Few divines were better ver∫ed in ∫cripture, than ∫he was. She could quote it pertinently on all occa∫ions; and never failed to read a portion of it every day; or have it read to her, in the latter part of her life.
The new te∫tament was her principal ∫tudy. Next to it ∫he was particularly fond of the p∫alms of David; and had tho∫e appointed for the day, read regularly to her.

She had been bred up in the church of England from her youth; and tho ∫he could not, in the fanatical times of the u∫urpation, attend any public ∫ervice; yet in the wor∫t
of tho∫e times ∫he never failed to hear the church-∫ervice in her own private chapels, which ∫he had been careful to fit up in all her ca∫tles. Many menaces of ∫eque∫trations ∫he received from the ruling powers, if ∫he per∫i∫ted in that practice. But ∫he ∫hewed the ∫ame ∫pirit on this occa∫ion, which ∫he had ∫hewn on many others. She continued her practice; and left them to do as they plea∫ed. No attempts however were made again∫t her.

She had no idea of pomp, and grandeur. With regard to her∫elf, her mode of living was rather par∫imonious. Amid∫t all the objects of her genero∫ity, her∫elf was the only per∫on forgotten. In her diet ∫he was even ab∫temious; and would ∫ometimes plea∫antly boa∫t, that ∫he had ∫carce ever ta∫ted wine, or phy∫ick; during her whole life. Of the elegance of dre∫s ∫he had never been fond; but in her latter life ∫he laid it intirely a∫ide; wearing nothing, for many years, but a clo∫e habit of plain, black ∫erge; which occa∫ioned many plea∫ant mi∫takes between her, and her attendants.

Her retinue was merely for u∫e, not parade. Be∫ides her common dome∫ticks, ∫he had al-
ways two ladies of education, who lived with her. Many hours ∫he ∫pent alone: at other times, they read to her, and were her companions.
Her chief expence, as far as concerned her∫elf, was in books. Her library was ∫tored with all the be∫t writers in the Engli∫h language. She knew no other.

Such was the life of this excellent lady; equally ∫uited to any ∫tation, in which God had plea∫ed to place her. It was a life of no more indulgence, than the mo∫t abridged circum∫tance would have allowed. Her ability in doing good, was that only, in which ∫he exceeded others.

She lived twenty-∫ix years, after the death of her ∫econd hu∫band: Providence lengthening out her life, as a ble∫∫ing to the country, beyond her eightieth year. The 23d of March 1675 was the day of her di∫∫olution -- one of the mo∫t melancholy days the northern counties ever experienced.

In her ended the noble family of the Cliffords. Her daughter Margaret, by the earl of Dor∫et (her ∫ole ∫urviving heire∫s) marry-
ing the earl of Thanet, carried the Clifford e∫tates into the Tufton family.
chap.note: The mo∫t material part of this little hi∫tory is taken from a MS life of Mr. Sedgwick, her ∫ecretary, written by him∫elf. In this work Mr. Sedgwick occa∫ionally in∫erts a few circum∫tances relating to his lady. -- It is a pity he had not given her the better ∫hare. His MS is ∫till extant in Appelby-ca∫tle.

chap.title: Volume 2, Section XXIV.
chap.head: SECT. XXIV.
chap.p: FROM Appelby-ca∫tle we ∫oon approach the barrier-mountains: but we approach them, in the u∫ual order of nature, by regular progre∫s. The ground is fir∫t high, before it becomes mountainous; and tillage appears in ∫canty plots, before cultivation cea∫es.

A little to the north of Brugh, the ground on the left, makes a ∫ingular appearance. A hill, on which a fair is annually held, forms an exact, ∫emi-circular convex. Scarce a knoll, or bu∫h break the regularity of the line. Beyond this, but without any intervening ground, ri∫es a range of di∫tant mountains. The∫e wore a light purple hue, when we ∫aw them -- the circular hill, a deep green. Perhaps no di∫po∫ition of ground was ever more totally
unpicture∫que: and yet even this (∫uch is the force of contra∫t) if it be only bi∫ected, and in a ∫mall degree adorned, is not wholly di∫agreeable.

At the commencement of the mountains ∫tand the town, and ca∫tle of Brugh, not unplea∫antly ∫eated. The ca∫tle which con∫i∫ts, like that at Appelby, of two parts, ∫eems to have been a very ∫trong place. Since the time of it's la∫t noble inhabitant, the counte∫s of Pembroke, it has been falling fa∫t into ruin; but we found it no ea∫y matter, even yet, to ∫cale the out-works of it's earthen mounds: ∫o ∫trong a fortre∫s hath it once been. -- Some parts of it, e∫pecially a ∫hattered round tower, are very picture∫que.

We had not the opportunity of ∫eeing this ca∫tle in ∫o advantageous a light, as had favoured us, when we ∫aw the ca∫tle of Penrith. We ∫aw them both in the evening; but here we had no bright beam of ∫un-∫et to illumine the ruins. And yet the effect was grand. The ca∫tle and land∫cape around, were in deep ∫hadow; under the influence of a retiring ∫torm, which had hung a ∫ettled gloom on all
the upper regions of the ∫ky. The ∫un was invi∫ible; but had fired the whole we∫tern horizon with a deep red. We viewed the ca∫tle from the ea∫t; and had therefore the ruddy part of the hemi∫phere as a back-ground to the grey tints, and ∫trong ∫hadows of the towers, and battlements, which intervened. The∫e, with the deep ∫olemnity of the gloom, were a ∫ufficient balance to the glowing red of the horizon, which would otherwi∫e have been too glaring. But the whole was in perfect harmony; and had a fine effect. -- Indeed nature's colouring is rarely without harmony. If the lights be glowing, the ∫hades are proportionably deep: on the contrary, if the lights decay, the ∫hadows decay with them; and as light is also the ∫ource of colour, the land∫cape wears always one uniform hue. Either the ∫ober colouring prevails, or one vivid tint ∫upports another. In compo∫ition, we have found, that nature may be improved; but in the beauty, and proportion of her tints, in the harmony
of her colouring, ∫he is an undeviating model of perfection.
chap.note: See the idea of improving natural compo∫ition, explained, p. 119, &c. Vol. I.
chap.p: The ∫quare tower, which made the grand part of the ca∫tle, conveyed, as we looked into it, a very horrid idea. Mo∫t of the∫e old ∫tructures have ∫uffered great external dilapidations. But here the shell was intire; and all the internal parts were gone -- the roof, the ∫tories, and even the vault over the dungeon. The whole was a mere excavation. I know not, that I was ever ∫truck with a more horrid idea of the kind. The eye, confined within the walls of a va∫t tower, open to the ∫ky above, which loured with unu∫ual blackne∫s, looked down with hideous contra∫t, deep into a dungeon below.

The whole road, over the mountains of Stainmore, from Brugh-ca∫tle to Bowes-ca∫tle, which is about thirteen miles, is the mo∫t unplea∫ant that can be conceived; and the more ∫o, as it reminded us of the ∫ublime ∫cenes, which we had pa∫∫ed, in another part of this chain, between Amble∫ide and Ke∫wick.
